name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the Statements by the European Council and the Commission on the conclusions of the European Council meeting of 15 and 16 October 2020, in particular the negotiations on future relations with the United Kingdom (2020/2773(SDR)). I would remind honourable Members that for all the debates during this part-session there is no catch-the-eye procedure, nor will applications for 'blue cards' or points of order be accepted, because of the obvious organisational conditions in which this plenary takes place. There are also possible remote intervention from the European Parliament's liaison offices in the Member States, an unprecedented procedure which is proceeding very efficiently.

name: Charles Michel
text: President of the European Council. Mr President, Brexit means Brexit like Theresa May said. But Brexit also means making choices about our future relationship. We want a deal but not at any cost. The European Council was extremely clear, we are 100% united and we expressed our unwavering support to our chief negotiator Michel Barnier and we re-confirmed all the principles of his mandate. In fact, we face three extremely difficult issues: the level playing field; governance; fisheries, and we need to find solutions in line with our principles. On the level playing field it's a matter of the integrity of the single market, a question of fair competition. Our UK friends say they want to maintain the highest standards. If that's the case, why don't they commit to them? We don't need words, we need guarantees. The same goes for governance; the internal market bill, which clearly violates the withdrawal agreements, reminds us just how important this is. What's the point of negotiating, signing and ratifying an international agreement if it is not implemented in full? In case of violation of the agreement we need to be able to bring the dispute to binding independent arbitration and get a swift resolution. Lastly on fisheries. Brexit was not our decision and it was not our fishermen's decision. Stopping access to UK water would cause extraordinary damage to our fishing fleets. Yes, we want to keep access to UK waters for fishermen, exactly like the UK wants to keep access to a huge and diversified markets for its companies.  Mr President, dear Members of Parliament, in June 2016 the United Kingdom took a democratic decision to leave the European Union. We respected this sovereign decision in 2016, and we respect sovereignty now, UK sovereignty now. Our UK friends say they want an ambitious and close relationship. We welcome this because we want the same, but the UK wants access to a single market while at the same time being able to digress from our standards and regulations when it follows them.  You can't have the butter, the butter money and the creamer's smile. You can't have your cake and eat it too. In fact, the United Kingdom now has an important choice to make about its own future. It's not about choosing a negotiation tactic, it's about choosing the model of society, the model of economy for their own future. Do our British friends want to regulate state aid? And do they want to maintain high standards in health, food security or climate, in close relationship with Europe? If so, why not commit to them in our future agreement?  Ladies and gentlemen, we are determined to ensure that all businesses - British, Chinese, European or from anywhere - follow the same principles when operating in our market. It's only fair.  Time is very short and we stand ready to negotiate 24/7 on all subjects, based on legal texts. The UK has a big decision to make. It's their free and sovereign choice and we will always respect them whatever choice they make but that sovereign answer will determine the level of access to our internal market, this is just common sense. We want a deal that is fair and balanced but we are also ready in case of no-deal.  Ladies and gentlemen, our strategy 'with Africa and not for Africa' was another important topic of our meeting. We need more than a partnership with Africa. We need a new alliance with this continent. Africa is more than just a neighbour. Africa is a natural partner because of our geography, our history and our cultures. Today, our two continents are more interdependent than ever and there is enormous potential for even greater cooperation. We need to harness the vast opportunities for the benefit of people on both continents and the economic dimension of a partnership will be key. Investments and financing would be crucial in the digital and knowledge economy, in renewable energy and in transport, health, agri-food systems.  One word on debt relief - we fully support international efforts on debt relief, especially in the context of G20, and we are ready to intensify talks in order to deliver on that, but all global players should do their part. We also stand ready to further support efforts on rule of law, peace and security, good governance and, of course, human rights. We want to work with our African partners on mobility and addressing all aspects of migration. We want a mutually beneficial partnership that's balanced and comprehensive, guided by the principles of solidarity and shared responsibility and we stand ready to step up cooperation in the multilateral organizations and fora. We will complete it together with our African partners at our next meeting with the African Union later this year.  We also had an orientation debate on climate. We want climate neutrality by 2050, as we decided last year, and to get there we need to update our 2030 target. We discussed the Commission's 2030 climate proposal, including the emissions reduction target of at least 55% by 2030 and we'll come back to this topic in December.  We will come back to this subject in December, our aim being to reach an agreement on this subject at The European Council level before the end of the year. It will be a difficult debate, we measure it well. We will have to take into account the different starting points and circumstances in different countries, but keep in mind this ambition to make the Green Pact for Europe the engine for development, the engine for prosperity and well-being in Europe and, more broadly, in the world. It is also the meaning of climate diplomacy that we are trying to activate with great force and ambition. Colleagues, as you know, not only has COVID-19 not disappeared, but we are even dealing with the second wave and it is brutal. It is painful, once again, for the victims, for their families, for carers, all over Europe, for all those who are directly mobilized to deal with this hard crisis that is hitting the world and which is also hitting Europe. As you have seen, in several European countries, severe restrictive measures have again had to be taken to contain the spread of the virus. We had an intense debate on the subject, we felt that we should continue to significantly strengthen efforts for more cooperation and coordination at the European level. That we must try to make progress in order to improve the capacity to deal together with the issue of travel within the European Union; cooperating to try to harmonize quarantine issues and having rules that are more coherent between European countries on the subject and above all - this is, in my opinion, the key issue for the coming weeks, probably in the coming months, pending a vaccine that can make a lasting difference, on the issue of testing and the issue of tracing. fundamental and extremely important. We had the opportunity to have an exchange fuelled by the work of the Commission and by the work of the German rotating presidency. We agreed that very regularly, including through videoconferences at the heads of state or government level, we would come back to this subject to try to provide the right impetus for projects to be carried out. This question of COVID-19 naturally brings me to the question of consequences as well. It is not just the harsh psychological consequences for our citizens, not just the harsh social consequences, in relation to the economic impacts that are hitting and will hit hard economic activities, which will singularly affect sectors more sensitive than others to the consequences of this difficult situation. This naturally brings me to the question of the European budget and the European stimulus fund. We have had the opportunity, Mr President, to have an exchange with you on this issue. I hope, once again, that the next few days will be an opportunity for all of us to be truly committed in order to be able to live up to it, to guarantee European credibility, to ensure that the strong and historic guidelines, I want to stress once again, taken at European Council level in July, also thanks to the , it is true, the impulses given by the European Parliament before July, can give rise to an implemented decision. In fact, it is a question of ensuring that, as soon as possible, European citizens and European businesses can benefit from the positive effects of this ambition for recovery, for economic support, for support for prosperity and well-being, throughout Europe.

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, President of the European Council, honourable Members of the European Parliament, I have pleasure in addressing you today on behalf of the President of the Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, who is, as I am sure you are aware, in preventive self-isolation. There is a question that is on every European’s mind today: when will the pandemic finally pass? No one has the answer. The second wave has come. Infections are rising at a worrying speed again and our Member States again have to take action to contain the second wave and eventually to stop it. Since the first wave hit us, Europe has achieved a lot. Let me just name our main strands of work: vaccines, European coordination and our resilience to prevent future crises. First, progress on vaccines. We now have three contracts in place with pharmaceutical companies and three more are being finalised. This means that, if they manage to develop a vaccine, there will be doses reserved for Europeans. It also means that all Member States will get a future vaccine on the same terms and at the same time. Last week, the European Commission delivered a vaccination plan, a European framework on who should get the vaccine first. Our vaccination plan is based on science and on common sense. Health workers will take precedence. High on the list will also be people over 60, people at risk because of their health and of course essential workers, people who cannot socially distance and people who are disadvantaged because of their socioeconomic background. We want to protect these people because it’s not only a matter of social justice. We believe it’s the smartest way to ease the pressure on our health system and slow down contagion. Second, progress on European coordination. Last week, the Council adopted the Commission’s proposal on colour codes and data exchange. This means that all Member States are now speaking the same language when it comes to their citizens’ health and it means clarity for people who need to travel across the border. It is now essential to implement these decisions in full and it is also essential to agree on common rules on testing and quarantine. From Spain to Sweden, we are all facing the same disease so our precautions against it should also be the same. But we are also aware that we still have a long way to go. It will be months before a vaccine is found and distributed. We must be very disciplined and help everyone to contain the spread of the virus as much as possible in the coming weeks and months. If we fail to do so, we run the risk not only of losing the achievements in the area of health protection, but we are also risking Europe’s economic recovery, which we launched with great effort before the summer break. No one in Europe wants a second lockdown. People don’t want that and companies don’t want it either. That is why I call on European citizens to behave responsibly. Protect yourself and others. But there is also a lot at stake economically in other areas. The President of the European Council, Charles Michel, has just touched upon them, namely our negotiations with the United Kingdom and our climate target for 2030. Let me first update you on our negotiations with the UK. The deal we are trying to achieve would be absolutely unprecedented. This was the will of the EU and the UK when agreeing on the scope of the future partnership in our joint political declaration and it is still our will. No other economy is as closely aligned to ours as the British economy. It is only natural after almost 40 years as a part of the single market. UK companies produce the same products, within the same value chains, and with almost no transport costs to reach our market. We need to ensure that the European Union and the United Kingdom’s companies face fair competition on the EU market. This is why we have put so much emphasis on ensuring a level playing field and on governance and conflict resolution.  Together with fisheries, these are the main outstanding issues where we are still far apart. On each of these issues, we still have to test whether it is possible to find common ground with our British friends. This needs hard work. We have made it clear that we are ready to engage intensively to find solutions. There is no time to lose. Our objective is still to reach an agreement that will pave the way for a new fruitful relationship between the EU and the UK. We will continue to work for such an agreement, but not at any price. My good colleague and friend, Michel Barnier, will provide you with additional information on the subject. If you allow me, I will now turn to the Withdrawal Agreement, which must be fully operational as of 1 January 2021. Deal or no deal, the Withdrawal Agreement must be respected.  (Applause) It is not only a matter of trust, which is of course key, but also of political responsibility vis-à-vis our citizens and peace and stability on the island of Ireland. Therefore I welcome that, at the last Joint Committee meeting, we managed to strike a constructive approach. Now it will be vital that this translates into concrete workable operational solutions. Finally, let me say a few words on our climate ambitions. Two weeks ago, this Parliament voted for a very ambitious recommendation. The European Council has not yet reached an agreement on targets and percentages but, rest assured, the Commission will continue to push for Europe’s Heads of State and Government to unite behind an ambitious climate objective of at least 55% by 2030 and this agreement must come before the end of the year.  Last week, we presented two more stepping stones to pave the way towards 55%, the renovation wave and the methane strategy. Our next steps will include revision of the Emissions Trading System, the strategy for offshore wind, the revised regulation for the trans-European energy networks, the mobility strategy and the new proposal for the circular economy. We have a plan that can lead us to 55% and, thanks to Next Generation EU, we have the resources to turn it into reality. We know how we can achieve this goal, but it is also important to remind ourselves why we are doing it. We are going for at least 55% because this is the only way to contain global warming. We made a commitment in Paris and we want to keep our word, but we are also doing this because it makes sense economically. If we go for at least 55%, it will strengthen our first-mover advantage in clean technologies. Our companies will be the leaders in tomorrow’s markets. We will become less dependent on energy imports from the rest of the world. As we work here in Europe, they are also engaging on the global stage so that other countries match our ambition. Europe wants to lead the way and today many others are following our example but never forget that in the near future companies will compete on international markets based on who has the best green technologies. We have to increase the pace of green innovation to remain competitive. It is the right thing to do and the smartest choice as well. Fifty—five percent is an insurance on Europe’s future. I have to repeat and underline that it’s decision time. Europe must be ambitious for our planet, for our economy and for our next generation.

name: Michel BARNIER
text: Head of the task force for relations with the United Kingdom. Mr President, thank you also, Mr President, and to Maroe 'eef-ovi' for allowing me to say a few words now about this negotiation for which I am responsible under your authority. I would also like to begin by personally thanking Maroe 'Eef-ovi' for the work he is doing, I can tell you, with great determination and rigour to lead the Joint Committee on the Implementation - the Proper Implementation - of the Withdrawal Agreement. This is a fundamental point in its connection to the negotiation, because as all your group chairs reminded you together a few weeks ago, it is a matter of trust. To build a new agreement on the future relationship, we need confidence in the implementation of the existing agreement. The European Council, as Charles Michel said, was a very important moment for this negotiation: this European Council reaffirmed to our British partners and friends that the European Union wants an agreement, an agreement in the mutual benefit of each party, respecting the autonomy and sovereignty of each side, and which reflects a balanced compromise. However, there will be no agreement at any price, as our President Ursula von der Leyen has made very clear and repeatedly. This is the position at the heart of the mandate entrusted to me, confirmed by your Parliament and confirmed by the European Council, also reaffirming our constructive attitude to continue the discussion and negotiation. I would like to remind you that the attitude of the European Union in this negotiation has not changed and will not change until the last day. We will remain calm, we will remain constructive, we will remain respectful but also, of course, firm and determined in defending the principles and interests of each of the countries of the European Union and the European Union itself. We will seek the necessary compromises on both sides to reach an agreement until the last useful day and our door will always remain open.  As has been said at the time by President Charles Michel and by Maroe 'Eef-ovi', we are ready to intensify our discussions at any time and on all subjects, and to do so on the basis of legal texts, since it is a matter of agreeing, of negotiating an agreement in the form of an international treaty, and therefore a legal document. We and my team were ready to come to London on Monday, early this week. What will not change, either, is the framework we have set on behalf of the European Union for this ambitious partnership with the United Kingdom, which is in accordance with our decision-making autonomy; respecting the integrity of the internal market; and which preserves the long-term economic, political and social interests of all countries, citizens and businesses in the European Union. These principles have been stated and stated by the Union since the very moment when the United Kingdom chose - as is its sovereign choice - to leave the European Union more than four years ago. These principles are, of course, from my point of view compatible with respect for British sovereignty, which is a legitimate concern of Boris Johnson's government. What is at stake, ladies and gentlemen, in this negotiation is not the sovereignty of either party in negotiations. We have said this from the outset of the political declaration: any future agreement will be done with respect for the european Union's decision-making autonomy and with respect for British sovereignty. What is at stake is simply - but it is already a lot - the organization, the right organization, our future relationships after the divorce, which is acquired. We want as intense a relationship as possible for our economic cooperation, security, joint investments, research, education and one day, no doubt, cooperation on foreign and defence policy. We have, of course, the red lines mentioned by Boris Johnson on the role of the European Court of Justice, on the legislative autonomy of the United Kingdom, on fisheries. For several months now, we have been constructively committed to the negotiating table to see how these British red lines that we know could be compatible with our own principles and interests, with the will to reach an agreement between us. For it goes without saying, of course, that any international agreement involves constraints between the two parties, mutually accepted constraints. So much for the overall framework of the negotiation. I believe, ladies and gentlemen, despite the difficulties, that an agreement is within our reach. If we are, on both sides, ready to work constructively and in a spirit of compromise, if we move forward in the coming days on the basis of legal texts, as is our wish, and, finally and above all, if we are ready, in the coming days, to address and resolve and the most difficult subjects. Time is limited, very limited, it is even limited more and more every day, and that is why we have to find solutions with the British, if they want, solutions for the most difficult problems. I said yesterday again to the coordination group chaired by David McAllister and its members that I thank - very much here - as I said at the Conference of Commission Presidents, that we have made progress in recent weeks with the British on police and judicial cooperation (I know the vigilance of your Parliament): we have made progress on the issue of the European Convention on Human Rights , data protection, Europol, Eurojust and extradition. Here we are: we see clearly the outline of an agreement. We have made progress on transport: the UK government is committed to a specific level playing field, particularly in the field of road transport, this is important for us; on the UK's participation in some important EU programmes: Horizon Europe, research, Erasmus; and finally on thematic cooperation, such as public health, which is so urgent at the moment, or cybersecurity. These are the issues where we have made good and positive progress through negotiation. On other issues, there are still disagreements, although we also see prospects of finding approval, particularly on trade in goods, services, energy, and coordination on social security. Finally, there are three subjects, as Charles Michel mentioned earlier, on which we must make progress because there are real differences: level playing field, fishing and governance. The level playing field - let's say in a slightly less techno way that it is economic and commercial fair play, at the heart of our future economic relations. The British often mention the Canadian model in their speeches, but we have a unique proximity with the United Kingdom, as Maro-Eef-ovio said earlier: 0 kilometres. Zero kilometres between the Republic of Ireland and the United Kingdom, therefore between us and the United Kingdom, and an economic interconnection built with the British for 47 years, which makes this situation unlike any other. That is why this agreement we want will be unprecedented. It is also the first time in our history that we are negotiating a trade treaty with a third country by establishing from the outset the principle that there will be no, or the proposition that there will be no tariffs between us and no quotas. We have never done that with any third country, not canada, or with Japan more recently. And then we are negotiating this agreement with a third country for the first time, I repeat, in a context of regulatory divergence: this is not, as in all previous agreements, encouraging convergence, it is about controlling the divergence that the British want to regain and will regain with Brexit. That is why the level playing field remains a fundamental requirement, as the President of the European Council has pointed out. We have noted with interest in recent weeks that the British have become more aware of this requirement and have evolved to recognise the need for fundamental principles on state aid control, beyond what exists in existing free trade agreements or in the WTO, and also non-regression standards with real guarantees of national implementation and a dispute settlement mechanism. But the intentions must now be translated into negotiation. It is also necessary for each party to be able to adopt unilateral measures in response to the risk of distortion of competition. This is the first major point of divergence, but I believe it is possible to find a path. Similarly, the governance of our future agreement is the key: it is a global structure for a comprehensive agreement, it is a binding mechanism for resolving disputes with an effective sanctions system. Here, too, Maro-Eef-ovi recalled earlier the risk attached to the withdrawal agreement and its respect. That is why we are obviously going to be demanding, in this negotiation for the future relationship, on dispute resolution and governance, because we have this warning from the British that we are concerned about. And then fishing, the last important sticking point: there will be no economic agreement without a sustainable, equitable, fair solution for fishermen on both sides. We will therefore insist to the end to ensure a sustainable prospect for our European fishermen. It requires reciprocal and stable access to water, and it requires a fair distribution of quotas. In conclusion, ladies and gentlemen, and thanking you for your trust, I would like to remind you that our door remains open and will remain open until the last useful day, to work together with our team, which is also your negotiating team. We are ready to work very hard, day and night if necessary, to finalise a draft agreement within a time frame which must allow the necessary time for democracy, that is to say to your Parliament and also to the national parliaments and the Council, to express itself. Of course, we will continue to inform you transparently, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, of the progress of this negotiation. To reach an agreement, you have to be two, and then you have to agree at the end. We are not sure we will, but I think it is possible. That is why we must also be prepared to accept the consequences of a possible No Deal and continue at the same time our preparations for this scenario, which we do not want, by the end of the year. And we have been carrying out this preparation work for many months in good cooperation with all parties concerned and with the Member States.  Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, our attitude and your unity, the unity of the 27, the unity of the political groups here, are the key to the success of this negotiation, which, as we know, is not only about the relationship between the United Kingdom and the European Union for the generations to come, but also, more broadly, the future of the European project.  (Applause)

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, dear colleagues in times of crisis the citizens of the European Union expect that we provide solutions to the problems that they are facing. Whenever there is a crisis, whenever people face difficulties, they expect that the European Union to help them.  This was the case ten years ago during the economic and financial crisis. This was the case five years ago during the migration and refugee crisis, and this is the case now during the Corona crisis. The fact that people expect us to deliver in times of crisis, shows that they believe we can deliver. It shows a genuine trust of the people in Europe, in the European institutions, and this is why we need to provide now what people expect of us – provide solutions.  These are times in which we have to trust science; trust the authorities; work together; stay united; keep in mind that facts matter; defend together a rules-based society; trust politicians who have solutions, and say loud and clear – the institutions of the European Union delivered in overcoming the crisis and, under Michel Barnier’s leadership, in keeping the EU together in the negotiations for finding the best possible relationship with the United Kingdom for the future.  The developments of recent days have shown to us that passing relatively well through a first wave of Corona crisis, is no guarantee of passing well through the second and through the third wave. The developments of recent days have shown to us that the Corona crisis is not a short-term crisis, but it will be at least a medium-term crisis, with consequences, potentially, for the long term. When people expect us to do more, when we have a crisis where it’s clear that united we can pass through it better, when people expect us to do more, we need to equip the European Union with the tools it needs to overcome the crisis. And one of our essential tools is the budget of the European Union. In the EPP group, we are committed to a quick conclusion of the negotiations on the EU budget and on the Recovery and Resilience Facility, so that both instruments can enter into force on 1 January 2021.  We do respect the many good elements of the agreement of the July European Council. However, we want to find solutions to allocate further resources where they are needed. We saw in recent weeks that the EU health programmes need more money, and this is why Mr President Sassoli, I would like to support what you publicly said yesterday – the creation of the Recovery and Resilience Facility of Next Generation EU should not become a burden for the budget of the European Union.  I would like to support what President Sassoli said yesterday. We should not place the interest payments for Next Generation EU within the EU budget. We should not have less money for farmers, for researchers, for students, because we have created the Recovery and Resilience Facility. As the rapporteur for the Recovery and Resilience Facility, I would like to tell our colleagues in the Council that we are working and respecting our schedule here in the European Parliament. We will be delivering. We have no delays here. We will adopt our position in November.  Be ready for the final negotiations with the Council, and the message to the people is, we will provide the facility that will help them overcome this crisis, and which will protect them for the next crisis.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, the ghost of the virus strikes Europe again. Curfews and mobility restrictions shake the working and social lives of our towns and cities. The second wave puts the health system back against the ropes. If more than two million contagions were counted in Europe a month ago, we are now with more than four.  International Monetary Fund forecasts, published last week, point to a collapse in the euro area. Moreover, the health and economic crisis pushes us to the precipice of social drama with an increase in poverty and inequality. As the European Poverty Reduction Network reminds us, it is unacceptable that nearly 22% of the population of the European Union is now at risk of poverty or social exclusion.  And if all this wasn't enough, the horizon darkens with the prospect of the abrupt Brexit by the end of this year. There's no complacency. The European Union must learn from the mistakes of the past and yesterday.  Mr Barnier, you are also supported by the Social Democratic family in your last effort to achieve the best relationship with the United Kingdom. But let us not do so at the cost of sacrificing one of our foundations: the internal market. In no way should we accept unfair competition, distorted state aid or social and environmental dumping. Alongside the mistakes of the past, we must also avoid yesterday's mistakes.  And I think it is important to make a reference today to something that the Council did not address, but what this Parliament continues to insist on, and it is the need, today more than ever, to address this Conference of the Future of Europe in order to have instruments that are really in line with the times in which we live.  Mr Michel, the European Council cannot return to the austerity which our welfare state has convulsed since 2008. If we often claim that education is the best antidote to extremism, why do they propose reducing Erasmus? If we tend to say that science is key to the ecological and digital transition, why cut Horizon Europe? If we are now debating the need to give the European Union strategic autonomy built from our health, why give up strengthening the health programme? And don't forget the support we must also give to those who suffer the most in Africa and Latin America. Because let's be clear that no one is going to be safe until we're all safe.  Let's take advantage of the recovery plan and budget to save lives and jobs. And to compensate for the over-indebtedness generated by the crisis. Listen to the International Monetary Fund. They are now calling for higher taxes, that the most affluent individuals and the most profitable companies protect the most vulnerable. And in the European Union we have the tools to make it possible: own resources.  We have to end the digital tax hole. It is not acceptable for U.S. multinationals to declare half their profits in Europe in a single Member State with an unfair corporation tax. President Von der Leyen pledged to relaunch the Google rate if the OECD failed to reach an agreement this year. Now you must comply. And don't go into a false dilemma about allocating funds. Taxpayer efforts cannot serve to finance countries with governments that violate the rule of law. Yesterday we knew that almost eight out of ten European citizens are in favour of linking funds to full respect for democratic values. Let's act on it. A delay in the arrival of aid would frustrate the hopes of millions of Europeans and Europeans and push them into anti-Europeanism.  Tomorrow is not written. With teson and generosity on the part of all, we are in time to guarantee the future of present and future generations.

name: Dacian CIOLOŞ
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, Colleagues, the European Union’s future relations with the United Kingdom has reached a critical point. The EU was always willing to negotiate, but Mr Johnson’s government preferred political games. From the beginning of the campaign of the referendum, until now, he played games.  The EU wants, and needs, a strong partnership with our UK neighbours, but, for that to happen, we need a serious partner, and serious partnerships should have a clear understanding.  Firstly, we will not ratify any trade deal as long as the Withdrawal Agreement is not fully respected, especially the Protocol on Northern Ireland. Secondly, my Group will only give its consent to an agreement that protects the interests of European citizens, and is fair and beneficial to our economy. Any possible deal should ensure a level playing field, as you said, Mr Michel, have an effective mechanism of governance, be fair when it comes to fisheries, and respect our strict data protection norms – and we insist on that.  If the United Kingdom wants a deal – which is in the best interests of UK citizens also – its government needs to sit at the negotiating table until one is reached, and stop playing delaying tactics. And Mr Michel, you have our full support in your work. Let me say some words on the pandemic also. Europe is on the brink of a second wave of the COVID-19 pandemic. The coordination of free movement, requested by my political group and Parliament, is a step forward, but we must strengthen operational coordination at EU level. We have to urgently prepare in order to mitigate the serious social and economic hardship this second wave will cause our citizens.  The Commission and Member States cannot allow themselves to work in anything less than a coordinated manner and learn from the mistakes we witnessed last spring. The cost of national selfishness is too high, and it is simply unacceptable. Furthermore, I hope it is now crystal clear to everyone that we need a European health policy to complement national ones, and this coordination on health will not be enough. We need investment, common investment, and we need an element in the budget for a real European tool on health policy. Let me end by saying, Mr Charles Michel, that this issue of health and COVID-19 coordination should be, in my opinion, on the agenda of every single European Council in the next months until we are out of this crisis because coordination and exchange of information is essential for this.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, on 31 December, in accordance with the democratic will expressed by the ballot box more than four years ago, the United Kingdom will finally be officially a third country, with or without agreement. The position of Brussels has always been, throughout these years of negotiations, to punish the British people for their choice by making the break as painful and complex as possible for London. Having tried to tie the United Kingdom to the common market with the famous backstop, the Commission is still trying to keep the United Kingdom on a short mark by seeking to impose, for example, the jurisprudence of the European Court of Human Rights or by wanting to keep a say in its state aid policy. But the truth is that your inflexibility never paid off. Boris Johnson had demonstrated the fragility of this alleged intransigence at the end of 2019, securing just after his election the renegotiation of the deal that had been concluded with Theresa May and which you claimed was immutable. As a French parliamentarian elected in Normandy, I am now very concerned about fishing, which is a major issue for our countries and mine in particular. Germany has already indicated that it is in favour of concessions, and you, Mr Barnier, had recently suggested that it was necessary, I quote, to 'be realistic about access to British waters'. So it will be either the weakness or the no deal, the lack of agreement. And of course I am not happy about the prospect of failure, but contrary to what has been said over the last four years, the consequences of a no deal would probably be much worse for the European Union than for the United Kingdom. You have taken the problem upside down, instead of negotiating a comprehensive agreement by imposing your ideological dogmas, the general agreement should have been conditioned on the specific issue of fishing, but you do not dare the balance of power because you fear above all a future trade war.  The European Union claimed to bring us prosperity, stability, strength and a place on the world stage after the United States, after China, and recently Turkey, well the United Kingdom today shows that the European institutions, both by their functioning and by their political orientations, organize the collective powerlessness of our nations and therefore of our continent.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, with regard to climate, those were very poor Council conclusions indeed. Or can I even call them conclusions, because the only thing that leaders could agree on was that they had actually talked about climate. We are in the midst of a rapidly progressing climate crisis and postponement of action is a mistake. This year again looks set to break any sort of records with regard to climate crisis, be it heat waves, droughts, intensity, extreme weather events, Arctic shield loss, etc.  So, let me be very clear. Deciding to talk about climate later is failing to grasp the urgency of this task. We have to act now and we have to act decisively at all levels and also in all policy areas, and the compromise reached by the European Parliament on reducing greenhouse gases by 60% by 2030 is a good step forward. Some of you have said it’s an ambitious target, but it’s not so ambitious: it’s a more realistic target if we really want to save our planet. Member States should sign up to it quickly – to the 60% goal – so we can finally start acting. The climate doesn’t wait and neither should we.  And yes, the economic transformation needed for that is no walk in the park, especially for regions with a long-standing tradition of carbon-intensive economies. That’s why the Parliament is insisting on having a proper-sized Just Transition Fund, among others, as part of a new EU budget, because you need to put the money where your policy targets is. You need to put the money where you want to have the EU fit for the tasks ahead and that requires adequate funding. Any government should know that. We need to have a climate spending target of 30% and a biodiversity target of 10% in order to be up to the tasks ahead. And EU funds also need to advance our Union values. That’s why compliance with rule of law must be an essential criteria for allocating the funds and these are critical elements in the Parliament’s position on the EU budget and recovery fund. It is just inadmissible that the Council disregards such fundamental concerns.  As for Brexit, it’s very sad to see that so much time has passed without any agreement being reached on our future relations. We’re approaching the end of the time limit and I just want to remind us that of course the UK Government could have asked for an extension and they decided not to, but it’s also clear that we cannot accept a deal that would endanger the single market, social rights or environmental standards. So further work is needed on that and we are still extremely sad that Brexit was decided, but now we need to see that we also ensure the Union’s togetherness. We are again holding this meeting under very exceptional circumstances. We’re in the midst of a big, big medical crisis. Let us learn from the EU response in the spring, let us now be more coordinated, more cohesive and make sure that border restrictions are avoided. It’s an exceptional year in many different ways and the Council needs to step up if it is ready to face these challenges. (Applause)

name: Derk Jan EPPINK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the European Council has actually ended with one conclusion: Britain, bow or crack! If you know that Prime Minister Johnson has written a great biography of Winston Churchill, you can imagine what he is going to do. So we have to prepare for a no deal. If we look at fisheries – because I really want to talk about that – the two positions are far apart. The United Kingdom claims the sovereignty of its own fishing waters. The EU really wants to leave the current situation that way. But there is a Brexit. So the British are allowed to claim their fishing waters. Now I have an important point. The Netherlands must not throw its fishermen overboard because the European Union is fishing behind the net. We don't know what's coming out of the bus yet. I hope you're successful with a deal. But if not, then there is another world, Mr Barnier. I'm very glad you understand Dutch so well. If no agreement is reached, I do not want to point the finger of blame. But then there is a different situation and then the Member States, the fishing countries, should have the right to negotiate bilaterally with Great Britain. Norway offers a good model. The Norwegians agreed fishing quotas with Great Britain last year. Flanders and Denmark, including those that fish there, benefit from this. So we have a model, because you must know, Mr Barnier, that French fishermen can fish a lot in the Atlantic, but we are in a trap. And that trap is getting smaller and smaller. So we cannot give that up! The Netherlands will never give up its centuries-old tradition of fishing and sacrifice on the sacrificial block of Brussels. This is a national matter that goes very deep culturally and I will defend our fishing supporters tooth and nail. Bilateral negotiations should therefore be possible if you fail. Because we've known the British for about 400 years. We've had wars with them and anything and everything. But we can do our best with the British.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I will dwell on two points, addressing the Council in particular, Mr Michel.  First point: stop "stroking" Erdogan, because you are sending the wrong message and that is why he is escalating his unilateral challenges, not only against Greece and Cyprus but also against the European Union itself. What happened, Mr Michel and Mr Šefčovič, to the list of sanctions which Mr Borrell presented orally, about two months ago, to the foreign ministers? When are we finally going to see it written at the summit, to approve it next to the positive agenda of dialogue that you are proposing to Turkey? Why is the summit — and in particular the German Presidency, and with your tolerance — constantly postponing and referring the matter to the future? Since June you took it to September and now you call us "date in December". You finally need to show more rigour towards Erdogan and consistency of reasons and projects.  Secondly, the severity of the second wave of the pandemic calls for stronger measures to protect society, the economy and public health. That is why, in addition to the positive step of the Recovery Fund, the European Parliament, with a large majority and with the agreement of five political groups — the European People's Party, liberals, Socialist Greens and the Left — is calling for a more ambitious budget.  That is why I ask you, from the Council, to listen to the statement made yesterday by the President of Parliament, Mr Sassoli, and to stop bullying Parliament and not to accuse it with fake news that — supposedly — he does not want a deal. In order to reach an agreement, mr Michel, the Council must also be moved. Parliament has moved from its original proposals, but in order to meet in the middle of the bridge and quickly have positive decisions, such as those demanded by the citizens (see yesterday's Eurobarometer), both the summit and the Council should take some steps towards compromise instead of blaming the European Parliament.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, the dangerous developments in Greek-Turkish also confirm in the European Council communiqués the deadlocks in the policy — of all Greek governments over time — of involvement in American-NATO projects and competition. From a once so-called 'wind-up port', the European Union has today become a 'slow-moving ship' for its apologists. They thus wash away the strong economic and geopolitical interests linking the European Union, Germany, Italy, Spain and others with Turkey. The European Union, the United States and NATO not only cannot stop the aggression of Turkey's bourgeoisie, but they are also tearing it apart; That is why the Turkish challenges on the Greek continental shelf, NAVTEX, the maps on the jurisdiction of the rescue, the drilling in the Cypriot EEZ, the opening of the beach in Varusia, are also taking place; Arms embargoes, reviews of trade agreements, sanctions and their literature are all within the game of the established great rivalries of the urban classes that people pay for in the end. No expectation from the European Union, NATO and the United States. They are — together with their competition — a source of the problem, not the solution. With their struggle, then, the people can reject imperialist plans for dangerous arrangements on their backs.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, none of us will go into history, but the coronavirus does. Why then do we treat it as if it were a problem that we don't all have or that we'll soon stop having? How are we so irresponsible? The virus is faster, more effective, more constant than our measures to prevent and control it, and the arrival of winter will only increase the advantage it carries over us. But politicians continue to confuse reality with desire: as much as we want the nightmare to end, it's not going to end if we don't treat it as the health, economic and social emergency it is.  We were wrong when we pretended it would end the summer and made a mistake again telling the lie that the vaccine will arrive before Christmas. We're presenting vaccination plans and we don't have any vaccines.  We have to prepare for a fight that's going to last for years. In Spain, for example, the virus in just eight months has killed fifty thousand people. There are a million infected; three hundred thousand people are infected each month. What do we do discussing other things?  Gentlemen of the Council, do you not think it is time to have a common strategy to combat the pandemic? How many more people have to die in Europe?  The lives and health of millions of people are at stake on our continent, the collapse of health systems, the survival of our small and medium-sized business fabric, which millions of families can afford for food, clothing or heating.  That is why it is even less understood that, in these circumstances, Boris Johnson fears the bridges that connect him with the continent, condemning even the impossible the future of the British economy. If Donald Trump loses the election, Boris Johnson is not going to have any friends left in the world.  Let us be responsible, support our negotiator together and ask our negotiator to negotiate on behalf of all, for the sake of the British as well. In these times, collaborating is survival.

name: Kati PIRI
text: – Mr President, when we last discussed the negotiations in the context of Mr Hansen’s and my report on the EU—UK partnership in June, we had only 204 days left before the end of the transition period. Today that number is down to 73. Prime Minister Johnson then gave assurances that all it would take to come to an agreement was a little oomph and self imposed a deadline: first, in July, and then on 15 October. But instead of a real engagement in the negotiations, the UK decided to put forward an internal market bill which breaches international law, jeopardises the Good Friday Agreement and ruined the good faith between the negotiators. And here we are in the midst of a second wave of the corona crisis with all its economic consequences, and the UK Government, for reasons no one can really grasp, decided to walk away from the negotiation table one minute before midnight, because we do not need a deal in 73 days: we need it within two weeks. Only then will this Parliament be able to ensure the agreement’s full democratic scrutiny. Because, President, let this be very clear to the UK Government: since the beginning of the transition period, the European Parliament has diligently and consistently taken its responsibility in reaching an agreement because we believe that finding one would be in the interests of both the EU and UK citizens. But under no circumstances will we now be bullied by Mr Johnson into rubber stamping just any last—minute deal after the UK Government chose to run down the clock on the negotiations since February. And our position has not changed. We have always been very clear regarding our red lines. Top social, labour and environmental standards, fair competition, effective governance, a sustainable agreement on fisheries and full compliance with the Withdrawal Agreement. Parliament remains fully committed to a comprehensive agreement with the United Kingdom. But let me draw a clear line in the sand. If the UK Government does not remove those provisions in the internal market bill that are in clear breach of international law, this Parliament cannot and will not consent to any agreement. And finally, let me underline once again that we, the European Parliament, just like the Council, are absolutely united in our support for our negotiator, Michel Barnier. Mr Barnier, we wish you the very best for the coming few weeks of hopefully intensified negotiations with a good outcome. Now it’s up to the UK Government to deliver on its promises for a comprehensive agreement in line with the Political Declaration and the Withdrawal Agreement to which Mr Johnson himself signed up to. We, on our side, are ready.

name: Nathalie LOISEAU
text: Mr President, Boris Johnson once said he was 'dying in a ditch rather than asking for a postponement of Brexit'. Today, negotiations are on a ridge road between a ditch and a precipice. When negotiating, you have to be wary of miscalculations. Boris Johnson committed three. The internal market bill was supposed to scare Europeans and weld its political majority. By threatening to violate international law, he has united the Europeans and frightened his majority. When driving at high speed on a narrow lane, you avoid breaking the traffic code. The British government thought it would put pressure on the Europeans by setting a deadline for negotiations on 15 October. October 15th passed and the Europeans remained calm. Negotiations can resume at any time. When you want to get there safely, you avoid making unnecessary stops. The British government sought to divide and rule, putting the subject of fishing at the centre of conversations, but no one was fooled. The big issue, the one that concerns each of the 27, is the risk of unfair competition at the gates of the single market. However, this subject is not settled, nor is it fisheries, nor is it how we resolve our differences in the future, even though, because of the British retreat on the withdrawal agreement, the confidence we would like to have is not the same. For us, the gap would be a no deal and the precipice a bad deal. Because we do not want to kill our companies if they were faced with unfair competition in health, social or environmental matters. Because we do not want to kill our fishing sector, which does not have to suffer the consequences of a decision, Brexit, which it has not taken. Then there remains a narrow path, that of an agreement respectful of the sovereignty of everyone but capable of serving the interests of all. This narrow path must be covered in a very short time. To avoid the ditch like the precipice, Mr. Johnson, turn off the smokescreens, open your eyes to the reality of business needs, respect the withdrawal agreement and break the deadlock where you put them. You are driving Mr. Johnson, you are the one who can avoid the accident.

name: Gunnar BECK
text: – Mr President, the EU commenced trade negotiations with maximum demands for a level playing field on EU terms, pre-Brexit fishing rights and continued ECJ jurisdiction. Britain wanted a Canada-style trade deal and signalled some flexibility; the EU in contrast barely moved. Negotiation is a discussion between parties with divergent views but a shared interest in finding a compromise. The EU, notably Germany, has a vast trade surplus with the UK, yet the German Presidency and the Commission remain committed to an unequal treaty on EU terms and enforceable before the EU’s imperial court. Merkel and von der Leyen know not to negotiate because they know not when to compromise. That way they will not have their way.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: – Mr President, I might not like to say it, but I think it has to be said also here in this House. Boris Johnson has been lying to the people in the UK: the GBP 350 million for the NHS after Brexit; no customs checks between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK; and then this oven-ready deal that basically just needed signing on the future relations between the EU and the UK. Come on, these lies have to stop. If we want to turn this around, truth has to be spoken. First, Brexit is a mess. Second, finding a solution to this mess is not going to be easy for either side, but thirdly, and I think this is important, there might not be a good outcome to this, but there are many different levels of how difficult this can become. So, Prime Minister, stop blaming others for your own actions, take responsibility and come back to the negotiation table and avoid the worst outcome for the people in the UK. You owe it to them. (Applause)

name: Geert BOURGEOIS
text: Mr President, for Brexit, the hour of truth is now approaching. I am pleased that both sides are saying that they want to achieve a close partnership, which, indeed, Mr Barnier, must be much more than a CETA agreement. The consequences of a no deal are terrible, especially on top of the recession we are now having as a result of the pandemic. The University of Leuven has calculated that the whole union will lose 1% of its gross national product and that we will structurally lose 1.2 million jobs which we will not recover in one, two or three years. For the countries around the North Sea it is even worse. In Flanders, we lose 2.5% of our GDP and 28 000 jobs are at stake. We must therefore reach a compromise and do everything possible to do so. I am charmed, Mr Barnier, by your approach and its broad outlines, namely respect for each other's sovereignty and broad red lines on a level playing field, good governance and fisheries. But we must share legendary British pragmatism in order to reach a good agreement. Of course, Mr Šefčovič, the unacceptable provisions must be taken out of the Internal Market Bill. Fortunately, there are still good Conservatives in the House of Lords for whom a word is a word. I wish you every success in the context of these lines. Time is running out!

name: Idoia VILLANUEVA RUIZ
text: – Mr President, 52 months ago — 52 – the UK exit referendum and we continue without agreement on future conditions. Referendum, I would like to recall, that it was supported only by 51.9% of the United Kingdom, and in which Scotland and Northern Ireland, for example, supported staying. A fully divided society. Unfortunately we have seen Boris Johnson quickly join the Trumpist current of white men imposing, threatening and despising negotiation or cooperation.  We support Mr Barnier in his negotiations and, at this time and situation, Europe must not join in this way of doing eer in form or in substance. We must always have our hands reached out for the benefit of all populations. However, from firmness, defending our strategic sectors, against the consequences in the primary sector and ensuring contingency plans, but above all we must prioritize the most vulnerable part: the rights of citizens, ensuring resources to guarantee these rights.  And finally, we must also learn from this process, to change the policies that left much of the public out of the crisis. And in the face of this new crisis, we must ensure a bill of rights, a strong social pillar and a project that invites us to stay.

name: Carles PUIGDEMONT I CASAMAJÓ
text: – Mr President, another European Council goes on without concrete advances on Brexit. In addition, even when the deadline is ever closer, I hope for a good deal that ensures that citizens and enterprises can continue to live and operate normally both in the UK and in the EU.  We are in the middle of one of the worst economic crises of our history. We are obliged not to worsen it with political games. On the other hand, Brexit is a reminder that borders change, as we all know. Today, support for Scottish independence is sky high in the latest polls with about 58% of the vote. The future of Scotland is in Scottish hands and we all hope that Westminster will again give an example to the world of how to tackle this kind of situation. London needs to show again how a mature democracy behaves. The UK needs to remind the EU that a referendum is something to agree on, not an excuse to put political rivals in prison as Spain has done. Very soon, Scotland will vote again to decide its future and the House of European democracy must be wide open for their immediate return.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, the discussion between EU leaders at this month’s summit covered some pivotal topics for our Union. I fully support further EU coordination in terms of the pandemic and ambition in our fight against climate change. However, it is the ongoing negotiations with the United Kingdom that will have the most immediate and severe effects for my home country of Ireland.  I’ve always been optimistic that when it came down to it, a deal would be reached. This I drew from the competency and fairness with which I have seen Michel Barnier do his great work. But recently our confidence lessened in this regard because of the shifting sands of Boris Johnson’s desires and his collection of supporters in parliament who seem more than willing to not only contradict themselves, but also contradict the foundation of the United Kingdom’s reputation by voting to willingly breach international law.  On paper, with our years of close cooperation, the remaining issues on Brexit seem achievable. The sharing of fishing rights and policing state subsidies to industry should not be deal breakers to close allies of 47 years. The real problem is the lack of trust in the seriousness of any commitments that the United Kingdom might give, which was most distinctly displayed by the abrasive introduction of the Internal Market Bill and the legal justification for same. Sometimes we get the sense that the United Kingdom is more concerned with short-term optics than long-term substance. Nobody in the EU, Ireland – and indeed the United Kingdom if they are truly honest – wants an extremely disruptive no-deal. There is a danger that a last-minute agreement could break down into a multitude of legal disputes within a year or so. This must be avoided. To my friends in the United Kingdom, I say: there is room for a deal in line with your previous agreements that will finally provide certainty to businesses and citizens and avoid economic catastrophe. I plead with you to meet the EU halfway and ensure that ordinary people do not become casualties of ideology. Mr Johnson, bin the bluster and get the deal done. (Applause)

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Mr President, first of all as rapporteur of this Parliament for the implementation of the withdrawal agreement, I would like to express my support to the European Commission and Vice-President Šefčovič for their efforts to ensure full compliance by the UK of the withdrawal agreement, and their commitments under international law.  We’ve always said that trust is a prerequisite for a sound and future economic relationship, and we mean it. And now that the UK Internal Market Bill is under discussion between the House of Lords and the House of Commons, this Parliament recalls that we expect nothing less than full compliance with the withdrawal agreement. As to the negotiations of the future relationship, I would also like to express full support to Michel Barnier and his team, and thank him for his remarkable patience and the responsible and firm manner in which he is pursuing the goal of reaching an unprecedented, but also fair and balanced agreement.  I can imagine that Mr Boris Johnson is having great fun playing with Brexit, playing with the no—deal scenario and the blame game. But I believe that citizens and businesses expect a much more responsible attitude.  But let me say that I don’t see how Mr Boris Johnson can win the blame game in this case. We are running out of time - yes - but he was the one to refuse any extension of the transition period. He was the one to announce the breach by the UK of the withdrawal agreement and international law commitments. He was the one to refuse to apply the commitments on the level playing field on state aid, that were already agreed as objectives in the political declaration, and he is now the one who is refusing to receive Michel Barnier and took the decision to suspend the negotiations.  So I believe that we need a responsible attitude. The EU has shown the political will to reach an agreement. We are waiting to see the same attitude from the part of the UK government.  (Applause)

name: Morten PETERSEN
text: Mr President! I want to speak in Danish, and I'll bring greetings from Copenhagen. Brexit is tragic in every way and it may seem completely incomprehensible why Brexit should be a good idea. After all, since World War II, all European countries have been working to remove barriers to trade. And now we are negotiating how we can make it more difficult and difficult to do business with each other. It simply does not make any sense, but it is the British's own choice, and we must respect that, but we cannot and must not respect the fact that British companies should be able to compete with Danish companies on terms that are not equal and fair.  I have visited Danish fishermen in Thyborøn, shipping companies in Esbjerg, farmers in South Jutland, I have spoken to industry all over Europe and the service sector, everywhere sounds the same basic message: Brexit is hard, Brexit is going to cost money, Brexit is going to cost welfare.  From the EU's point of view, we must stand together – we have succeeded so far, not least thanks to the great efforts of the EU's chief negotiator Michel Barnier. And we must make one last attempt to find each other in a deal. It will not be easy: as colleagues in the Chamber have said, there are huge knots in terms of fishing. There are huge problems in relation to what rules of the game should apply going forward to trade. And the English must understand that when the English side raises doubts as to whether you want to comply at all with the agreements you have signed yourself, but then the rest of us become rather sceptical. It simply needs to be in place for us to trust each other going forward. The European Union must be fair, but we must not be crazy.  Thank you for the word. And all sorts of luck to Michel Barnier in the negotiations ahead.

name: Laura HUHTASAARI
text: – Mr President, I have a dream. I want all Member States to do Brexit. As the EPP President, Manfred Weber, has put it, if Brexit felt like a success, it would be the beginning of the end of the EU. That reveals that if the UK leaves the EU without a deal, it means that the EU has not even tried to be fair.  I have a message for Boris Johnson. Defend your fishing waters, etc. You now have an opportunity to take your sovereignty back. Use it.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Mr President, first of all, I would like to convey my full support to Michel Barnier and his team in the Brexit negotiation and wish him good luck in the coming months.  Today, however, I wanted to talk about the fact that unfortunately the Council did not address the issue of climate change as we would have liked at the last meeting. It is urgent that, as far as the Climate Act is concerned, the 60% we have proposed to them will be adopted by the European institutions and most Member States.  On that, we need to align all our policies with that objective and yesterday Parliament failed with the CAP vote. As Greens, we are not satisfied with a reform that will not defend our biodiversity, which will not guarantee a transition to another way of producing and, therefore, we will fail with the CAP and we will have a big black hole in the fight against climate change.  But there's another place we can't fail: in the Recovery Fund. We cannot lay abode EUR 750 billion without a clear objective of ecological transformation. And it's okay to devote 37% to the climate target, but we can't, at the same time, pour money on highways, into fossil fuels. That, in the regulations we are going to negotiate, must be avoided and I hope, for this, the cooperation of everyone.

name: Mazaly AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Mr Barnier, the lack of trade agreement with the United Kingdom is very bad news for both sides, but especially very negative for European farmers and fishermen. Brexit increases the uncertainty of a pandemic-hit agricultural, agri-food and fisheries sector and a price crisis in many EU countries. Farmers have one eye on the CAP and another in the Brexit negotiations.  Spain, my nation, exports EUR 4 billion annually to the United Kingdom, of which 2 billion are in fruits and vegetables, 400 million in wine and 200 million in olive oil. 10% of agri-food products are imported by the United Kingdom from Spain.  I ask the European Commission to inform us urgently what support measures it will give to the agri-food sector, and it is time to demand an answer on how and when the Commission intends to activate the EUR 5 billion of the agricultural reserve for Brexit.  And now let me simply tell Mr Puigdemont, who I think has left, to learn how to differentiate between illegal and legal referendums. Brexit was legal. Yours was illegal and also a pantomime.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you, Mr Barnier, also for the clear words you have said today. But where do we actually stand? All citizens, societies and the economy on both sides of the Channel need to be clear at last. For Johnson, it was about key slogans of his campaign for Brexit, "What to prove." British sovereignty achieved? Or will the British continue to have to comply with standards that we have adopted in the EU? Will the European Court of Justice monitor compliance? access to the single market? Will British products be exported freely, will entrepreneurs and service providers be allowed to travel freely through the EU? Deregulation allowed? Can the London financial world operate with us and still be deregulated by Downing Street 10 soon? Fishing for Britons only? Or are the fishing boats from other countries bordering the North and Baltic Sea allowed to continue catching the fish where it swims? And do we take care of fish stocks together? It is also about our own holding lines. Please do not think of ticking down the clock and putting a treaty on a minimum agreement on the table for the European Parliament and the Member States only at the last minute. Democracy would suffer further damage, because it could go wrong, in our european parliament and in some Member States.  We need a contract with our neighbours, but one of quality. The EP is very clear about governance, level playing field, social and environmental standards, citizens' interest and the fisheries treaty – and the full implementation of the Good Friday Agreement.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: – Mr President, I have always maintained that Brexit was bad news for both the European Union and the United Kingdom, and time has given us the reason (inaudible words) that negotiations for future relations are becoming more complicated. They move in a sea of unknowns in all areas, from the future of the fruit and vegetable productions of my Canary Islands to fishing.  And speaking of fishing, today I think it is more necessary than ever to reiterate our position: no general agreement should be reached with the United Kingdom if there is previously no stable, lasting and balanced agreement on fisheries that maintains access to water and the allocation of quotas and catches. The Council sent a very strong message in this regard and our chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, too. It's our turn today from here.  The organization of fisheries is much more than the establishment of a percentage of TACs and quotas. The current common fisheries policy responds to a delicate balance between economic benefit, social welfare and the preservation of fish stocks, and that balance cannot be lost. Fishermen in the European Union and the United Kingdom have shared the waters of our seas for centuries, and the new agreement cannot be overlooked.  The common fisheries policy is already a compromise between Member States, including the United Kingdom, which until last year has participated in all the negotiations on its most important aspects which also take into account their priorities and interests and which could continue to benefit for years.  In this sense, the European Union's position is not maximalist, as some might think. We in this Parliament build this system together with the United Kingdom and we cannot now downgrade or refnege that commitment, neither they nor us. Our responsibility goes beyond fishing fleets: it is also a commitment to people. Let us not lose sight of the view that any change in the current balance will have consequences on employment, from Spain to Sweden, and it is our duty as Members of this Parliament to fight for each of these jobs.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Internal Market Act, passed by the House of Commons, is a very serious act on the part of the British Government, an act that violates the Withdrawal Agreement and the UNITED Kingdom's obligations towards us. Prime Minister Boris Johnson is not making any real progress on the points still under discussion, but there are only ten days to 31 October, the deadline for us to be able to move forward effectively and conclude the procedure. As the European Union, we want to reach an agreement in the common interest in order to continue working in key areas – I am thinking of research, international cooperation, security, universities, I am thinking of the rights of European citizens in the United Kingdom and vice versa – there are more than 600 000 Italians in the United Kingdom, for example, and these people, like all European citizens, cannot be left in uncertainty.  Today, in order to restore a relationship of trust between us, it is necessary to withdraw the law on the internal market and to converge on a common governance mechanism, which guarantees a clear framework with regard to State aid, competition and fisheries.  After last week's Council, the risk of a no deal is real. As the European Union we will do everything we can to avoid it and reach an agreement, but Johnson is wrong if he thinks we will get there at any cost. The European Union is playing its part today, and I think it is necessary for the British Government to do its part today too.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: – Monsieur le Président, M. Bay du groupe ID n’est plus là parce que sa position frôle le ridicule. On doit s’arrêter de punir les Britanniques, on doit mieux reconnaître la souveraineté britannique mais quand il s’agit des poissons, ce n’est plus le cas, donc c’est vraiment ridicule, c’est n’importe quoi! It’s the same with Mr Eppink. Mr Eppink is explaining to us that we do not have to do it in a European way, but we have to do a bilateral deal. Every country with the UK. The last time that you did this, you lost New York, I presume, when you got your negotiations with the British. So, if I have a suggestion to make, Michel, it’s the following. If we make a deal with the British - and I hope that there is a deal in the coming weeks - then we put in this final agreement, in this treaty - it’s an international treaty - a disposition that automatically that treaty ceases to exist if the British don’t follow all the commitments that they have taken, including in the Withdrawal Agreement. In my opinion that is absolutely necessary because otherwise, if there is a deal, if there is an agreement, and the 27 will have ratified it, and they don’t follow their commitments, it will be a huge mess and it again be necessary for 27 decisions by the 27 Member States to stop that agreement.  So I think that, after what has happened with the Internal Market Bill, it’s in the interest of the European Union to foresee such a disposition in that final agreement as fast as possible. I hope that there is a deal because it’s the only way to secure the Good Friday Agreement, to secure peace in Northern Ireland and to secure our internal market.  (Applause)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you, Mr Verhofstadt. If you allow me to comment, it is a great pleasure to listen to you. Your contributions are parliamentary and not read, and if you then also cook a point, then all this is wonderful.

name: Jaak MADISON
text: – Mr President, it’s always very funny to hear the speeches of Mr Verhofstadt, because he’s very active and funny and full of power and has been talking about the damage of Brexit since 2016, saying that they’re going to lose everything and that we’re going to have to put huge pressure on the UK. Well, since 2016, they have been doing pretty fine, actually.  Unfortunately, the EU is trying to mix together a green deal and climate history, while at the same time take huge loans with some kind of economic reforms, and they are declining more and more. At the same time, the UK and Mr Johnson are just playing with the EU. The EU is trying to play the tough guy, but at the same time it couldn’t manage any normal deal. Here I am just talking about fisheries.  So that’s why I wouldn’t take Mr Verhofstadt very seriously, because he was pretty wrong from 2016 to 2017 and it’s pretty clear and understandable that, if there is no deal before the end of the year, the EU stands to lose much more than the UK. In some ways I’m pretty happy about that. Congratulations to Mr Johnson.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Mr President, I read with great interest the Council conclusions on Africa and the intention to strengthen our partnership with it. I would like to highlight a very particular kind of partnership that has now been initiated between the European Union, between the Commission and African cocoa-producing countries – Cote d’Ivoire and Ghana – because we really need to do something to eradicate child labour and deforestation from our supply chains. The brand new multi-stakeholder platform on cocoa is exactly what is going to do that, with broad cooperation between partner countries, the EU, civil society and local producers. The aim is to bring about sustainable livelihoods for poor people, poor growers in Africa, and avoid damage to our environment. I would encourage you to vote in favour of the Burkhardt report this week, which is exactly about this partnership to eradicate deforestation from supply chains.

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The recent European Council, through the absence of some leaders of the Member States, shows how to deal with the problems facing the European Community today as a result of the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. And while it is impossible not to agree with the summit conclusions on, for example, the coordination of measures adopted by Member States in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, it already appears that the European Commission's ongoing efforts to raise the reduction target for 2030 to at least 55% appear to be a complete detachment of Commission officials from reality. , which affects the global economy today.  No one in China, in the US, in Argentina, in Brazil, in India is bothered by climate change in the context of the struggle of their industries and economies with the effects of COVID-19. Therefore, in my opinion, it will not be possible to take a possible decision to raise the reduction target by 2030 if this decision is not accompanied by the simultaneous definition by the European Council of key guidelines for the legal framework and mechanisms that will allow this... (The President has received the speaker's vote.)

name: Chris MACMANUS
text: – Mr President, thank you and the many Members for reiterating their support for the Irish protocol, which is extremely important. But there are other key issues. The all-Ireland economy is not just about goods, it’s also about the free movement of people and services. The Common Travel Area, however, does not allow for the free movement of EU nationals.
