An all-Ireland labour market and cross-border access to services are essential to the lives of thousands of EU nationals living in Ireland north and south, as well as to the all-Ireland economy.  Parliament called for this in a resolution earlier this year and now we should make it a reality. Because the Good Friday Agreement is based on rights; the right to access EU programmes and healthcare across the EU, and the right to be represented in this Parliament.  We should find a way to give effect to these rights. Rights that are being taken away by the spectre of Brexit, and the right to self—determination, which would allow the majority who opposed Brexit in the north of Ireland to remain within the EU through the vehicle of Irish unity -  a central provision of the Good Friday Agreement and which is likely to happen within the next few years.  We all know the real problem is the partition of Ireland and it would be wise for all of us to start preparing for Irish unity.

name: Christophe HANSEN
text: – Mr President, last week’s European Council did not bring a Brexit-breakthrough, and frankly nobody expected it. It is the UK side that has to move now. Yet London is sulking because their third artificial deadline was not respected, and Lord Frost even dared to be ‘disappointed’.  Well, in my honest view, the UK Government has lost the right to be disappointed – the moment it introduced a bill to unilaterally override an international agreement that was the fruit of more than three years of negotiations; a bill that puts the UK’s international credibility at stake; a bill that was met with strong rebukes from the European Parliament and the American Congress; a bill that was rejected by the Scottish and Northern Irish Assemblies, and yesterday by the House of Lords; a bill that undermines trust and hangs over the negotiations like a sword of Damocles. We have stated it again and again: this House will not ratify an agreement if the Withdrawal Agreement is breached, or threatened to be breached. A no-deal Brexit after four years of negotiations would be a drama for our fisheries, for our hauliers, for our people and, last but not least, for politics. Now is not the time for brinkmanship, now is not the time for blame-games, now is the to time to wrap it up and finally land a deal. The EU will never walk away from these negotiations, no matter the amount of spin that comes out of Number 10. For this Parliament, there is still time until the beginning of November, so keep calm and negotiate on. Michel Barnier, Maroš Šefčovič, we trust in you.

name: Javier MORENO SÁNCHEZ
text: – Mr President, be my first words to transfer the condolences of the Spanish Socialist Delegation to the relatives of Professor Samuel Paty, victim of barbarism, and to also condemn any kind of terrorism. All our solidarity with the French people and authorities in the fight against this scourge.  Because fanaticism and violence attack directly at the heart of the European project, a project that is based on values such as tolerance, coexistence, freedom, diversity or peace. We must act firmly in the face of drifts, both religious fanaticisms and political extremisms that travel through Europe, sowing hatred, division and involution. They put our common future at risk. Moderate political forces must be united and accountable. They can't give wings to the far right. I warn navigators, especially those in my country, especially today.  Quant au Brexit, je désire une fois de plus saluer le travail acharné de notre négociateur, Michel Barnier, et lui transmettre notre ferme appui pour que les négociations soient accélérées et achevées en temps voulu. M. Johnson doit respecter ses engagements, faute de quoi il serait tr's difficile de conclure un accord avec un partenaire aussi peu fiable. Johnson has to respect the withdrawal agreement, as well as Community rules on social, labour, environmental and tax matters. The rights of European citizens living in the United Kingdom must be guaranteed. Whatever the conditions of divorce, our Europe must continue to advance to 27 and reflect on its future. The Council should move a tab to start the Conference on the Future of Europe as soon as possible. We need that new impulse.

name: Liesje SCHREINEMACHER
text: – Mr President, today I’m not here for a ‘he said, she said’ discussion and how far which door was open and who shut it. No, our citizens and businesses, on both sides of the Channel, are looking at us to be responsible, are looking at us not to play political games, and are looking at us to reach an agreement because they know that a no deal is not in anyone’s interests.  We are in the middle of an economic crisis, of which we cannot see the end. The corona crisis hit our businesses hard, not only the European but the British as well. The British economy has hit its largest recession on record. So why make things worse with a hard Brexit? How could that serve the interests of your - and our - citizens and businesses? How could that be in anyone’s interests? It is not.  I want to thank Michel Barnier for his tireless efforts to try and reach an agreement. It is the responsible thing to do. But we also have to remain clear that the EU will not accept a deal at any cost. We want a fair deal. But what’s fair? That’s the million dollar question! Let me tell you what is not fair. A country that wants to leave the European Union, but still wants to enjoy the same rights as a Member State. It was the UK that decided to leave the EU, it was the UK that decided to be a third country, and now it’s the UK Government demanding that an entire economic bloc of 27 countries change its way of doing business. So, when we talk about fair, the UK Government cannot expect us to sacrifice our businesses and our fishermen in order to get Brexit done. This is not their choice and they cannot become collateral damage in this story. What seems fair to me is that the UK can only get access to our market of 450 million consumers if fair competition for our companies is guaranteed and our fishermen can continue to fish in British waters. Time is ticking, so let’s get Brexit done, but let’s get it done right because a hard Brexit is not in anyone’s interest.

name: Tom VANDENDRIESSCHE
text: Mr President, five years after the British took back their freedom, there is still no trade agreement. This is the result of years of deliberate sabotage. Brexit must apparently be made as painful as possible because positive new cooperation and relationship with the United Kingdom are proof that there is an alternative to the EU superstate and the ever closer Union. If Brexit were to be a success, even more countries would want to leave the European Union. And that is what we want to avoid at any cost. Despite centuries of trading relations with the United Kingdom, 40 000 jobs in Flanders are now at risk. We pay the price for the convulsive attitude of the euro-fanatic elite. This European Union is becoming something that we have never signed up for. If this continues, the Flemings, like the British, will sooner or later draw their conclusions.

name: Michael BLOSS
text: – Mr President, I’m a full-hearted European. For me it’s all in for the Union and for the climate, and I think that the youth want that from us, they want to see passion and commitment for the planet. But what do they see if they look at the meeting of the heads of state? The opposite. They see delay tactics at the expense of our climate and of their future. The heads of state of Europe cannot come to an agreement on climate politics. Your inaction is blocking the progress. Therefore, I ask you, the German Presidency, don’t shy away any more from your responsibility on the climate and the postponement of climate action. And if you can’t deliver, just give climate policy back to the normal democratic legislative procedure because we are ready and why aren’t you?

name: Joanna KOPCIŃSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The current epidemiological situation is unprecedented and of very serious concern. Our treatments in the fight against the virus, however, do not stop, and we must act responsibly and in solidarity. At a time of current high increases in the number of cases, new sets of updated safety recommendations and procedures for coordinated action for The Member States of the European Union should be developed. In this case, I am thinking in particular of the extent to which the Council conclusions take into account the position of the European Commission's September Health Safety Committee and its recommendations on a strategy setting out a new approach to testing in order to achieve the specific objectives of the fight against the virus.  In the context of the spread of disinformation, I wanted to ask whether there is now a need to take into account concrete plans to counter the spread of disinformation about coronavirus and accrued false theories that hinder the implementation of security measures and the fight against the virus. Does the European Commission, together with the Council, see the basis for creating an appropriate platform to take an effective form of countering... (The President received the speaker's vote)

name: Kris PEETERS
text: Mr President, the days of the transitional period are coming to an end and we hear again and again that the negotiations are intensifying. But we have not yet seen any real progress. It is time to send a clear message to our companies, our SMEs and our fishermen. Hope for the best, prepair for the worst. But in spite of everything, we can't give up yet. A goal in the last minute could be the victory. The last centimeters in a cycling race can be the most important. The stakes are simply too important. We need to think about the possible redundancies that will follow as a result of a hard Brexit. We need to think about the number of bankruptcies that will increase in our SMEs and our fishermen. That is why, ladies and gentlemen, we must do everything in our way to encourage the British to be reasonable. Gradually, the British also realised that they had gone the wrong way. The recent vote in the House of Lords on the Internal Market Bill should shake up the British government. The message was clear: breaking pacta sunt servanda, international law damages a country's reputation. After all, a good agreement is better for both sides of the Channel than no agreement. I would like to conclude with Michel Barnier and wish the Vice-President every success. The affectio societatis, if one wants an agreement, both sides must be convinced that an agreement is the best solution. On our side, that is certainly clear. I hope that in the next few hours and days it will also become clear on the British side.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Mr President, last week the Council met with a very busy programme: corona, Brexit and climate, they were all on the agenda. This week, the Commission presented its plans for 2021. Great plans for the Green Deal and the digital transition. But what about the social plans? The blows that the economy has to deal with through the corona crisis, which we know is far from over, and the blows of a possible hard Brexit, which is yet to come in a few months, have to be paid for by someone. The pressure keeps on increasing. Unemployment is rising across Europe. But the bill cannot be paid by the employees. We now have to make fundamentally different choices. It is precisely where the pain is greatest that we must invest now: in the European Social Fund, to help people move from job to job, and in a guarantee against child poverty. We also need a permanent law on part-time unemployment, because only together can we cope with the crisis.

name: François-Xavier BELLAMY
text: Mr President, everything will be better than a no deal, than an exit from the United Kingdom without a deal. We know this and that is why I would like to reiterate our support for our chief negotiator - to you, dear Michel, for the exceptional work you are doing. We need to put the interests of European activities first and I am surprised that some here are playing the politics of the worst. I hope that tomorrow they will come and explain it to our companies, to our fishermen in particular, to all those who are threatened by an exit without a deal. The situation also obliges me, Mr President, to return to another subject, because the European Councils follow each other and unfortunately look the same. On 6 October, Varosha was again occupied by Turkey, in defiance of all UN conventions in Cyprus. A few days later, it was the victory of Mr. Tatar, Mr. Erdogan's self-proclaimed vassal, in this enclave occupied by Turkey since 1974 on European soil. Turkish ships have returned to Greece's exclusive economic zone. Who could seriously believe in the de-escalation that we had been told? Erdogan takes three steps forward, one step back, but it is to resume better then and when he advances, it is on Europe that he walks. We cannot forget, in particular, the fate of Armenia, which is now being hit by Turkey's actions. Azerbaijan has caused so many civilian casualties in Armenia, in Nagorno-Karabakh: what is Europe doing in the face of this? Well, she deplores, she urges, she calls for appeasement. So many ways to hide his denials, so many ways not to say the word "sanction", the only effective, the only one that must be pronounced. Mr President of the Council, Turkey is a crisis every week, it is the deaths of innocent people every day, and here it is Munich at every moment. I believe it is time to save the honour, it is time to finally act. We have no right to remain powerless any longer, we do not have the right to take Turkey's propaganda on our own, especially when it supports - Mr Erdogan recently said - terrorism in the face of the measures recently announced. I am thinking in particular of the attack on Samuel Paty, most recently in France, which earned us new statements from the Turkish President today.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Mr President, european citizens are more than ever attentive to the political responses of those who elected them to represent them. They want more concrete measures and fewer proclamations. I therefore welcome the progress made in coordinating the European response to the pandemic, the sharing of scientific data, the interconnection of screening applications and screening strategies, the consolidation of common quarantine behaviour, the reduction of restrictions on freedom of movement.  These are life-saving decisions that are useful to the community. They should inspire other dossiers that the Council has to resolve by continuing to maintain a firm and defending attitude of European citizens' rights in relations with the United Kingdom. Preparing, in conjunction with Parliament and the European Commission, a rapid availability of resources for the recovery and resilience and economic and social transformation of the Union. Approving a robust and viable rule of law mechanism, and making relations with Africa an example of partnership between equals, knowledge sharing, resources, priorities, with the strong involvement of civil society. And, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, with respect to the institutional dimension of which parliaments and joint parliamentary assemblies are an inalienable party. Citizens listen, they want solutions. Let us be able to make them happen.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Mr President, President Michel, I would like to thank the President for his work and for his work It was good that you put Africa on the agenda of the recent summit, and it was good that all sides stressed that we are talking about a partnership on an equal footing – indeed, what else in these times? But we will only succeed in this if we take up with all the firmness the problems that are now threatening our neighbouring continent. President Michel, you know, you see and the Commission knows, that the pandemic is also increasingly taking control of the African continent. African societies are unprepared, they have a weaker health system than us and many others.  Are we prepared for this? Are we providing the appropriate help? I have doubts. You know that millions of children cannot go to school in Africa because of the COVID-19 measures. We are in danger of losing an entire generation. What we need, including as an address to the Commission, is a task force, an action plan, so as not to let this generation get lost.  Hunger will become an issue, people will die en masse if we do not mobilise the resources to provide the appropriate aid. And in the global south as a whole, it will be decided whether we have partners for our values, partners for a multilateral world. Debt relief, as you said, Mr President, is the crucial issue.  Do not rest, do not settle for what has been achieved, drive us forward! And the Commission should go further than in its work programme. That was a disappointment in this regard, I would ask you to be more active, to be clear.

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, the debate was very much focused on four major topics, the first one being how to mitigate the economic and social consequences of the corona crisis. Ms García Pérez and Ms Jongerius have reminded us how important it is to bear in mind that this health crisis, this pandemic, also has very dire social consequences, like possible social exclusion and poverty, and how important it is that we put in place policies where no one is left behind.  Yesterday, in this Chamber, I presented the Commission Work Programme for the next year. I would like to reassure the House that we are going to put enormous emphasis and focus on the Action Plan on the European Pillar of Social Rights, where it would focus on the new European Child Guarantee and other important steps, which I believe would be very important for the future. We are already working on putting the first foundation stones on a new, stronger health union for Europe. We are proposing operational steps on how improve the work of our European Medicines Agency (EMA) and our European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC), but also on founding the new advanced research biomedical BARDA agency, which I believe will help us not only to be at the cutting edge of research, but – if at any time in the future we are faced with the same challenges – will also mean that we have much faster and much better answers.  I agree with all of you who have been stressing the importance of citizen—to—citizen solidarity – support, but also responsibility – which we have to show to each of us. We can do much more in the European Union. We see how the SURE scheme was important for preserving jobs in Europe, and we can be encouraged by this first interest in European bonds, which I hope is a good indication of how this instrument can work well in the future, and not only of how we can finance the Next Generation EU, but also of how we can combine it well with the next multiannual financial perspective.  The calls, from many of you, to make sure that we negotiate in an honest and speedy way in order to make sure that we have these two powerful instruments at our disposal as of 1 January 2021 was absolutely crucial. I would like to reassure you that the Commission will do its utmost to get the co-legislators closer and to play the role of honest broker. We will be ready to assist in any way possible so that, as of the beginning of next year, we will have all financial instruments at our disposal and we can fund all the operations and all the programmes that we were discussing today. That would, as Mr Mureşan and Ms García Pérez have been calling for, also comprise new own resources. We are working on a roadmap which would cover a digital levy, a carbon border adjustment system, revision of the Emissions Trading System (ETS) and some other measures which we know are very important, not only from the political and economic point of view, but also from the point of view of making sure that these new own resources will help us to fund the right and correct policies for the future.  I would say that almost every Member of the European Parliament who intervened today addressed the very important issue of our future partnership with our friends in the United Kingdom. I think that this debate clearly demonstrated strong trust and support for our chief negotiator, Michel Barnier. It’s well deserved, and, as they say in his country, bien mérité. I can assure you that President von der Leyen, myself and all our services are ready to work for a fair deal up to the last minute. We know – and we listened to your very loud and clear position – that we are interested in this unprecedented partnership – the deepest that was ever negotiated – but not at any cost. Therefore, regarding the concerns of Mr Bourgeois, Mr Scholz and others on fisheries, I would just like to tell you that, without a fair deal on fisheries, there will be no fair deal on a trade agreement. It’s part of the deal. We know that, and this is how we are going to negotiate.  At the same time, I totally subscribe to the calls for urgency. Time is really flying by, and every day of lost negotiations is a day of lost opportunities to find the necessary compromises. Our chief negotiator and the President – and I was listening very carefully to the President of the European Council – have been very, very clear on that as well. Therefore. I would again underline that now it’s time for responsibility towards our citizens and towards peace and economic prosperity on the island of Ireland. This is what is at stake. This is what we have to bear in mind when negotiating.  I would also like to thank you for your support on the proper and timely implementation of the Withdrawal Agreement. Mr Cioloş and others made it very clear that there cannot be a new deal unless the last one is properly respected. It is very clear and very simple, and we all should understand it very well. At the same time, I have to say that this Monday I was encouraged because we had a good, constructive discussion with the Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, Mr Gove. We are advancing very well on guaranteeing citizens’ rights, as we promised to UK and EU citizens in the Withdrawal Agreement. We agreed to maximise and intensify the frequency of our meetings at the level of the negotiators. We have also been providing clear political steer on what needs to be done to ensure that the Withdrawal Agreement is properly respected, implemented and operationalised. We will be very vigilant at every single step. I know that our British friends say that the proof of the pudding is in the eating. Therefore, let’s see how far we progress and what we can achieve between now and mid—November, when we agreed with Chancellor Gove to see each other again in the form of the next Joint Committee. I hope that this will assuage the concerns that were presented by Mr Kelly, Mr MacManus and Mr Hansen.  I would like to thank Ms Keller, Mr Urtasun and others for your support for our ambitious goal for our climate agenda. Yesterday, when I was presenting the Commission Work Programme for the next year, I made very clear reference to the very ambitious Fit for 55 chapter in our Commission Work Programme. I think, without any exaggeration, that this is the most ambitious host of measures we have ever presented in the area of climate goals, and I hope that – with your support – we will be able to achieve them. Concerning the right focus in the interventions of honourable Members, Ms Hautala, Mr Bullmann and Mr Zorrinho on Africa. As you know, one of our priorities when we started to work as a Commission was to develop our relationship with our African partners, based on the Strategy with Africa, and I would underline the word ‘with’ because we really want to have a deep partnership. That was behind the first trip of our President, which she took to Africa and behind our efforts in development of a deeper and stronger partnership with our African partners. The clear example of this is that, if we are talking about vaccines, we are talking about vaccines for all – including for our partners in Africa. I know that Africa is something that is very close to the heart of the President of the European Council, who very wisely put it up for discussion among the European leaders, and he got a lot of support for that.

name: Charles Michel
text: President of the European Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for the messages that have been sent. First, a brief word on Brexit because it seems to me that this is a demonstration of the full capacity of the European institutions to cooperate and to express together, as we do, the quiet strength of the European Union. We have principles, common sense principles, principles to which we are attached, and it is in this context that Parliament, the Council and the Commission, with the very strong involvement of Michel Barnier, we are situated. We will therefore support, on the side of the European Council, all efforts, because we do believe that an agreement is desirable, but we will indeed defend the points of concern that have been raised by many of you and which I myself have highlighted with Michel Barnier and Mr 'Eef-ovi' in introduction to this debate. The second point, to which many reacted rightly: the battle against COVID-19. We are at the heart of this battle, we must remain fully mobilized. When the battle broke out, starting in February/March of this year, initiatives were taken, decisions were made. The European Commission's mobilization on the issue of vaccines is essential, but we can see that even if vaccines are developed sometime next year, it will take time for them to reach their full effectiveness. And we are now faced, there is no doubt, with the second wave, which imposes harsh measures, again, restrictions, with hard impacts both psychologically and economically and socially. That is why we must indeed work hard, be even more mobilised on the issue of cooperation and in particular, from my point of view, on the issue of tracing, testing, quarantine, intra-European traffic. There is no doubt that in the coming months, even if vaccines are available from next year, we will have to continue to use this lever to reduce this threat, which is a tough threat to Europe, which is our citizens, which is our businesses. That is why, as Dacian Cioloo has pointed out, we have indeed considered that, at each of the European Councils, at the level of heads of state or government, the point will have to be debated, raised and discussed in order to try to give the necessary wise impetus on this subject. Moreover, since the pandemic started, either by videoconference or by physical meeting, this point has been systematically debated and discussed at the beginning of each European Council meeting. The third point I want to make following the questioning on the subject is what I understand is the situation in the eastern Mediterranean. I have been a member of the European Council for almost six years now, of which I have been President for less than a year. For the first time, a few weeks ago, we had an in-depth strategic debate - almost eight hours of debate! - which has focused on this issue of the Eastern Mediterranean, in order to have indeed all the necessary nuance on the subject. Yes, we must be firm in defending and enforcing our Member States, sovereign sovereignty and rights! It is the firm and unambiguous message that is addressed. On the other hand, we wish to make this dual approach possible with a positive agenda, as positive as possible, on the condition that unilateral provocations that are not acceptable cease. We also maintain permanent contact within the framework of the United Nations, because we know that there is also a role to play in relation, in particular, to the Cyprus issue and the necessary settlement of this issue. Rest assured that, as President of the European Council, I will constantly mobilise to build a European consensus for a stronger, more ambitious and firmer geopolitical strategy in order to defend our values and win the interests for which we are all mobilised. I am pleased that many of you have raised the issue of Africa - Mr Bullmann, and others as well. I welcome this because I do believe that this neighbouring continent is, for so natural reasons, so obvious, a continent for which we must mobilize. We must engage in an ambitious alliance. This means, in fact, that investment issues, infrastructure issues, green pact issues for Europe, probably also digital agendas, education issues or health system, which is being tested in the context of COVID-19, must be the subject of our mobilization in a partnership of equals, imbued with mutual respect, by of course defending the values to which we are attached: the rule of law, the protection of human rights will have to be addressed in these matters, in order to advance this agenda for the benefit of Europe. , to the benefit of Africa. It is also, for me, a common-sense issue. We must all roll up our sleeves to try to meet this ambition. Several have rightly raised the climate issue. I would like to avoid the misunderstandings between us - allow my presence in this House to be an opportunity to correct perhaps some misunderstandings. It was not our intention to make a decision on the 2030 issue at this summit. I fully accept that I considered and consider that we needed a strategic discussion, not a discussion today on the issue of drafting and exact country-by-country ambition. We will have to make this decision as soon as possible, I hope at the end of the year, but this strategic discussion was the necessary step, the necessary step with the involvement of the European Commission, which we are going to need. I have noticed - this is an important point to highlight - that there is a trend towards support for the 55% proposal put on the table by the Commission, but with concerns in terms of national impacts. Hence the conclusions which highlight the Commission's engagement with the Member States, especially some of them, which are more directly concerned with the concern of the starting point. The aim, as you well measure, is that each member state, when it commits, can really be mobilised to implement the commitment, to produce results. Rest assured that I will be very personally engaged, because I believe that this point is central so that before the end of the year, at the next Council in December, we can make a decision on this subject. I have already had the opportunity to say how totally convinced I am that this green ambition for the European Union is a key ambition. We are consistent, which is also why we have activated more of what I call 'climate diplomacy'. I am pleased that, less than a year after this historic decision, in my opinion, of the European Council on climate neutrality by 2050, less than a year later, therefore, we are taking the first steps: China in view of 2060 and South Africa have spoken. We are not naïve, it is not enough, but it shows that the strength and the regulatory power of the European Union must be put at the service of our values and the interests we believe in. That is the sense of action that we also want to take. Finally, a word on an essential issue, which many have mentioned: that of the next European budget and the Stimulus Fund. I do believe that we must draw on the creativity that is the magic of the European Union to find an agreement as soon as possible in order to implement it. I would just like to ask you, with extreme delicacy, extreme courtesy and deep respect, to say everything when debating the figures, to explain all the elements. I, of course, respect the position of the European Parliament that, in its view, the amount proposed by the Council in terms of the MFF is not sufficient. It is very legitimate for the European Parliament to have this point of view and I respect it, but we read that massive cuts have been made in Erasmus, in innovation funds, in defence funds: however, when you talk about cuts, what you are talking about to talk about these cuts. If it is in relation to the Commission's proposals - very legitimate and very respectable proposals - that is one thing, but if I compare the means mobilised today, I say never, in the history of the European Union, have so many resources been made available! $1.8 billion for the next few years for Erasmus, for innovation, for digital, for climate. In terms of stimulus funds, that is much more, proportionally, than China and the United States are doing. I therefore respectfully and courteously ask the European Parliament to present, when we are debating these issues, the whole image as proposed to it by the European Council. I look forward to continuing to engage in debates with you in the service of the European Union.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. Discussion topics were: negotiations between the EU and the United Kingdom, climate and external relations orientation debate with particular attention to Africa, and the issues of the poisoning of Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny and the management of the coronavirus pandemic were re-addressed. name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – As has been emphasised many times today, the whole world is facing an unprecedented health crisis. It will soon be a year from the beginning of this crisis, but the end is not yet apparent. It is therefore necessary to further coordinate and respond to this crisis at EU level. First of all, it is necessary to improve coordination between Member States because of the restrictions imposed, which directly affect the lives of our people. It is necessary to strengthen all actions on coordinated measures in the quarantine period, cross-border cooperation to ensure the traceability of infected persons, testing strategies, mutual recognition of tests and many other actions. Indeed, the Commission is already doing a great job of ensuring the purchase of the necessary quantity of vaccines, so it is now very important to take decisions that ensure that our citizens have access to affordable vaccines when they appear on the market.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. – At last week's European Council, the Heads of State or Government focused on EU-Africa relations in addition to the all-out Covid19 pandemic situation, which appears to be becoming increasingly serious throughout Europe. Solidarity and close cooperation in the fight against the Covid19 pandemic are crucial. Stability in Africa is a common goal, a prerequisite for a liveable vision. It requires cooperation in both the short and long term. We must work with our African partner countries in the fight against illegal migration, the fight against people smugglers and the return and readmission of illegal migrants. Halting mass exodus is key to Africa's vision, as generations disappear. We must give these young people a vision, and these countries must not be emptied. It is necessary to improve the conditions and wages of young workers in their home countries, to provide them with adequate professional education and to support their entrepreneurial skills, so as to prevent further emigration and to ensure that young people return home. Unfortunately, Christians are still subject to serious discrimination in some parts of Africa, so it is regrettable that the Council conclusions do not address the problem of discrimination on religious grounds, specifically the protection of persecuted Christians.

name: Loránt VINCZE
text: in writing. – It is in the interest of both the European Union and the United Kingdom to agree on an as close as possible partnership for the future. However, any agreement is worth being negotiated and concluded if there is trust that it will be implemented in full. The UK government just dealt a severe blow to this trust when it introduced a bill unilaterally overriding the Withdrawal Agreement, a binding international contract painstakingly negotiated for over three years and concluded less than a year ago. Arriving to an agreement and avoiding a disastrous no-deal outcome would be in the benefit of our industries, services and people. The EU should be ready to negotiate day and night to find the compromises needed for both sides, but only if we have the assurance that the Withdrawal Agreement and the provisions of the new partnership will be fully respected.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. While we are experiencing one of the worst crises in our history, Brussels continues to repeat the same mistakes. The approach to climate change remains ideological and totally inadequate to provide European citizens with the answers they need. Between unrealistic objectives and unrealistic forecasts, the only effect of these policies will be to make our already suffering industrial sectors less competitive without achieving full environmental protection. There is also still great fragility on the geopolitical front: in recent months Turkey has been at the centre of the diplomatic scene, starting with constant aggression against Member States such as Greece and Cyprus. Nevertheless, the EU continues to give funding to the country and to condemn Erdogan only in words, showing as always little consistency. The credibility of the European institutions is also diminishing in the area of managing the economic and health crisis. Negotiations between the Council and Parliament to reach an agreement on the Recovery Fund are stalled and, as widely expected, Italy will not receive any concrete help before 2021. Immediate action is needed for recovery: The Italian citizens cannot afford to wait for the slow timing of the European Union.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the joint debate on the report by Joachim Schuster, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the economic policies of the euro area for 2020 (2020/2078(INI)) (A9-0193/2020), and - the report by Klára Dobrev, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on employment and social policies in the euro area in 2020 (2020/2079(INI)) (A9-0183/2020).

name: Joachim SCHUSTER
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the Ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank all the rapporteurs very warmly. It has not always been easy discussions, especially since our original positions were very far apart, but we have tried to find a compromise, because it is important for Parliament to give an opinion on the issue of the European Semester. We agree that in the future we need an economic policy that takes into account both the challenges of the Corona pandemic, the challenges of climate protection, growing social and regional inequality and digitalisation.  The world has changed over the last twenty years, and politics must face up to these new realities. What new realities do I mean? The Corona crisis has worse economic effects than the 2008/2009 crisis. So far, we have succeeded in giving a European response in solidarity to the crisis. Part of this answer is that we are prepared to take on European debt together in order to get out of the crisis as quickly as possible, and that we tolerate a significant increase in the debt of each Member State. The corona crisis is a symmetrical shock, but it has different effects in the different Member States. However, this will also have consequences for the debt targets set. Some of these objectives set at the beginning of the 1990s will not be able to remain unchanged. My opinion on this is clear: we still need rules to limit public debt, but unrealistic and unattainable objectives do more harm than they use.  Another reality is that even before the crisis, the level of public and private investment was too low. This has severely limited the growth opportunities of European economies. In the meantime, the demands of climate change have also been added – a consistent climate protection policy requires additional public investment in the tens of billions of dollars every year.  In other words, we must ensure that these future investments can be made and that we do not fail because of debt brakes or restrictive fiscal policies – we agree on that. Incidentally, this is also a requirement of intergenerational justice, because today's failure to invest, especially in climate protection, will result in devastating damage and doubly burden future generations. In the report, we have therefore stated that we need a review of the economic and financial rules and, of course, depending on the results of the review, a change in the rules. The mistakes of the past must be avoided in choking off growth processes shortly after the end of a deep economic crisis, because debt targets are being absoluteised – this must never happen again.  We need a tailor-made countercyclical policy of sustainable growth that takes into account the requirements of the Sustainable Development Goals, the European Pillar of Social Rights and the Green Deal. In other words, fairness in distribution, reducing unemployment and reducing CO2 emissions must be a central part of European economic policy, and this economic policy must also become more democratic. All this must be reconciled with sound budgetary and fiscal policies. However, this is not only a question of expenditure, but also of revenue. That is why the report emphasises that we can no longer tolerate tax evasion and tax dumping. And we need new tax revenues, especially where only the European level can guarantee fair taxation, for example through the introduction of a digital tax, a financial transaction tax or harmonisation of corporation tax. Incidentally, this will also help to really service the European debt that we are now taking on.  As I said, these were difficult discussions in committee. Despite some differences in starting points, however, it has been possible to find sensible compromises. Thank you again to the rapporteurs for this.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: I'm not going to do that - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Those who do not learn from the past will be punished by repeating their old mistakes. We've heard that sentence many times in the last few years. Dear Colleagues, we do not want to repeat the old mistakes of the past. We must therefore learn from the mistake that Europe made in dealing with the economic crisis of 2008-2009. Remember, after the real estate bubble collapsed, Europe was threatened by an economic collapse not seen since The Second World War, and we Europeans successfully defended the banks and successfully protected the functioning of the economy. We just forgot about the most vulnerable, we forgot to reach under the arm of those who lost their jobs, their homes, their houses, who were in a hopeless situation. Europe will never make this mistake again. And now history is testing us again. We do not yet see the economic and social impact of the coronavirus crisis. One thing is certain, if, ten years after the previous crisis, we can say that Europe has successfully recovered the economy but failed European citizens, then we must never again allow the same thing to be seen 10 years after the current crisis of the coronavirus. That is why, in my report, I would like in all respects to help the most vulnerable, the most vulnerable. That is why I am calling, for example, for the introduction and regulation of the European minimum wage at European level. I would like us to invest much more money than ever before in education, social investment, health. In the latter context, the report supports the creation of a European Health Union. We've learned our lesson. Furthermore, we propose that older people living below the poverty line should also receive a fair and sufficient pension. We propose that Member States adapt their tax systems so that it does not increase the gap between the richest and the poor, but rather reduces it, because that is our task. And that is why we support the rule of law, because it is the rule of law that can protect the most vulnerable, the poor, the vulnerable against the strong, against the powerful. I know very well that we in the European Parliament overwhelmingly want the same thing, a strong and successful Europe. But let us finally understand that there is no strong and successful Europe without strong and successful European citizens. If we cannot say that all European citizens are strong and successful, then Europe will not be either. I therefore ask you to support my report. Thank you very much!

name: Paolo Gentiloni
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, today we discuss I think two extremely timely and important reports. First of all I would like, also on behalf of Commissioner Schmit, to congratulate Joachim Schuster and Klára Dobrev, as well as the shadow rapporteurs, on their outstanding work on economic and social policies.  We know that we are facing unprecedented challenges. The human costs and the economic consequences of this crisis are huge. Recovery, from the economic point of view, began indeed last May, but uncertainty is still surrounding us and the speed of recovery is slowing. On 5 November I will present our autumn forecast and I have today a few clear messages coherent with the report Joachim Schuster presented.  First, we need a supportive fiscal stance. It should continue. We should avoid premature withdrawal of supportive measures. We can’t risk a double—dip recession. Second, the general escape clause will remain in place for 2021, as Valdis Dombrovskis and I made clear to Member States recently. Next spring we will assess the situation. Third, we should use NextGenerationEU to transform our economies, not to go back to normal but to build more sustainable, resilient and competitive economies. We increasingly see the social consequences of this crisis. Employment has been falling and unemployment is on the rise, even though so far it has been contained by the massive use of short—term work schemes. We are strongly supporting this effort with the SURE instrument. You saw the success of our first emission of social bonds yesterday.  Population groups that were already vulnerable before the pandemic are particularly hit, for example young people, women, and generally all those in precarious jobs, or disadvantaged children held back from benefiting from digital education. Mitigating the social impacts of the crisis will be one of the overarching objectives of the Recovery and Resilience Facility (RRF).  We would like to highlight three elements which we see as key for success. First, we need a skilling revolution to tap the job opportunities offered in the recovery, and particularly to face green and digital transitions. This is the objective of the recent Skills Agenda proposed by the Commission. Second, we have to enhance the quality of jobs – fair minimum wages are an essential element. We want to reduce wage inequality and poverty for the most vulnerable workers. This is why the Commission will put forward a European framework for a minimum wage later this month to make sure work pays off. This proposal will fully respect national traditions and the role of social partners in collective bargaining.  The third point is addressing poverty and inequalities. One essential element is to eradicate poverty from the start of life. Too many children across the EU grow up in poverty, creating barriers for their career and social integration. The European Child Guarantee, which we will present next year, will make sure that all children, whatever their background, have access to the same services and the same opportunities.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. First of all, it is gratifying that we in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs have once again managed to bring a report to plenary. This has not always been taken for granted in the past, and i would like to thank all those who have taken responsibility for being able to make our comments from the economic side. On the other hand, I think it has already become clear during the negotiations that we no longer have quite this common basic understanding of why the European Semester actually exists. The European Semester has been created as the preventive arm of the Stability and Growth Pact, because, ladies and gentlemen, we can, of course, do the next generation a green deal and sustainable development goals and everything, only if we do the next generation a beautiful globe, but because of high over-indebtedness, we have not done the next generation any favours either.  If even amendments are now being tabled in plenary, that the ECB should simply put the debt to zero that it has bought up, then they are showing the real face of what is really at stake, namely a state economy that can take money into its hands without regard for the next generations, because it is easy to set it at zero if it is parked at the ECB. I tell you quite frankly that I come from a country where this was done in the post-World War I period. This led to hyperinflation and poverty, real poverty, unemployment, and then a dark time on this continent in 1923.  I warn against just saying we have to save the world, whatever it may. We must always keep economics and ecology in harmony, and that is unfortunately our problem with this report. I am glad that the committee has managed to strike this balance. I hope that this will continue to be the case in plenary. The rapporteur is right to say that we must carry out a review, that we must prepare for the 1920s and provide the answers. It can no longer be answered with the questions of the 1990s of the first millennium. But you are pretending that you already know the answer before the relevant institutions have even dealt with it here. So what do we have to face to a review when parts of this House already know what needs to come out? Sorry, then I don't need a check.  That is why I would ask you to focus again on what to do – to design the preventive arm of the Stability and Growth Pact in such a way that the Member States do not fall into a permanent debt trap, then we are sustainable in the real sense.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. Mr President, if even Prime Minister Rutte and Minister Hoekstra fall off their austerity beliefs, something is really going on! When big companies falter, they pull the stock market. Unfortunately, however, we need to talk not only about emergency measures, but also about structural measures. It is time, we believe, that it is about people again and not the interests of the multinationals. Europe is more than a market and more than a market with a currency. It is the challenges we face in the Netherlands and in Europe to get out of the crisis honestly, and we will not forget anyone. That's the way the PvdA wants to go. We want higher minimum wages, so that no one has to choose between hot water or hot food at the end of the month. We want a ban on zero-hours contracts so you can make plans and be sure of your income. And we want more affordable social rented housing, because then start-ups can really start a future. With support from Europe when jobs are at risk from the crisis. Digitisation and climate change can only be managed if everyone can come along. Therefore, support amendment number 12 by my colleague Joachim Schuster. We need to invest in the opportunities of all and not just the happy few. We must honestly get out of the crisis with binding social targets so that everyone can be sure of a higher minimum wage, secure contracts and affordable housing.

name: Ivars IJABS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, recovery from the COVID crisis demands rethinking the European economic governance, and the European Semester framework can be a good starting point for this. What we in the Renew Europe have done in this year’s report, is try to combine the existing macroeconomic core of the Semester fiscal discipline and healthy debt levels, with the urgent demands of today, like the need for public and private investment, social protection, as well as the need to tackle climate change. Let me mention a few issues of great importance for us.  First of all, the promotion of reform is still the most important task of the Semester. The country-specific recommendations were often extremely weakly implemented. Member States should have tailor-made solutions for reform in order to promote competitiveness and growth in all European countries, also using Next Generation EU money.  Second, the report urges the review of the existing conditions of the Stability and Growth pact, since the crisis has shown that there are changes to be made. However, it must be done in a careful way, which would effectively motivate the Member States to comply with the requirements of the Stability and Growth pact.  Third, the need to tackle climate change, which is already an overarching, horizontal priority. We need to find its proper place in the framework of the European Semester. Therefore, we urge the Commission to develop a Climate Indicator, which would be supplementary to the existing Semester framework. When critically adapted to current circumstances, the European Semester can have a real, transformational impact on the European economy, and the current report is a significant attempt to strengthen the Semester framework by making it more sustainable, effective and resilient to future challenges.

name: France JAMET
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this report promotes the principle of the European minimum wage, which we will never accept. This smoking idea would inevitably lead to a levelling down, a deterioration of the most advanced countries in terms of social policy, wage, and a decline in the social rights of workers. And as the devil hides in the details, I will add that I see in the vocabulary used, "systemic racism," "structural discrimination" the pernicious permeation of an extreme left. This same semantic process serves as a mask for Islamists to dissolve our civilization and impose theirs insidiously. In short, a typical report of which only the European Union has the secret: our economic ruin on the one hand and the civilizational submission to Islamo-leftism, on the other. You were talking, Madam, about a strong Europe; we need a Europe that defends itself.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, when I hear our colleague Mr Ferber, I do not know whether I should laugh or cry. He basically tells us, ''OK to save the planet, but only if it doesn't ruin our public finances and it doesn't ruin our economies.'' What I am saying to him, Mr Ferber, is that if the planet becomes uninhabitable for human beings, there will be no more savings, there will be more public finances, it is as simple as that. And he would like us to believe that, of course, the only people who know how to handle well are the Conservatives. We are also convinced that when we are part of an economic and monetary union, we need common rules that must promote the stability and convergence of our economies. One element in this sense is, of course, the stability of our public finances. But who can still say that allowing the pandemic to take hold, the social divide deepening, the climate crisis getting carried away, natural resources depleting or biodiversity collapsing will have no impact on our public finances? I agree with your EPP colleagues only on one point: reducing inequality or our ecological footprint is in tension with the indiscriminate pursuit of growth at all costs. But pursuing an economic and budgetary policy that ensures the stability and even the economic competitiveness of our societies requires a European semester that can take into account the whole picture, and that is what the Commission is obviously proposing. On this account, the statements of Mr Ferber or his colleague Enik-Gyri remind me of those who, after the trial of Galileo, were delighted, despite common sense and science, to see the triumph of the thesis that the Earth is the centre of the universe: pitiful and unworthy of a great European party.

name: Eugen JURZYCA
text: for the ECR Group. – Madam President, Member States need a return to budgetary responsibility as quickly as possible and a plan to reduce public debt, which is expected to exceed an astronomical 100% of euro area GDP this year. This is what the Commission's recommendations in the European Semester cycle are intended to help them do.  However, the present report looks more like a way to further long-term indebteding of the Member States. I consider the failure to respect fiscal rules to be quite a great deal of irresponsibility and a threat to the monetary zone. Member States need more structural reforms in the long term, not more debt. In the long term, new debts increase taxes and hinder growth. If Member States do not make the necessary reforms to their economies, they will ultimately have nothing to finance either domestic or costly European priorities such as the Green Deal. At the expense of the future, you cannot live forever.

name: José GUSMÃO
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, as a member of parliament's Committee on Economic Affairs and the Employment Committee at the same time, I am very sad to see that the report coming out of ECON continues to see austerity and pro-cyclical policies as the only possible economic policy within the European Union, and continues to relegate social issues and climate issues to a background, as seen well in paragraph 25. That is why I will support Amendment No 12. And that is why It seems to me that the lessons of the last economic crisis have not been well learned by a part of this House and also by the European institutions. Because it is not worth telling states that they need to maintain support for economies when the European Commission's action programme comes back there with fanaticism, with the irresponsible discourse of budgetary prudence. Fiscal prudence is economic growth now, it is responding to the unemployed and poverty.  There is no point in lamenting wage inequality when we continue to press Member States to maintain policies to deregulate labour markets, which have been imposed by the European institutions for decades. It is not worth saying that we need a European Health Union when for decades we have been pressuring Member States to underfinance and privatise their public health services, the public health services that are now saving the lives of millions of European citizens.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to say that this crisis, as is evident to everyone, has caused so many problems, it has highlighted so many critical issues and fragilities of our Union mechanisms.  You think that at the moment, in the European Union, the money supply is tending to double, but the speed of circulation of the currency is tending to halve. This means only one thing: that, as our economy, the real economy suffers more and more, the banks are getting more and more enriching. Any chain of monetary policy has now broken down, so that every injection of new money no longer has any effect at the level of inflation and politics is unfortunately completely subordinated to the power of the banks, which are now a bottomless pit that is getting richer and richer at the expense of the citizens.  So if we want to get out of this situation, I would say catastrophic, we must do a few simple but also courageous things: firstly, we need the ECB to be freed from the blackmail of private banks, the Member States must be freed from market blackmail and we must avoid abandoning the concept of unsustainability of public debt, abandoning the concept of European funds, the ESA, the SURE , the recovery fund's share of loans make no sense under fiat money regime, and then zero, eliminate all differences in the cost of money, under the single currency regime.  If we do not do these simple things, unfortunately, the fate of our continent is sealed and will inevitably be a third-world destiny.

name: Dennis RADTKE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. I think it is fair to say that today's report is a really good piece of social policy here.  I realise that there are also Members of this House who take a completely different view of this, because they believe that social affairs and Europe have nothing to do with each other, and that is why we, as a Parliament, should also remain silent on this. I see it quite differently, for two reasons: firstly, each Member State is committed to the principle of the social market economy through its membership, and secondly, every single citizen of the European Union has acquired fundamental rights through their citizenship of the Union, including fundamental social rights.  That is why I think it is our job, our primary duty as A Parliament, to look closely: how far is it really with these principles of order and what is the point of respectforing these fundamental social rights, including and especially in the most serious economic crisis in the European Union? That is why I think that today's report has really made an important contribution to this, and we have also built a bridge to what is on the agenda in the coming weeks and months. I am simply saying the minimum wage, the further development of schools, these are all issues that we will be dealing with in the coming weeks and months, as well as the issue of the fight against homelessness.  I think – and I would like to end here – that anyone who looks at developments in some places on our continent can simply conclude that people who cannot live on their hands, child poverty and homelessness are the case in every keynote speech on European policy, on every Sunday speech on European policy. I am therefore pleased that today we have made a good contribution to moving things in the right direction. Ask for your approval.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteurs for the work of the rapporteurs and, as a member of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, to thank Joachim Schuster for preparing this report which deserves Parliament's support. It deserves the support of the house primarily on one issue — and I will focus it on only one — this report requires that national fiscal policies remain expansional until we find a solid basis for recovery. And, to the extent that uncertainties about the evolution of the pandemic remain present in our societies, we believe that this will be necessary for quite some time.  In any event, this should not avoid the debate on the fiscal rules that the report also advocates: a revision of the fiscal rules allowing the Stability and Growth Pact to be adapted to the orderly management of the economy through the Union as a whole.  And, therefore, beyond the discussions on the flexibility of this Pact, we need to discuss at the same time what we are going to do with the Next Generation EU in the medium term, because the report also calls for an automatic stabiliser. Can we also discuss the viability of a risk-free asset in Europe — and have we seen the success of yesterday's debt issuance? And why not also talk about the prudential treatment of state debt?  But this great debate to which we are doomed, which we have to have, cannot prevent us from going through this expansive policy in the short and medium term.

name: Marie-Pierre VEDRENNE
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the rapporteur first of all. This report is our response to the social challenges created by the shock of COVID and our message is clear: to ensure a European recovery that meets the challenges by leaving no one behind. The European Semester will be the instrument of recovery, that is fine, and this report reminds us that social and employment must be as much the priority as our economic stimulus policies. We have to make sure that we all go in the same direction. A revival is an innovative transformation that is economically, just socially and ecologically responsible. For this, three simultaneous priorities. First, the urgency of recovery. The historic recovery plan, adopted last July, will have to support workers, specifically the most insecure, in order to preserve their jobs, wages and working conditions. Promoting social inclusion, combating poverty, supporting the poorest, strengthening the employability of young people must remain our priorities. Second, to maintain our course. This shock requires quick responses. However, we must not give up on our longer-term goals at all. Our economic and social policies must contribute to the objectives of sustainable development, the implementation of the Green Pact and the realisation of the European social rights base. Third, the acceleration of the implementation of the social agenda. Deep inequalities and the weakness of our European social model have been revealed. We must move forward on our agenda for social convergence and the fight against poverty. As an example, you have mentioned, Commissioner, an instrument for a fair minimum wage in each Member Country is needed more than ever. We know the European Commission is committed, we are waiting for strong announcements and you can then count on the European Parliament to build a Europe of social justice.

name: Francesca DONATO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Covid-19 has regained its vigour throughout Europe and the world, and serious economic damage that has already occurred will last for years. Despite this, the European agenda continues to give priority to the fight against climate change, tying every measure and intervention to unrealistic targets, instead of concentrating every effort to avoid the most likely and imminent economic collapse of the entire Union.  The only tool that has been effective and timely so far is the ECB's extraordinary sovereign bond purchase programme, without which the eurozone would have jumped. In order to withstand the shock of the pandemic crisis, the Stability Pact had to be suspended. What is needed today, therefore, is not new climate constraints on the European economy, but greater flexibility for investment and maximum support for Member States' spending, through a strengthening of the ECB's mandate and the lifting of the ban on Article 123 TFEI. Banking regulations on credit risk management and the classification of non-performing loans should also be reviewed in order to avoid tightening the credit policies of European banks, which are detrimental to households and businesses.  Before calling for reforms from the Member States, the European Union must today reform its treaties and objectives. Only in this way will it be credible and resilient.

name: Kira Marie PETER-HANSEN
text: – Madam President, I hope that you can hear and see me down in the Parliament. I’m speaking from the Danish office.  Thank you very much to the rapporteur for the work on this file, as there is a strong need to make sure that the social aspects are a key element in the Semester.  This is the way that we will make social process progress in Europe, and especially now, when every country is experiencing downward-turning economies. We need to create incentives for the Member States not to let the burden of a recession fall on the people most in need, and here the European Semester is a golden opportunity for us to create these incentives. Austerity and tight budgets are not the way to manage the crisis. Making sure that people have decent lives is the way. This means securing a roof over their heads and food on the table. We need to make sure that the social and economic aspects are on an equal footing in this Semester, and taking the Green Deal into account, and we need to push for a European framework for minimum income, binding pay-transparency measures as well as ensuring quality employment with decent fair pay for our young people in Europe through the youth guarantee. These has been some of the key issues for the Greens Free Alliance group in the work on this file.  Thank you very much to you, Klára Dobrev, for doing a really great job on this report and making sure that the European Parliament has a strong social and sustainable voice on this issue. It’s been a pleasure working with all of you and I’m looking forward to keeping this fight up.

name: Helmut GEUKING
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her So first of all, thank you very much, I was present at the consultation, Mrs Dobrev, you managed this excellently. Thank you very much to Mr Radtke. There is nothing to add to what you said earlier, and I see it the same way– that is the case.  What has been forgotten, however, is, of course, the parents and the poverty of old age. If you look at old-age poverty in Germany and other European countries, you know that parents have been being scammed for their life benefits for decades. Point.  If you look at how child poverty is progressing, you know that there is a need for action, and not just with a leap guarantee, in mere words, we are giving access to education. We need direct financial support for children in order to get children out of child poverty. That is why we, as the family party of Germany, have dribbled forward and have beaten passports for the child benefit 2525. It is enshrined in the social report in the sense that children need to be better off financially, and only child benefit is left behind. We have beaten the passport, and it is now up to Mrs Merkel and the German Presidency to use this passport and bring it to the gate accordingly.  I call for the main support of this social report, above all in order to strengthen the funding of children and to combat child poverty directly. We owe this to future generations.

name: Mislav KOLAKUŠIĆ
text: – The respected Presidency, economic and social future and present of the European Union depends mainly on our reaction to the COVID-19 pandemic. This year in the spring we started using lockdown. As a result of the lockdown and its policies, millions of jobs were lost in the European Union. Now slowly individual states are reintroducing and implementing lockdown policies. We're going to lose millions more jobs. If we continue to do so by spring, we will be able to talk about tens of millions of jobs lost. It took decades to create these jobs.  The states will go into extreme debt. Now in the Republic of Croatia, the Prime Minister said yesterday that due to the consequences of repairing the lockdown damages and financing entrepreneurs, we are unable to pay out one billion euros in debt to wholesalers, which means that we are not capable of paying for medicines. One billion euros in Croatia means a sixth of the entire state budget. We need to rethink, in this house, the lockdown policy, whether there is another way to combat the COVID-19 pandemic.

name: Enikő GYŐRI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. The future of the Union depends on whether, in the current crisis situation, we can re-establish the economic backdrop to the European model of which we are so proud. As a responsible decision-maker, economic funds must first be provided. The European Semester is a compass for this work. Only in this way will we be able to achieve our ambitious goals, such as the digital transition or climate protection, so that we can grow again, preserve jobs and create new ones. This strategy cannot exist without rules. Even in the current epidemic and crisis, these Member States have been given sufficient flexibility to increase the financial space. In the course of the negotiations, I have seen that the main objective of the left is to break down the essence of economic policy coordination and fiscal rules one by one; the People's Party is not a partner for this. The left wants the instrument of coordination between Member States, the semester, which we created to prevent and deal with crises during the Hungarian Presidency, to be filled with all sorts of fashionable topics. If the left succeeds in realise its ideas, we can say goodbye to competitiveness. No free lunch. Funding all left-wing ideas would trigger a wave of spending that would ultimately lead to job losses. We cannot allow our economic policy to become a mess of competing goals. These ideas have been voted down by the Economic Committee, and the left is now trying to smuggle them back with amendments. Irresponsible economic policies would jeopardise the restoration of the Union and ind due to future generations. Hungary citizens of The United States learned what it was like under communism and then socialist-liberal governments, and did not ask for it again. And our fellow Liberal Members are already thinking of a common finance minister in the European Federation, i.e. they would significantly reduce the powers of the Member States. This goes against the treaties and would break the balances in political and economic policy coordination between the Member States and Brussels. Such ideas, in times of crisis, are a waste of time and energy from important things to do, not helping them to recover. I would therefore ask my fellow Members not to vote for the amendments, not to be partners in irresponsible economic policy ideas.

name: Marc ANGEL
text: – Madam President, the past financial crisis and the answer the EU has given show how cuts in public services had a negative impact on our economic, environmental and social recovery. No progress in poverty reduction and social inclusion shows that many of our social welfare systems are not robust and resilient enough to absorb social shocks during a crisis and also transition. This is why we Socialists and Democrats urge Member States to stop considering public services as a cost but, on the contrary, as an investment to guarantee a decent life for all of us in the Union. And a decent life means wellbeing that includes access to quality education and jobs, as well as social security, healthcare, housing, justice and social services, and also especially for vulnerable groups.  To achieve this, it’s important to change the mind-set of many EU leaders and to come forward with a model that puts social and environmental challenges on an equal footing with economic ones. This is the only way to align our EU policies with the three dimensions of the SDGs and to avoid a lost generation. If we want our next generation in Europe to be strong and resilient, we must invest in their future and therefore must consider Child Guarantee and Youth Guarantee amongst the most precious instruments we have. Dear colleagues, Child Guarantee and Youth Guarantee can only be successful if we allocate sufficient financial means and if we are able to show creativity when it comes to shaping them and implementing them. Let me finish by thanking Ms Dobrev and Mr Schuster and the shadows for their excellent reports.

name: Guido REIL
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Ladies and gentlemen present, I am proud that you have found the courage to be here today. Because since last week we know that it is dangerous here. This building is apparently the COVID—19 hotspot in Europe – you have to imagine that. It takes courage to come to this Parliament, and the interesting thing is: why? What are the causes? Of course, it has nothing to do with the fact that oysters and champagne have been served here again in recent weeks. It has to do with the intensity of work in this Parliament – it has nothing else to do with it. And what are the resulting measures? 80% of our staff are in the home office. There was indeed a debate last week about whether we were allowed into the building at all – thank God we can still do it.  Our meetings will soon take place completely digitally – at least from January. So Personally, I think that's a good thing. Because then you can perhaps finally do something meaningful with this building. For example, house the homeless, as was announced in the media in April to do something for the homeless, and then again nothing happened except warm words. So let us stay at home and do the work that can do it: the national parliaments! Because they are fully capable of working.

name: Claude GRUFFAT
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, as long as green investments are seen as mere deficits with no future benefits, we will deny European states a stronger and green future for a more sustainable and livable society. Of course, I agree, coordinating economic policies is necessary, but the current rules do not differentiate between spending on keeping a system running out of steam and spending on building a future for us and our children. A new approach is therefore essential to enhance green investments. New indicators that serve the real economy and our planet must be taken into account when calculating deficits. Let us get out of it, among other things, the expenses related to the ecological transition and, above all, stop using indicators dating back to the 1930s, whose health crisis has demonstrated obsolescence. Utilities, those that serve our planet, are not deficits, they are real economies.

name: Elżbieta RAFALSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The report highlights the key role of economic, social and health policy coordination, in which the European Pillar of Social Affairs and fiscal space policies play a major role. In times of crisis, accurate diagnosis is more important than ever. It also points to the social risks associated with the pandemic crisis, such as rising unemployment, including youth unemployment, increased child poverty, worsening of the situation of people with disabilities and the elderly, a crisis in care services, limited access to health services. However, I would like to draw attention to the following problematic issues. Firstly, the assessment of the rule of law and the effectiveness of justice taken into account in the European Semester. Secondly, the importance attributed to the permanent EU reinsurance programme for unemployment benefits. Thirdly, the call for a European Health Union. Fourthly, the Commission's call for a European framework on the minimum wage. These are issues that fundamentally change us.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: – Madam President, dear Commissioner, dear and dear Colleagues, it is not acceptable in the European Union to have 100 million citizens at risk of poverty and 700,000 people without shelter. We can't be indifferent, we have to act and we can't do our part.  The European Union makes many resources available, such as the European Social Fund, the Youth Guarantee, followed also by the Child Guarantee. They must be well used and made available, in particular to charities such as IPSS and Mercies. But then we must above all go to the causes, promote individual autonomy, help social ascension. That is how we give dignity back to our citizens, and for that we have to bet on the economy, which has to be resilient, it has to be competitive, it has to be sustainable. We cannot be afraid of the words productivity and sustainability, and of the entrepreneurship that is necessary.
