In addition, we must help businesses, and in particular small and medium-sized enterprises.  And so, Commissioner, it is unacceptable that the Council has cut off a solvency instrument precisely to support companies in difficulty. It is unacceptable that the Council has cut investeu, which promotes investment. Everyone has to do their part. The European Commission has done its part, and Parliament. Not all Member States. The Council has not acted to do its job to combat poverty, to promote inclusion, to help small and medium-sized enterprises, and I hope that an instrument such as SURE will go from temporary to permanent and that, moreover, it will be an instrument where the European Parliament is also involved. We are, of course, defending the Community method.

name: Stefania ZAMBELLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the social and economic effects of the Covid-19 pandemic are clear to everyone. The impact on the world of work is unprecedented, with unemployment rising by two percentage points across Europe. If we want to relaunch the labour market and employment, the appropriate instrument will certainly not be the introduction of new taxes to finance the recovery fund, because these will put the productive world in further difficulty. Instead, we must give practical support to entrepreneurs, craftsmen, traders, operators in the world of tourism, VAT numbers, all those who have waited in vain for aid from Europe and the Member States in recent months.  The number of businesses and businesses closed to date is appalling and is nothing compared, believe me, to what will happen in the coming months when, once the redundancies have been stopped, hundreds of thousands of people will find themselves in the middle of a street. Europe will have to take responsibility for these people, and I do not think it is useful or wise to waste any more time.

name: Dolors MONTSERRAT
text: – Madam President, COVID-19 hits us with a dramatic balance in loss of life and millions of jobs. The European Union has assumed its responsibility and is up to the great and constant needs.  Now is the time for the Member States, to particularise in each country the collective effort we are making among all, to strengthen our national health systems and to promote the recovery of the economy and employment. Employment is the best social policy to combat poverty. But we must also be vigilant so that, in the chaos of the crisis, partisan agendas are not put before the common and collective good. The pillars of the Union must remain intact through a firm defence of the separation of powers. And European funds are to strengthen us. That's the way and not undermining the rule of law. Therefore, in order to ensure the good end and use of European aid, responsible involvement of all levels of government, both national and regional, and local, together with social actors, is essential under the effective coordination of the European Union.  In Spain, immediate action must be taken, applying funds to support brutally punished sectors such as tourism, hospitality and services. The Government of Spain should focus on implementing active policies to alleviate 41% youth unemployment and implement tax cuts, abandoning restrictive policies aimed at maintaining the sheer non-productive structural cost. The Spanish citizens and those throughout Europe look at us in a demanding way, as never before, waiting for responsible and future solutions from us, and immediately.

name: Herve JUVIN
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I have appreciated, like many here, the torrent of good intentions that populate this report. Unfortunately, I'm afraid I won't appreciate them from all angles. First, because we are not going to the next world, we are going to the world with it. We are going to live with the pandemic that no one thinks will end until the summer of 2021 and perhaps longer. We will live with the threat of ecological collapses that we are already seeing the announcement of and which perhaps this pandemic was one of the first manifestations. The issue is not nature or the planet, the issue is human life on this planet and it is man, we will have to think about it. Secondly, because the collapse we are witnessing today, let us not address its consequences, let us look at its causes. Its causes are uncontrolled cross-border movements, it is the ideology of free trade, it is the ideology of openness. In our parliamentary work, we will have to question a number of the fundamentals that have caused the current situation, unsted tragedies. We are probably at the beginning. Let us not only consider the consequences, let us tackle the causes.

name: Peter KOFOD
text: Madam. President! The European Parliament often gets carried away when discussing employment policy, and that is basically not wise.  Federal results and decisions lead to a more uniformity and do not take account of the differences between member states. More the EU does not necessarily create a better Europe. We are seeing it at a time when we are discussing, among other things, an EU minimum wage. Such a decision would, according to leading experts, destroy the Danish model in the field of employment. It should be the eu's policy to protect and defend the freedom and diversity of individual countries, not to unify. Employment policy is and should remain a national matter, not an EU matter.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. What else has to happen? Health crisis, economic crisis, social crisis, as in the last ten years, does not exist. A growing division of our society through crises, and we are still unable to do what the citizens want us to do. Two-thirds say that the EU needs more powers to deal with crises such as the Corona pandemic. 56% believe that the EU should have more financial resources to deal with the effects of the crisis. We still do not have the political majorities of the Heads of State or Government in order to develop the European Union as a Community into the Economic, Social, Educational, Research and Health Union. The two reports make it clear: yes, we need a political strategy to unite our key instruments – the European Green Deal, the European Pillar of Social Rights, the European Semester – into a powerful instrument. It is outrageous that six out of ten EU country-specific measures to the Member States are not being implemented by them, leaving EUR 45 billion a year on the table, which we urgently need for investment.  Ladies and gentlemen, let us change the switch! Let us ensure that we jointly promote the next project for the people – the Economic, Social and Health Union – in the interests of our common future.

name: Paolo Gentiloni
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the debate this morning reflects the deep crisis we’re in and the complexity of the relationship between the health dimension, the economic dimension, the social dimension and the environmental dimension. Indeed we need to address all these challenges knowing that in the coming weeks and months, we will have to push on facing an emergency and promoting recovery. There will not be a particular moment when the emergency finishes and recovery begins. They will go hand in hand for some time.  Yes, we need common rules – of course we need fiscal common rules – and I understand many interventions were on the Semester and on our common rules. Next year we will return to the discussion on the review of our fiscal rules which, as you know, was put on hold. It began in February but then the COVID-19 crisis hit and the discussion on the review of the rules was put on hold, but I’m sure that next year we will address it with a little more certainty, also from the economic perspective at that time. Meanwhile, I repeat that the general escape clause will remain, as should the supportive fiscal stance. It is important, I think, that in view of our future discussion, we now concentrate our efforts primarily on implementing what we have already decided, and I’m confident that the Commission and Parliament will work hand in hand in the coming weeks in taking the necessary legislative steps to have these instruments in place.  Finally, I think that the entire debate shows that it is urgent that we move on with an Action Plan on the European Pillar of Social Rights. The public consultation, as you know, is ongoing. It will last until the end of November and at the beginning of next year we will present our proposal as the Commission and the Portuguese Presidency will then convene a social summit. I think that the interest on the social dimension demonstrated by this debate is very important for the Commission.

name: Joachim SCHUSTER
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would just like to mention two things, both of which Mr Ferber mentioned. He said that the EPP has saved us from making debt, as he said in the press and saved us from a new debt trap. I think that is a very good support! The only thing that is ineffective is the criticism, because no one in the working group has asked for such a thing to be done, because that would also be pure nonsense.  We have only said that there are new realities, namely that the EU is in debt, that the debts of the Member States are rising properly and that we have new requirements that we cannot ignore. This requires that we also change our debt rules, and I am curious to see how the EPP argues that we want to maintain a 60% debt target. I am looking forward to this debate.  By the way, many members of the EPP have already realised that it is different. Above all, for example, Chancellor Merkel in Germany, who only rejected European debt at the beginning of the year, but has since endorsed and even proposed it, because she understood that the world has changed. The second thing is that there is a strange contrast between economic policy here and social and environmental policy on the other. At the same time, however, everyone is calling for sustainable growth. What is sustainable growth? Sustainable growth is socially and ecologically compatible. How can we actually achieve this if we do not take this into account in economic policy, what is socially acceptable and what is required from an environmental policy? This is where contradictions are built up that are absurd.  This can either only be understood in such a way that one has not yet understood it or that one actually does not care about sustainability in growth. However, this is extremely difficult from a competition point of view, because companies will only be competitive in future if they operate sustainably, otherwise there will be no competitiveness.  That is why I would like to conclude with a request to the members of the EPP: do not dig into the ideological trenches of the past, but get out. You can take the first steps today by supporting many of the proposals that Renew, the Greens and the S&D have made. I would be very pleased about that and would be a real step forward for our debate.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: I'm not going to do that - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support At the beginning of the debate, I said that I am sure that everyone here in this House wants a strong and successful European Union, and the debate has convinced me that I do, and thank you very much for your support from the various parties, from the factions and from the majority of the different parties. It has been said several times in the debate that the budget deficit, public debt, balance must take precedence. I would also like to reassure the doubters that we are all aware of our responsibility for the future, we are all aware of our responsibility for how the European Union manages. But let's look at what makes a country competitive, innovative, what makes the European Union competitive and innovative? From competitive and innovative people. And what makes people competitive and innovative? If they're smart, if they're healthy, and if they're balanced. This is the european Union's competitive advantage. If we keep doing everything the way we've been doing, we're going to be in trouble. While we have focused on the budget deficit in the last 10 years alone– with relative success – we have seen millions of European children missing out on quality education. How they become smart, competitive, innovative Europeans; I'm going to miss them. While we have focused on the budget deficit, we have allowed a number of Member States to take resources out of health care and today health care is not available to everyone on equal terms in many places, and now we are literally fighting a life-and-death battle against a new virus. How will the European people, who will be able to operate a smart, healthy, innovative and competitive economy in the future, be so smart and healthy? And when I say that we need balanced people, then while we have constantly turned our watchful gaze only and exclusively to the budget deficit, youth unemployment is skyrocketing, while worker poverty has increased over the last ten years and the gap between rich and poor in Europe has not decreased, but has increased. We did something wrong. And now is the opportunity to do something right, to set ourselves goals that are not only about improving economic indicators – and about it – but also about improving the lives of the people of Europe, because what is the point of running an economy well, if not so that people can live well, predictably and safely. Thank you for your support.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Wednesday 21 October 2020. I suspend the meeting until 13.30; the first item after the resumption of the meeting will be the announcement of the results of the first part of today's vote. Written declarations (Article 171 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Marek BELKA
text: in writing. – As has been proven up until now, throughout this mandate one of the topics that really splits this House are issues connected to macroeconomic and budgetary policies. Nevertheless, under the guidance of Joachim Schuster, we are debating a report that is balanced, emphasises the most important needs connected to further socio—economic support throughout the pandemic and puts pressure on deepening the Economic and Monetary Union. That being said, most of us would want to have a certain reform of the Stability and Growth Pact. We might differ in what is to be changed but, I presume, the majority of us wants and needs a change, as not everything is perfect. With the COVID—19 pandemic demolishing our economies, undermining our way of life hitherto and threatening the life and health of us and our loved ones, it is not the time for drama. We need to support this report despite some minor differences amongst the political groups. Only then we can be perceived by the Commission and Council as reliable partners in reforming the economic and social frameworks that have an everyday influence on us all. We cannot fail when it comes to this.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. In 1976, François Mitterrand predicted that "Europe will be socialist or not." Reading the report on social policies of the euro area 2020, it is downright the crassest communitarianism that now seems to guide the European project. Indeed, voted by an overwhelming majority in committee, the other major parties send us a clear message: social Europe has a price! It will be an ideological flattening in front of the communitarian extreme left.  Recently in the European texts, it has become impossible to talk about poverty without mentioning racism. It is no longer possible to talk about inequality without mentioning gender theories. Finally, it is no longer permissible to fight against wage insecurity without incensed the multiculturalist model.  The best example is the desire to establish a task force to combat stereotypes in the workplace. The European Union gives us a glimpse of the world it is concocting for us. A world where political correctness will police the office. Neither socialist nor communitarian: we want the Europe of nations!

name: Milan BRGLEZ
text: Writing. – The health crisis and the restrictive measures around it will undoubtedly also reflect the profound economic and social consequences that, as such, can be one of the European Union's greatest common challenges since its inception. According to the world bank's latest forecasts, tied mainly to data from the first wave of the coronavirus epidemic, between 88 and 115 million people will be further into poverty by 2021. In this context, it is necessary to stress that poverty is not only an economic category and also causes a number of other negative effects, both on people's physical and mental health and on their social security. This time, despite these already known facts, we are too early, because we are in the midst of another wave of epidemics, which, with its inappropriately increased scale and impact, will further deepen the economic and social crisis. However, it is difficult to discuss concrete EU measures to mitigate these consequences, given the fact that the negotiations on recovery and reconstruction funds and the Multiannual Financial Perspective are still not concluded. The collateral damage of the absence of this agreement is probably at this point also the European Commission's work programme for 2021, which has no attachments to deal with the social crisis, and at the same time more radical changes and a shift towards a more inclusive and more resilient society.

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "The situation around the world in 2020 is a surprise to everyone. We must face the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on every aspect of our lives, including social strategies for employment. This area has always required stability, peace and far-reaching planning in order to invest in human capital and professional activation of all social groups, from young workers to people of pre-retirement age. A sense of security, social security and health is essential for the development of employment.  Our economic and social systems now face the unprecedented challenge of ensuring a balance between economic stability and liquidity and ensuring security both before and before the pandemic. This is necessary both in each Member State and in the Community as a whole, particularly in the euro area. It is hoped that this report will highlight the role of the family, although it is palpable to seek and pressure the term 'family' itself, to be referred to as a household and a partnership.  I am pleased to stress that the ECR Group, through its compromise amendments, calls here for access to five key social rights for children: access to free healthcare and education, decent housing and adequate food. At the same time, there is concern about the emphasis on controversial issues such as the assessment of the rule of law and the effectiveness of justice to continue to be taken into account in the European Semester.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. – The report in this form is unacceptable. The report is a representative of a non-euro area Member State, which can be traced in the report: it is packed with promises that are not limited to the euro area Member States, and this is nonsense, because the report is specifically about the euro area. Moreover, these promises can be regarded as unsecured blank cheques, since there is no financial resources behind them, so the citizens would ultimately pay the price. We know well what led Hungary economic crisis in 2009: irresponsible social and economic policies, which this report seeks to repeat. I would now like to comment on the most contented point in the report, namely the issue of the minimum wage.  The Hungarian Government's commitment to protecting the interests of workers cannot be questioned. Since 2010, the minimum wage has been rising steadily. However, we believe that only Member States can set their minimum wages, taking into account their national policies and economic capabilities. It is very important that the minimum wage should be set in all countries in accordance with national traditions, respecting the autonomy of the social partners at national level and well-functioning collective bargaining models. I cannot support this report for a number of reasons: I do not accept the demand for progressive taxation because it is inefficient and leads to tax avoidance, and because taxation is a competence of the Member States and I do not agree that the rule of law framework should be examined within the framework of the European Semester.

name: Margarita DE LA PISA CARRIÓN
text: in writing. – The family is an institution present in all cultures because of the important role it plays; indeed, in the humanization of people, the family performs an irreplaceable function.  As the first and fundamental human society, the family holds natural and unique rights, and the cradle of social life and all the issues that concern it. It collaborates in an original and profound way in the construction of the world, making possible a life proper to human, in particular by guarding and transmitting virtues and values. Thus, she is called to be the protagonist of social coexistence, through the active participation of its members in society. It is therefore necessary to relaunch the family as a social institution that mediators between the individual and society, as a socializing, humanizing and educational element that promotes freedom and responsibility. This commitment should cover the different sectors of society; three of them, however, are particularly important: politics, economics and work.  It is incomprehensible that a report on social and employment policies should oed this natural institution, with a social vocation, such as the family.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: I am opening the second round of voting today. We voted on those dossiers that are on the agenda. The voting round is now open from 2.30 p.m. to 3.45 p.m. The well-known voting procedure is applied as in previous voting rounds. All votes are roll-call votes and I hereby declare the second round of voting open.  As has already been said, you have until 3.45 p.m. to vote. The results of this round of voting will be announced again from this location at 6.15 p.m.  We will resume the debate this afternoon at 3 p.m. with the statement by the Council and the Commission on the European Union's action to mitigate the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on society and the economy. Until then, I shall suspend the sitting. I ask you to exercise your right to vote. (The sitting was suspended at 2.32 p.m.)

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: – The next item is the Council and Commission statements on EU measures to mitigate the social and economic impact of the COVID-19 crisis (2020/2792(RSP)). I would like to inform you that no debate in this part-session provides for an in-house application procedure and no blue cards or requests for compliance with the Rules of Procedure will be accepted. Remote speeches from Parliament's contact offices in the Member States are foreseen.

name: Paolo Gentiloni
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, we all know that this crisis in eight months changed our world. We will measure its economic impact for the EU with our autumn forecast in a couple of weeks. The last forecasts released a few hours ago by the IMF states that the negative growth for the euro area will be in 2020 of minus 8.3. Just to compare, we had a negative growth of minus 4.1 in 2009, so during the financial crisis it was less than half the crisis that we could have according to this forecast in 2020. The social consequences will be deep and leave scars. Poverty increase according to the World Bank will be, in the world, around 120-140 million and this could put at risk the efforts to eradicate poverty that were done in the last 30 years. And the social consequences will be deep also in our Union, well beyond the numbers of increased unemployment rates because we know that, yes we have an increase of unemployment rates, but we have increasing gender gap, we have difficult situations for precarious jobs and for children, less educated, so we have deep consequences all in all.  This unprecedented crisis triggered unprecedented reactions and several measures as you know were taken by the Union, beginning with the first decision in March of having much more flexible rules, both on the fiscal and on state aid, and then easing the use of remaining cohesion funds and then the decisions of several loans, including the SURE package in support of short-work schemes.  And then the big decision of Next Generation EU that the Commission proposed at the end of May and the Council adopted at the end of July, and is now under discussion with the Parliament. And these common tools are on top of national responses. I think we should be very well aware of this and on average these national responses amount to around 4.5% of GDP in the Union, and together Member States’ reaction and common reaction makes our stimulus packages comparable and in some case even stronger to those of other global players.  But uncertainty is still there. It is not decreasing. It is may be growing uncertainty in the last weeks, for sure we will not have a so-called V-shaped recovery. We will have to coexist with the virus for a certain amount of time and we have to be very clear in the effort to avoid a double dip recession, keeping supportive fiscal stance and confirming as we did, as Commission, our general escape clause for next year. So now at stake is the implementation and the quality of our decisions. As far as the RRF is concerned, we have to find the right balance between the national ownership, which is fundamental in this initiative – we are not writing memorandum here in Brussels for these plans – and the common priorities and the country-specific recommendation. The balance will be key if we want to have a good result with this Recovery and Resilience Facility.  Our goal in general and in conclusion is to transform our economy in these terrible and difficult crisis, as always happens with crises. Should we be able to have a more sustainable, more competitive, more resilient? Should we be able to mitigate the social consequences of this crisis, and to strengthen the social pillar of our economy? I think that the Commission and this Parliament have not an easy task. It is an enormous responsibility but it is also the unique opportunity to contribute to better economies and better societies in Europe.

name: Heléne FRITZON
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I would like to begin by thanking Commissioner Gentiloni for the introduction. Covid-19 has put both economic and social pressures at risk. Various measures have been taken, both within the EU and, above all, in our Member States. But much work remains to be done. Especially now that the pandemic has unfortunately taken off in many places in Europe.  For me, as a Social Democrat, it is important that the recovery is based on measures that include everyone, regardless of background, and the solutions must be forward-looking. We're going to build a new green economy, not go back to the old one. It is about strengthening social Europe. Today we have an imbalance between people's chances of a good life, both within the EUROPEAN Union and between the Member States. We know that equality brings high benefits for social development, health and the economy. So we have everything to gain from having common ambitions.  We must therefore, as the Commissioner expresses, raise our ambitions in the work on the social pillar. It is a more social and equal Europe, and in order to achieve this, we must seize the opportunities of the European internal market, promote job creation, increase investment, make the transition to the digital society and, above all, make the transition to the climate change. We need a new long-term strategic agenda within the EUROPEAN Union, with concrete objectives and commitments. And in this way we can increase our ambitions and set out the way for a more equal Union for greater justice. We all benefit from this, and not least our citizens in Europe.

name: Sylvie BRUNET
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I am happy to speak from Marseille. I wanted to stress that, in the face of this unprecedented health crisis, the Union has reacted quickly. From the outset and within its competences, it has tried to counter the economic and social consequences of COVID-19. Firstly, with the adoption of emergency instruments such as SURE, in support of partial unemployment schemes, then REACT-EU or the rapid adaptation of aid to the poorest. Secondly, the European Union reacted with the presentation of important stimulus tools. Europe is here! I call for the recovery plan to have a strong green and social component by devoting a significant part to environmental objectives and the implementation of the principles of the European social rights base. For my conviction is that there will be no economic recovery and exit from the crisis without the deployment of social measures. I repeat this because I am beyond certain reluctance and the systematic referral to the competences of the Member States alone. Social is horizontal; social is cross-cutting. I would like to emphasize four points. Firstly, some of the resources available through REACT-EU must be directed towards combating the rise of the invisible, the great poverty and the precarious, through the FEAD and the ESF. Secondly, we need, of course, an ambitious multi-year budget, with an ESF that meets the needs and new own resources. Thirdly, investments in digital and green transitions must include powerful components of training and retraining of workers, especially young people, with all the instruments we have: the Fair Transition Fund, the Youth Guarantee, the new skills strategy. Fourthly, the crisis has urgently highlighted some shortcomings in European policy. I am thinking of the Europe of health, of course, which needs to be strengthened, but also of the fact that we need to deploy two new directives in the work of social Europe: one to introduce fair minimum wages in each country of the European Union, the other to guarantee better working conditions and stronger social rights for platform workers.

name: Jörg MEUTHEN
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very Today we are talking about the EU's ability to mitigate the social and economic consequences of the COVID-19 crisis. Such a request comes from a superficial view supposedly noble. But the question that needs to be asked here is this: why should this task be a task for the EU in the first place?  Firstly, the social and economic consequences of the COVID-19 crisis vary widely from one Member State to another. Secondly, and more importantly, social policy is not the eu's job at all, but social policy is a national task, and that is where it belongs. Each state must and can give its own response to the social challenges. What you are actually doing here is quite another matter and, if I may say so, it is blatantly contrary to national sovereignty. You are acting as a generous savior here, only to gain control over further funding and thus to expand your own power. In this way, you are only striving to pave the way to the EU's statehood, using the COVID-19 crisis in a targeted manner.  But the problems of this crisis must and can also be solved by and in the nation states themselves. If the Member States take different measures, that is a good thing. Competition for the best solution is always better than a false centralised strategy for all. You can see your wrong approach by setting up an almost gigantic EUR 750 billion recovery fund without even a single word being said about what exactly is to be done with these EUR 750 billion. All this, in order to finance a reconstruction that is neither your task nor, despite all your Cassandra calls, will actually be necessary in this dimension.  You are in the process of opening another chapter in the history of the decline of your presumption of power. Let me say this to you once again quite unequivocally: social policy is not the task of the EU. This task arises only in the nation states.

name: Monika VANA
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which I very much welcome the opportunity to address you in plenary today directly from Vienna.  We in Europe are facing more than 200 000 corona deaths, 5 million corona cases, 15 million unemployed and countless people on short-time work. Europe's citizens look to us, to the European institutions, and whether and how we manage the crises – crises in the majority. This is an economic crisis, a social and distribution crisis and a climate crisis. The European Parliament has repeatedly made it clear in recent months that there are large European majorities for a more social Europe, a Europe in which we share the costs of crises in solidarity and support each other. So we now need to invest heavily out of these crises. And our actions should also focus on the victims of the crises and those who carry us through these crises on a daily basis – including women, for example. There is therefore an urgent need for a European care deal and massive investment in health, care and public services – as this crisis has shown. And if we want to combat rising poverty effectively, we must quickly launch a social-policy offensive, which must go far beyond short-term measures– for example, on short-time working. That would be, for example, European unemployment reinsurance, that would be a Europe-wide minimum wage and that would be an initiative on minimum security. I warmly welcome the Council's agreement on a framework for a minimum European guarantee – a minimum income. And we hope that the European Commission will also come forward with proposals quickly.  However, the climate crisis also requires us to set clear the course for green jobs, and I want – and I believe this together – that we should use the Covid 19 crisis as an opportunity to promote European integration and the transformation of our economy.

name: Beata SZYDŁO
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Firstly, solidarity, secondly, solidarity and, thirdly, solidarity. Today, this word should guide us in our actions and in all these projects, the ambitious goals that we set ourselves, both in terms of protecting the health of Europeans and defending jobs and supporting the economy.  Those actions that have already been taken should be assessed positively. Among other things, the European Instrument for Reconstruction is a good tool that supports Europeans at this difficult time. But we should continue to work on preparing and carrying out precisely such projects, such plans, which will take into account the solidarity and justice that I have already mentioned.  The actions taken must take account of national problems. For example, the reduction of the CO2 target, the reduction of CO2 by 2030 to 60%, which is currently being pushed into the climate transition, will, among other things, hit my country's economy. So it is worth considering whether we should not work at this point, develop such forms of support and prepare projects that will support us all, the whole of Europe, in dealing with this very difficult moment for us.

name: Sira REGO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, for years, those of you who ruled the EU have told us that Europe had a strong economic and social model that could do anything. However, a fortnight of pandemic has sufficed to highlight our weakness. Fortunately, on this occasion we have been able to push forward an agreement for the essential Recovery Fund, which can be fairly distributed or can benefit them again.  Why do we say this? Because Europe is a place of enormous asymmetry and there are usually a few who benefit from public resources.  This is particularly serious in sectors such as industry, where we often see relocations that have taken advantage of subsidies, condemned thousands of workers to unemployment, and left us with no capacity to produce what we need. An example of this, here in Spain: Alcoa.  However, we believe that the crisis can be an opportunity to change things. The pandemic has shown that only public control guarantees the well-being of all. That is why we need an industry subject to public control and planning and, of course, that responds to the challenges of the climate emergency and creates quality jobs.  That is why, Mr Gentiloni, I take advantage of my speech to, in these days when the future of Airbus' staff is being negotiated, to ask us to focus on what is important and to make an effort to ensure that the exit from this crisis defends strategic sectors such as aerospace.  We strongly support workers who create true wealth in Europe. Let us make an effort to demand that European funds serve to shield quality employment and the future of our people.

name: Daniela RONDINELLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Commissioner Gentiloni for his speeches today. Last July, we welcomed the recovery plan as a new beginning for Europe, but a few months later some States are once again blocking the budget negotiations, and this is serious because it marks a very strong distance from citizens and businesses. In fact, with each passing day, the billions of Next Generation EU become less and less than those needed to revive employment and production. Strategic programmes such as Horizon and the Social Fund are in danger of being cut.  Yesterday sure's reception was extraordinary on the financial markets, but there is still no clarity on cross compliance. The directive on the minimum wage, which was to be launched in the first hundred days, has been postponed yet another time. The Youth Guarantee will not be that binding, universal and permanent measure that many young people could have counted on.  Finally, we are still a long way from deciding how to proceed with the revision of the Stability Pact – that is just a few hours ago – even the European Fiscal Board has supported its overshoot. We in the 5 Star Movement were crucial a year ago to elect this Commission, just as the Italian Government contributed to a decisive change of course in the European Council. So let us stress the need for action quickly and well. It is time to dare and do so now, because any further delay causes enormous economic and social damage.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: - Madam President, dear Colleagues, From the point of view of citizens and Member States alike, the pandemic crisis is the most serious. It is unpredictable, not just economic, social and health challenges. Member States considered it important, because of the epidemic, that as few people as possible lose their jobs and that if they did lose, they would be supported for this transitional period and be able to find a job sooner. I would like to talk about what we are doing in Hungary to do this. In addition to old jobs, new jobs need to be created, flexible working hours, greater monitoring of a healthy working environment, the possibility of unilaterally ordering work from home and teleworking. At the same time, 904 companies applied for investments under job-preserving measures, such as the competitiveness programme launched by the Hungarian Government.  The total value of this exceeds HUF 400 billion. This has managed to preserve 154 000 jobs. Traditional grants have helped 200,000 people, or 354,000 people overall. The Union's role in dealing with the crisis caused by the coronavirus has become secondary to citizens because of its belated and slow process. We can only improve this if we act quickly, effectively, in the interests of the Member States and citizens. Thank you for your attention.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, the European Commission and the European Parliament have been swift. We were quick to mobilise the resources that we still had available within the European Union budget. We have made flexibility to Member States to use the funds, we have made the possibility of using 100 co-financing, we have eliminated barriers such as State aid, we have strengthened the civil protection mechanism. We recently gave the European Commission permission in this Plenary to buy 1,100 million euros of doses of vaccines, 300 million doses as soon as they are available, with the possibility of going up to 400 million. We acted quickly, and what did the Council do? Don't we need a vaccine? What does the Council do? It reduces research, reduces horizon Europe.  Do we not need to strengthen a European health programme? Need. What does the Council do? It cuts the European health programme. We need what strategic and critical investments are for the European Union. What does the Council do? It cuts funding at InvestEU, which allows for these same strategic investments. There is talk of the geopolitical Europe, which we support, the autonomy of the European Union, and then we are talking about what made it possible to create industries for the production of medicines, in a structured way, an industry that would enable fans to exist. What's more, and to finish: the Recovery Fund is urgent.  In this very House, in this Parliament, we approve our opinion which allows the European Commission to go to the markets. What did the Council do? You haven't decided since September 16th. What's the council waiting for? It is urgent to decide and move on to the Recovery Fund.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Madam President, the coronavirus pandemic is an unprecedented emergency affecting all the Member States of the European Union. But it is not enough to say so; it must be reflected practically in our measures and policies to address it. We are now experiencing the second wave of the pandemic, with an even greater economic and social impact, which goes beyond the sector of the economy. Workers, households, businesses, vulnerable groups, women, children, education, culture and more have been affected and need our support immediately. However, with some delay, my dear colleague, initially, the European Union has announced substantial and ambitious proposals to deal with the effects of the pandemic, as the Commission and the European Council have said. For example, a pan-European minimum wage as a minimum measure to protect workers. However, in order for the measures to be effective, they must be implemented immediately and without conditions which make these proposals impossible. This means in practice 'mitigating the economic and social impact' in the face of this unprecedented and exceptional situation, and creating resilient economies and social systems through investment — particularly in public health.  The attempt to exploit the pandemic to impose small memoranda on the Member States is rejected. The role of the European Central Bank is equally important and decisive for the real economy. The role of the European Parliament in tackling the pandemic must be upgraded as long as we represent European citizens.  Finally, Mr President, this pandemic has highlighted another point: what has been agreed must be respected, even if some strong Member States do not agree. If there were a pan-European deposit guarantee, today we would have very expanded capabilities and tools in our hands.

name: Luis GARICANO
text: – Madam President, just as there is consensus among virologists to restrict our individual freedoms and try to limit the progress of the pandemic, there is also consensus among economists that governments need to increase their scope and spend a lot of money now, in a timely manner, in order to prevent the economy from collapse during a time as complicated as the current one. That is why, from Europe, we have agreed on this 750 billion euro Recovery Fund, which will allow all countries to have a cushion and aid in getting their economies recovered and rebuilt in the best possible way.  This means that governments have much greater room for manoeuvre than without it, but this same opportunity also has obvious risks. We must prevent governments from using this European money to build new like-minded elites, to build client networks that, among all, can be perpetuated in power. This money , the European funds - must by no means be the money that finances a long election campaign to any government.  That is why it is so important that now that we are negotiating the Recovery and Resilience Mechanism Regulation with governments and groups within the European Parliament, let us put in clear and demanding rules to ensure that money is used for the good of Europeans, that we put those controls that ensure that it is not used to build these client networks or to make that long election campaign.  The prestige and future of the European Union also depend on this money being spent well. If we don't, five or six years from now people will see it as a failed experiment and we will never see this solidarity between Europeans again.

name: Peter KOFOD
text: Madam. President! Basically, the debate is about securing growth and jobs in Europe in the wake of the covid crisis. I do not have the impression that the European Union is acting positively in the current situation in which we are currently in office. In Denmark, we have companies that cannot benefit from the government's and the Folketing's aid packages because the EU system does not act in time and approves. This is absolutely absurd, and in the meantime we are talking about what the European Union can do, but let me give you the answer: the European Union can get started and give our own countries the opportunity to spend our own money on helping our own citizens and businesses, that would be very helpful. It is my clear impression that the European Union is more of a problem than an active asset in the crisis we are now in.

name: François ALFONSI
text: Madam President, the economic and health crisis following the COVID-19 crisis is a profound and lasting crisis. The epidemic rebound seen these days confirms that its consequences will be spread over time and that the peak of the economic crisis is still to come. We also know that the health crisis, like the economic crisis, has a very different impact on the territories. I also want to stress the particular situation of the island spaces, which are the most vulnerable to this crisis. This vulnerability stems from the proportionately strong place of tourism in their economies. It is also due to the fact that the islands are highly dependent on supply chains, which are themselves weakened by the fall in tourism-related revenues. For both shipping lines and airlines, for example. These sectors are the most impacted and the collapse of the players in place would mechanically generate the collapse of trade and thus an even greater economic shock. Europe must therefore pay particular attention to the impact of the past and future economic crisis in the islands and the various stimulus tools must provide for specific means to be applied and the usual rules on state aid to be eased there, as soon as a vital economic link is threatened there.

name: Joanna KOPCIŃSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab At a difficult time of the pandemic, we should support all those who need it most in solidarity. I therefore support the efforts to make cohesion policy more flexible, i.e. the CRII and CRII+ initiatives, which have so far mobilised EUR 13 billion in investment to counter the effects of the coronavirus pandemic by simplifying the procedures for implementing the programme. This is unprecedented because of the situation caused by the COVID-19 epidemic, but we need more sustainable changes, such as a smooth revision of the Regulation on common rules for the European Fund for Aid to the Most Deprived.  And let us all take this simplest step in the form of protecting those who risk their lives fighting the virus. I therefore call for responsibility, adherence to the principle of 'distance, disinfection, mask' and adaptation of the intensity of contacts to the epidemiological situation. Let us not hinder the already difficult work of doctors, nurses and paramedics who face the virus every day.

name: Nikolaj VILLUMSEN
text: Madam. President! We need a significant change in the EU's policy to date. We are in the midst of three serious crises: a global pandemic that has cost millions of victims, an economic crisis that means millions have lost their jobs, and a climate crisis that requires urgent action if climate change is not to get completely out of control.  We need an ambitious and socially just green transition, so that we boost the economy and create green jobs. We need to put an effective end to shady tax havens so that we force multinationals to contribute to the common well-being. This requires us to stop black agricultural subsidies and invest in green conversion. This requires us to slam the EU coffers in for farmers and businesses that do not respect collective agreements and the right to professional organisation. This requires us to blacklist all tax havens so that neither Luxembourg nor Cayman Island go free. Ladies and gentlemen, we need green and solidarity action.

name: Antoni COMÍN I OLIVERES
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the European Commission has a great responsibility, which is to establish the most objective and clear criteria possible to help states decide what measures to take against Covid at all times. Unfortunately, it did not, even though we asked at the beginning of the pandemic. Criteria based on reliable and transparent scientific indicators and data: infection rate, number of positives, regrowth indicators, employment rate in intensive care, when and how to lockdown, when to close bars and restaurants, if a curfew needs to be established. These decisions have serious consequences for everyone's health, life, freedom and economy, and we must not politicise these decisions, we cannot make them the subject of a partisan battle, as is happening in Spain.  There the management of Covid has become a political field battle, followed with outrage by the rest of the countries of the Union. Why is Spanish politics so difficult to manage this crisis as mature, responsible and intelligent as so many other EU countries are doing? Does the fact that Spain's GDP has the strongest fall forecasts in the whole of the Union have anything to do with this? It is true that the Spanish economy is heavily dependent on tourism, but the Italian economy is also heavily dependent. And now the difference between Spain and Italy, both from an economic and health point of view, is significant. Some learn from the past and others seem to repeat themselves in their mistakes.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I believe that the European Union, as a community, has learned a lot during the pandemic. The beginnings were very difficult. The seriousness of the situation and the rate of spread of the virus surprised us all. Nevertheless, we started to work together very quickly. Extraordinary measures have been taken. In difficult circumstances and at an express pace, we have decided to maximise budgetary flexibility and to provide support to Member States on an unprecedented scale. So we have as a result a number of instruments that are already in place.  Unfortunately, at the moment we cannot fully address the recovery from the crisis and the effects of COVID-19, because the pandemic is still going on. The whole of Europe is currently facing a second wave of infections. Further restrictions are being introduced in social and economic life. Therefore, the principle of cooperation and flexibility should continue to be and remain the most important for us. The Union must respond on an ongoing basis by directing assistance where it is most needed, because not everywhere and not every social group faces similar problems.  Like many other crises, this one also carries a huge risk of increasing inequality. We must ensure that no one is left behind. It is extremely important to support companies, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, in order to prevent mass layoffs and increased unemployment. We should also support sustainable and long-term investment, for example in the high-tech sector, which will help the Union return to growth. However, social aspects are equally important, such as the systemic strengthening of the care of seniorcitizens who are at particular risk.

name: Estrella DURÁ FERRANDIS
text: – Madam President, my message is this: we will not achieve a real recovery and a socially sustainable Europe without measures adapted to the tragic situation we are experiencing that will face its consequences not only economic but also social.  That is why we need to invest in measures and funds of permanent recovery, governed by indicators, within the European Semester, that guarantee investment in welfare and social protection systems, putting in place the principles of the social pillar.  Only with a multiannual financial framework and an ambitious recovery fund focused equally, both on economic growth aspects and on social goals, can we move towards a truly sustainable Europe that invests in what really matters: people.  The COVID-19 crisis is affecting our health, decent living conditions and, above all, employment. That is why we also need a commitment from all social actors and businesses to commit themselves to maintaining economic activity and employment in return for the aid they receive, avoiding business relocation processes that lead to mass redundancies.  The idea is very simple: a socially sustainable Europe is synonymous with investment in public social welfare systems. The welfare state, like the rule of law, is an identity sign of our European Union, and we must continue to bet on it.

name: Monica SEMEDO
text: – Madam President, looking around us, the room is mainly empty. We can see that the pandemic is far from over. In fact, it is gaining strength. While we are anxiously waiting for a vaccine, the situation for citizens and businesses is becoming more and more serious. Youth unemployment has soared, businesses are struggling – many won’t be able to survive the second wave – and the most deprived need our help more than ever.  A recent survey in Luxembourg found that almost 60% of people who needed help were below the age of 40 and 39% were single parents. This House passed a resolution in April which addressed these problems. We must live up to that resolution. We need to maintain jobs and provide liquidity to enterprises, especially SMEs. We need to help the most deprived. We must support all of them and provide help quickly. The European Parliament is standing up for citizens but I say to the Council and the Commission: you hold the power to act. You must step up and show how strong our Union can be.

name: Paolo BORCHIA
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, let us be honest, on 11 March the WHO declared a state of pandemic, but after seven months of tangible results we still have too few of them compared to the expectations generated by too many announcements. The April European Council allocated EUR 540 billion – hurrah for SURE – but the ESA 240 billion was not requested by any government, perhaps because the conditions were not really so advantageous. It was also laborious to reach agreement on the recovery fund, the long delays of which were blamed in a grotesque, uncredible way even, on those who did not even sit in the European Council or the Eurogroup. Only two days ago, the newspaper El País revealed that the Government of Madrid does not intend to use the loan component of the recovery fund. Some people were surprised, but on this side of the House we have tried several times to explain to you that the instruments that have been under discussion for months probably present it. The European Union – I will end, Mr President – is very extensive, when priorities are imposed from above, from Brussels to the territories, these are the consequences.

name: Ciarán CUFFE
text: – Madam President, here in Ireland we’re entering six weeks of Level 5 restrictions, the highest level of restrictions that we have. It’s a difficult time for so many in the midst of this global health crisis. We’ve already seen substantial job losses, particularly in the aviation industry, but also in retail, hospitality and tourism. We’ve seen this crisis have a huge impact on young people, on older people, on carers, and on everyone’s mental health. Many people have had to transition, particularly the young – those in education – from learning in schools and universities to listening to online studies at one point or even now during the pandemic.  But we can’t let this crisis go to waste. We need to ramp up public investment and we need to help ensure people’s livelihoods are protected and fund a transition towards a fairer and greener socio-economic model in recovery. We cannot respond to the crisis by returning to business as usual.

name: Helmut GEUKING
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her One thing is obvious: the victims of this COVID-19 crisis and this economic and financial crisis are the families in each country. Families have to take advantage of the crisis, and they need to be strengthened.  That is why, in my speech earlier, I argued that we must finally introduce this child benefit, so that we can get the millions of children out of child poverty and strengthen families. This is the best economic policy, because families need the money and they spend that money and run it into the money cycle. This means a much higher tax income in each country, that is, increasing productivity, safeguarding jobs and creating new jobs. That is why we need to give people the money directly – and that is social and that is modern economic policy.  And – I have only sixteen seconds – very briefly to Mr Meuthen, who is unfortunately no longer there. I am happy to give you the answers: because we are making a human policy – unlike you – and because we are making a policy where we focus on people and Europe has a certain view of values. We are a social, humane Europe for the people and not ice-cold and with backward-looking policies, but we are making a modern, forward-looking policy – just in response.

name: Marc BOTENGA
text: Mr President, Commissioner, if a cleaner has to be quarantined in the near future, she will lose her job or part of her salary. I know it's hard to imagine that. Because if you have to go into quarantine, you just keep your 20 000 euro salary. But this virus is a real class virus and the working class is hit much harder than the millionaire class. The working class can't retire to an estate. It has to go into the workplace, it has to be done by public transport and it risks pay and a job. While shareholders continue to receive dividends, ordinary workers lose their jobs. That's the reality! And what kind of programme will the European Union come up with? Especially with hundreds of billions for big business. For this, large companies do not even have to pay fair tax or stop paying dividends. You don't have to do any of that. Even securing jobs is not a condition. You can't do that! Free on the drip, while the common man loses his job! No, that is really unacceptable to us. I would suggest you reverse that logic. Instead of giving taxpayers' money to big business for free, let us do the opposite. Let us make contributions to the very richest, the millionaires, and then let us invest that money in public services and our public sector. That benefits us all. I think that's a much better deal for our entire society, both socially and ecologically.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Mr President, the corona crisis is, of course, first and foremost, a health crisis, but a health crisis with major social and economic consequences. Many general issues have already been raised, so let me mention a specific case, an issue that should certainly affect us in this Parliament. I mentioned the situation of border operators here five months ago. Border operators have also been hit hard in this crisis. I am thinking of entrepreneurs with, for example, a company in the Netherlands, who pay tax in the Netherlands and pay social charges in the Netherlands. But those who, because they live in another country, in this case often Belgium or Germany, are not eligible for Dutch support. For many of them, it is becoming increasingly difficult to keep their heads above water. I had hoped that this situation would be resolved by five months later, but the opposite is true: the Dutch Secretary of State stubbornly insists that the Tozo scheme (temporary bridging scheme for self-employed persons) is an assistance scheme and therefore does not need to be exported. It is therefore logical that these people look to Europe for help. Because the only reason they are not getting this support is because they are using their treaty rights in the area of free movement, treaty rights for which we must ensure that they are guaranteed. I was therefore very pleased that the European Commission, in response to my question, made it very clear that the Netherlands was wrong. That there are elements of social security in this scheme and that these people should therefore be able to be helped. It has not changed the attitude of the Netherlands and the Secretary of State and the border entrepreneurs are still out in the cold! I have therefore lodged with you, with a large number of them, additional complaints with the European Commission. I would therefore like to call on you, Commissioner, today: look carefully at these complaints, read the harrowing stories of these entrepreneurs and help us take steps to ensure that these people are still helped.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: – Madam President, I think it is right to recognise that we are, first of all, facing a health crisis with a deep recession in which economic policy can barely put cotton. And until certain health treatment is available, until we can clear up the fears and uncertainties that our societies have hit our societies from an exclusively health point, it will be difficult to think of an economic policy other than supporting spending, supporting investment from the public sector. I believe that it is important to strengthen expansive fiscal policy - and I hope that the Next Generation EU will help this – and also support monetary policy activities.  Because I would also like to remind you that inflation is still in the euro area on negative ground and we are still a long way from that 2% target. Therefore, there is scope to implement greater fiscal policy, but also greater monetary policy. And when the health crisis begins to subside and we begin to see some certainty about the future—and we all hope it will be sooner sooner without later—we must recognize that this crisis will leave deep scars on our societies, on a few generations, the youngest, that they will have suffered two crises in just a decade. And that will be the case, it will be at that time, when we have to build, we have to finance, we must give future to that European pillar of social rights that needs support, a very clear commitment on the part of these institutions.

name: Maxette PIRBAKAS
text: Madam President, I will discuss with you today the situation in the five French overseas departments. For the past seven years of health, social and economic crisis, I have been fighting for a major economic recovery plan that is favourable to the Overseas Sea. The survival of our ultramarine territories is at stake. As a Guadeloupean, I say to you: our insularity and our remoteness penalize us even more in this COVID crisis—19. Tourism, agriculture, fishing and handicrafts are economic pillars that are under threat and which, under Article 349 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, should benefit from aid in normal times, in addition to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in this time of crisis. We must also remember that our hospital system lacks resources, that THE budget of POSEI is threatened to fall by 3.9%, that administrative simplification is still not effective. All these elements need to be resolved, and now! Colleagues, it is high time that every aid to the Overseas is kept to the euro close. It is even more necessary than usual to accompany our five overseas departments, Guadeloupe, Martinique, Reunion, Guyana and Mayotte, during this crisis, in order to revive their economy in order to avoid the bankruptcy of many businesses and businesses.

name: Mikuláš PEKSA
text: – Madam President, the pandemic has proven two things. Most importantly, it showed us how much we are interconnected and depend on each other. If we suffer or prosper, we are in it together. However, it also showed us how disorganised and weak we are in the face of new challenges. Member States closing borders without coordination, applying different travel conditions, providing contradictory information, and competing for supplies among themselves look like complete chaos, a dangerous chaos with human lives at stake.  We need a coordinated European response. We need stronger rule of law conditionalities, and we need to move the health competencies from national to central EU level, with the backing of a stronger European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control. Only by acting together will we overcome this pandemic.

name: Carlo FIDANZA
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we are in the midst of a second wave of covid that is widely predicted, yet most European nations seem to have found ourselves unprepared. It is true that the Eu ropean Union is now working on the vaccine, it has given itself common practices on travel restrictions, it should be able to avoid new blockades in the internal market, it has achieved greater health coordination, even if it is still largely imperfect.  Yet it is seriously behind schedule for economic recovery, at a time when new restrictions are being introduced which are severely affecting many productive sectors. The so-called frugals use the rule of law instrumentally to block a plan that they never really wanted. It is also news these days that some countries, thanks to negative rates at the ECB umbrella, would prefer to finance themselves with national bonds and not with recovery fund loans, which further reduces the overall impact of the plan.  This makes it all the more urgent to remove instrumental vetoes and unblock negotiations immediately, because we need a share of transfers now to support our businesses before it is too late.

name: Vladimír BILČÍK
text: – Madam President, slowly all of us know a person who is suffering from a disease that has radically changed our lives for all of us in recent months. I would therefore also like to reassure you from this place that it is our sincere interest to help wherever we know.  I am glad to see and meet every day examples of bravery, help and resilience. Among medical staff, supply workers, shops, offices. Thank you very much for your work.  It is precisely in a crisis like this that it is important that we join forces and look for a solution that will help us and not break us down and destroy us even more as a society.  That is why, during the pandemic, we need responsible politicians looking beyond the horizon of the next few hours. I am therefore concerned at the recklessness with which border closures are being talked about. Schengen and the border is not only a 'holiday trip', it is also a free and free area of mutual trade and shared prosperity. The Schengen area is both our freedom and our prosperity. Let's protect him.  And let us not be afraid to appreciate the work where the award demands it. At a time when we are watching how many European governments are experiencing major problems in preparing aid programmes, let us say that this situation is new and we also need a little generosity towards Europe and European solutions. It is in our interest to resolve this unprecedented corona crisis as best we can, and therefore a great deal of thanks and somewhat admiration also belong to the institutions of the European Union, for the speed with which they have proposed functional aid and support programmes. We also need cooperation in the areas of health, science and research, a European Health Union, yes, which will help us all to respond better to public health crises. This is a necessary and correct path. A road that can save lives.   Ladies and gentlemen, we will only manage the crisis with honest political answers and honest communication. We will overcome the economic and social consequences of the virus all the better, the more we will heed the facts, proven knowledge and solutions that offer hope and a plan for better conditions after the pandemic. This must be the case for us in Brussels and across Europe, especially in the coming months.

name: Gabriele BISCHOFF
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We also see from the contributions that this is one of the most serious crises that the European Union has experienced so far, and I fear that the worst is yet to come. The fear of poverty and social decline is growing, and with it insecurity. We see that COVID—19 is a fire accelerator of poverty. It is therefore right that Commissioner Gentiloni has pointed out the importance of solidarity-based solutions such as SURE.  But short-time working does not cover certain categories of employees, and this is where we must act. And these are in particular the precarious workers, the artists, the small self-employed and, in particular, a group: the young people. We know how important adolescence is for the entire phase of life, for the course of life. And we see that young people are slowed down in a central phase and then also blamed for the infection. We need real perspectives. This must be more than just the Youth Guarantee.  And we note that we have a wave of restructuring in Europe. Companies that use the crisis to cut or relocate jobs, disregarding existing workers' rights to information and consultation. We need stronger rules here, and we need to act to ensure that the rights that exist for democracy in the workplace are actually enforced. There is more to be done here than the Commission has so far included in its work programme.

name: Joachim KUHS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Allow me to point out something fundamental: we are obviously terrified of an ominous number – the number of people who have tested positive for the coronavirus. Because this number is increasing exponentially, the competent authorities – rightly or wrongly, I will leave it quite free – are ordering far-reaching and freedom-restricting measures without, it seems to me, questioning whether the consequences of these measures are not much more serious.  We are suddenly afraid of numbers. In doing so, we should be afraid of God. Just as Jesus Christ said in Matthew 10 verse 28: "And do not be afraid of those who kill the body, but cannot kill the soul. Fear, however, the one who can spoil both the soul and the body."  Because we have lost our Christian foundation and true fear of God, we are now afraid of a virus. How embarrassing that is! Let us turn around, let us cease to be saviours in need, and we begin to give people back to life and true joy of life.

name: Dace MELBĀRDE
text: – Madam President, I will speak as a member of the Committee on Culture and Education. Since the outbreak of the COVID pandemic, much energy has been paid to the EU economies and labour markets as a whole, but often not to specific sectors and workers.  The culture and creative, as well as the media, sectors have been hit particularly hard, with dramatic income losses and a high rise of unemployment. Meanwhile, support for these sectors has been inadequate, both at national and EU level. Culture and media cannot simply be bailed out or resurrected after a failure, like other industries. It is deplorable that, during these times when media and culture is consumed more than ever, many of these organisations are struggling for survival.  That is why I reiterate the calls for a 2% earmarking of the Recovery and Resilience Facility to the cultural and creative sectors and the media. I strongly believe that a strong news media and well—financed culture must be at the heart of our democracies and the bedrock of the EU’s recovery.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: – Madam President, after a lockdown in the spring many activities were put on hold, companies lost their income and people lost their jobs. Actions are required, especially now. We see that many Member States are in a second lockdown, and that it’s being initiated.  All these socio—economic measures you talked about depend on a balance of competences at national and European level. I call on the Commission to increase its active monitoring and guidance. I ask the Council to uphold solidarity and Europe—wide coordination. Borders should stay open, internal markets should remain active, health risks should be tackled together.  Special attention should also go to those that are the hardest hit – research, health, the cultural sector, tourism and small and medium enterprises in general. The Croatian Government has announced additional measures to improve support for micro entrepreneurs, as together with small and medium enterprises, they form the backbone of our economy.  Safeguarding jobs, guaranteeing income and on top of that developing actions to limit the spread of the virus, this crisis requires a lot from us. Only with a genuine European approach we can assure social and economic recovery. We are in this together. No one can save themselves by themselves.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Madam President, I believe that it is indisputable that the Recovery Fund was and remains a great necessity in order to support the economies of the Member States and to be able to cope with this unprecedented and unprecedented pandemic that is sweeping everything in its wake. However, it is also a common admission that the Recovery Fund was decided on different facts and under different circumstances when the pandemic was at its beginning and no one could calculate and assess the enormous socio-economic impact and depth it would have. Therefore, I believe that today, given the current circumstances, we need to review our objectives and objectives. On the one hand, the Recovery Fund can become the economic recovery fund of the countries' economies and, on the other hand, it now needs, here and now, a new strong corresponding fund which can be called the 'social recovery fund'. This fund will immediately be able to channel money into the market for our unemployed, as there is a risk that the unemployment funds of all countries will collapse, for small and medium-sized enterprises, farmers, vulnerable groups, pensioners, the socio-economic whole. This is particularly important because the economic recovery fund (EUR 1.4 trillion) will take too long to bring money to market.  I come from a country, Cyprus, which is heavily dependent on tourism, as do other countries in the South. If these countries do not receive direct support for the tourism sector, I can assure you that in the coming years we may have tourism but we will not have tourism businesses because they will go bankrupt. It is therefore necessary to have the Social Development Fund in order to prevent bankruptcy and bankruptcy, not only of businesses but also of the economies of our countries.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her European measures to cushion the Corona pandemic must primarily benefit workers, young people and women. The rich should not get richer through the crisis.  We must not allow the financial injections to benefit only companies – without any conditions. Why am I saying this? As a cautionary example, I would like to mention the Austrian truck company MAN. MAN received huge amounts of taxpayers' money, EU support for reconstruction, and now the company is leaving, leaving 2,000 people in unemployment. This is not what solidarity reconstruction looks like! These 2 000 employees exemplify millions of working people who have lost their jobs or are now fearing for it. In addition, it is mostly women who are not only double and triple burdened, but are also the first to be dismissed. They are our heroines of this crisis.  Where exactly is your support nice? By investing in quality jobs, we can counteract this. More specifically, for example, by investing in social infrastructures, such as high-quality care and care from baby to old age. If only 2% of national GDP is invested in quality care, we can create up to 1.5 million jobs. 1.5 million! That is why we are now investing in this quality care work, we are investing in the future, in a wellbeing economy for all of us!

name: Karlo RESSLER
text: – A respected presidency, an unprecedented global pandemic and crisis are opening deep wounds for the whole of Europe, especially for the most vulnerable groups.  The social and economic consequences are again particularly felt by young people – just as, not so long ago, they were particularly affected by the financial crisis.  Mass unemployment meant millions at the time, especially young people not from Western or Northern Europe, marginalisation, low incomes, later independence and harder starting a family. Crises affect all generations, but for young people in formative years its consequences are deeper and last longer.   This autumn and winter, the priority must be to protect the human lives and health of vulnerable groups. Every life counts. Every life is priceless. Full intergenerational solidarity today, above all, means protecting the most vulnerable groups.  Health care, these are the elderly at this time. Economically and socially, these are due to the consequences of the crisis – without any doubt – young people.  That is why today we need a strong employment policy and therefore we must not allow new lost years, new lost dreams of a new generation of Europe.

name: Sunčana GLAVAK
text: Dear Chairman, in an unprecedented effort to deal with the effects of the global crisis caused by the coronavirus pandemic, we have adopted a historic and extraordinary package of measures for Europe's recovery at European and national levels in recent months. The European Union has programmed more than €65 billion for the resilience of health systems and the procurement of medical equipment. At that moment, great solidarity was shown.
