From the level of the Republic of Croatia and the Government of the Republic of Croatia, it also acted quickly and efficiently to support, first of all, the private sector, workers and employers in order to preserve jobs. Thanks to financial assistance from the European Union and active engagement of the Croatian government, Croatia recorded more than three thousand new insured persons compared to February this year. Croatia continues and actively work to mitigate the impact of the pandemic. Of course, with a lot of support from European funds. New measures for entrepreneurs were also unveiled yesterday, and by the end of the year their cost is projected to be around HRK 350 million (€47 million).  This pandemic is a huge challenge, but also an opportunity to transform and reduce differences in economic and social terms. The European Union is a complex mechanism, but it must take into account member states' priorities, connect closely and connect in the common interest. We have a time ahead of us where we have to think like chess, at least two moves ahead.

name: Paolo Gentiloni
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I think that in this debate it has become very clear how deep the crisis we are facing is and that the new measures and new restrictions that have been taken in these weeks in our Member States could further challenge the recovery. So this is my first point. The crisis is not behind us because this crisis is not like a war that finishes at a certain point and, with the end of the war, reconstruction begins. In this case, we will have a certain amount of time where emergency policies and recovery policy will go hand in hand. I think the awareness in the Parliament of the importance of a common reaction is very strong. I have to say that this common reaction came first of all from a sentiment of solidarity, which is a very good and European sentiment, but also from a common interest: the common interest to preserve the single market, because all we are seeing now shows that our concerns about the fact that this crisis could have uneven consequences among different sectors and Member States have been confirmed. So we are seeing that distances are there. Again, this common interest is not behind us. This is one of the reasons why we should continue to support the recovery with our fiscal policies in the next period. I think that several interventions mentioned the need to make the best possible use of the Recovery and Resilience Facility. What the Commission is committed to is finding the right balance because this is not a memorandum written in Brussels that we have to impose on Member States. These will be proposals coming from Member States and the Commission will work to make sure that these proposals are coherent with our common priorities and with countless specific recommendations, and not only linked to tactical or short-term goals.  But I repeat that the starting point will be national decisions, national governments and national parliaments. Several honourable Members rightly say that we need stronger coordination, but we all know — and you know better than me — that it’s always necessary to find the right balance between the demand for stronger coordination and the demand to preserve a national role. We are not a federal state. This could be a good thing or a bad thing, according to political and cultural points of view, but the fact is that we are not. So we have some sectors and some areas where the coordination is easier and others where it is more difficult. I think on this occasion we should go further in coordination, especially on health care safety measures, border coordination and the whole situation concerning travel, which is really very difficult among Member States. But of course this is an effort that the Commission can easily make, if Member States allow us. I appreciate the fact that I understand Parliament is strongly advocating for this stronger coordination.  Several honourable Members took the floor on social issues and our social model. I think that overall in this crisis our social model showed its difficulties, but also its strengths. I think we can be proud of our social model if we compare the social consequences of this crisis in other parts of the world where we don’t have social services or even where we have authoritarian models in government.  In my view, the European social model confirms its strength, but of course we have to reinforce it. We have to confirm the commitment to make the social pillar crucial in our semester. We have to be aware that the crisis is increasing social inequalities and that we have winners and losers. We have winners from this crisis, not only rich people in general, but also sectors of our global economy. For example, the digital global platforms are winners in this crisis. We will speak about this when we speak about digital taxation, own resources, etc. but, for sure, they are the winners in this crisis and other sectors that were mentioned here — culture, entertainment, travel, tourism, SMEs, and I am sure that I am forgetting something — are the losers in this crisis. This means that they will need support for a longer time than others. We can’t change and phase out the support in these sectors too soon.  Finally, I think that there is broad consensus on the fact that our goal, the goal of this unprecedented common response, is not only to revive our economies and go back to where we were at the end of 2019. We are all aware of the difficulties and some of them were mentioned here. Climate transition is not easy in many countries, but we are also aware of the tremendous responsibility that we have during this crisis to seize the opportunity to change our societies and our economies for the better.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: – I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 171 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Adam BIELAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The crisis caused by the Covid-19 pandemic has huge economic, social and geopolitical consequences. I am pleased that the Commission has decided to maximise budgetary flexibility and to provide support to Member States on an unprecedented scale. Increased coordination in order to avoid new roadblocks in the internal market and in the field of health are further positive developments. However, the situation in Europe has deteriorated again in recent days. Further restrictions are being introduced in social and economic life. In order to prevent further pandemic effects, swift action is therefore needed. I therefore call on the Representatives of the Commission, Parliament and the Council to reach an agreement on the eu's multiannual budget as soon as possible and to follow the principles of cooperation, solidarity and flexibility. It is extremely important to support small and medium-sized enterprises in order to prevent mass layoffs and increased unemployment, as any fluctuations in this area affect the internal market as a whole. By finalising the budget negotiations, we will be able to support our European businesses before it is too late.

name: Cindy FRANSSEN
text: Written. – Many Member States are facing a second COVID-19 wave. At present, 60 million Europeans are at risk of losing their jobs. So far, Europe has been able to avoid the mass unemployment that has struck elsewhere. This is largely due to systems of shortening of working hours (such as the SURE instrument) which employed around 45 million people, and which are to help people pay rent or meet basic needs. But we also need to think about the future of our jobs. The health crisis made it clear that we need to focus more on quality jobs and decent working conditions, in line with the SDGs and the European Pillar of Social Rights. Our employees deserve a fair income and a safe and healthy working environment. This requires a strong involvement of the social partners. That is why I am asking the Commission and the Member States to preserve the current measures to protect employment until a real recovery is made, to launch a proposal for a permanent European reinsurance system for unemployment and a European framework for fair minimum wages. Moreover, as shadow rapporteur on behalf of the EPP, I am pushing for a significant increase in the budget for the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The COVID-19 epidemic is on the rise worldwide. In recent days, there has been a record daily increase in cases worldwide. Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovakia and Belgium are just some of the EU countries that are facing the most rapid increase in cases since the beginning of the epidemic. With the deteriorating epidemiological situation in Europe, the social and economic crisis is deepening. The increasing day-to-day illness means the return of tougher restrictions that will worsen economic problems. Thousands of European companies, operating in a wide variety of sectors, are on the precipice. Cost-cutting, mass redundancies and restructuring are a reality today, and without effective action, the economic situation will deteriorate. Bearing in mind the economic aspects of the crisis, its social dimension must not be forgotten. More and more citizens are struggling with the virus or are watching this fight among their loved ones. Health services are on the verge of endurance, as demonstrated by the example of Belgium, where COVID-19 testing has already been discontinued among people who do not show symptoms despite close contact with patients. At these moments, we should take particular care of the citizens most at risk from the severe course of COVID-19 – the elderly and the sick. We already know today that we will feel the effects of the crisis for years to come. Identifying needs and adapting appropriate measures to them is essential for the survival of the economy.

name: Guido REIL
text: Writing. – The EU says that the newly created financial instruments such as SURE and the Reconstruction Fund are necessary to mitigate the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on national societies and economies in the EU. This is wrong. Since the social and economic consequences vary from one Member State to another, The Member States should and must also implement their own specific policies to meet these challenges. In any case, the Reconstruction Fund is a mere label fraud. It is said that the EUR 750 billion will be used to reduce the economic and social consequences of the crisis. In reality, however, they serve to advance the "Green Deal" and to complete a debt and transfer union. After the British leave, of course, there is much less money, but you don't want to cut back. Spending more and more money is the message and that is why new funds are being created through a new budget. The Chancellor has always stressed that there is never any common debt. Now there is indeed common debt and there is no way back. The fact that the EU is taking on debt, even though it does not have its own statehood and financial sovereignty, and that the money is distributed past parliaments and its budgetary rights, is a violation of democracy and law. The result is that in this transfer union, 40% of the EU population co-finances the remaining 60%.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: – The next item is the report byLara Burkhardt, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety on deforestation (2020/2006(INL)) (A9-0179/2020). I would like to inform you that no debate in this part-session provides for an in-house application procedure and no blue cards or requests for compliance with the Rules of Procedure will be accepted. Remote speeches from Parliament's contact offices in the Member States are foreseen.

name: Delara BURKHARDT
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased to be here today from Berlin with you to have this important debate, which affects all of us every day. Whether in our morning coffee, in chocolate, in grilled meat, even in car seats, in many of our everyday consumer and consumer goods lies the destruction of our forests. And we consumers often unconsciously contribute to this. Forests are being cleared, burned and rolled down all over the world to make way for agriculture. It is made room for the cultivation of soy, coffee, cocoa, palm oil and other raw materials. The same applies to cattle, whose meat and leather are also traded on the European market and contribute to 10% of global deforestation. Since there are no uniform rules or reliable labels, we cannot be sure that the coffee beans, soybean food and cowhide do not come from areas such as the Amazon, which have been deliberately converted into agricultural land there. So it is that the rainforest is literally burning on another continent for the steaks that we put on the grill here in Europe. Europe's largest meat processors and steakhouse chains regularly source their products from leading Brazilian meat producers, who are associated with the destruction of forests, even though they have committed themselves not to cut down forests. Deforestation is even in European cars: recently, NGOs revealed that a well-known German car brand buys the leather for some of its luxury cars from Italian suppliers, who in turn source their material from Paraguayan farms, which ruthlessly extend their agricultural activities to the forests of the Gran Chaco. In 2019 alone, ladies and gentlemen, an area the size of a football field was destroyed every two minutes in Paraguay. And that's just one of many examples. In 2019, there was a loss of primary rainforests the size of Belgium. Countries such as Brazil, the Republic of Congo and Indonesia are one of the hardest hit. Europe contributes to this global deforestation through its consumption. And no one in Europe should be able to opt for or against a deforestation-free product before the supermarket shelf, but at the moment there are no European rules prohibiting this. The European Commission announced in its communication on the protection of international forests last year that it would take action against it. And the work plan presented – and we are very pleased about this, Mr Sinkevicius , confirms this.  But we in the European Parliament have not been idle and prepared. We are voting this week on a report that contains demands for this legislative initiative, ensinrating a simple principle: if a company wants to bring products to the EU – after all, the largest in the world – it must demonstrate that the entire supply chain, including suppliers, business partners and traders, does not include products or services related to deforestation or the destruction of other valuable ecosystems.  But the destruction of forests, the green lungs of our planet, home to 80% of rural biodiversity and one of our strongest allies in the fight against climate change, is not only an ecological disaster, it is also a social one. The destruction of forests is often the result and cause of human rights violations. That is why companies must also be able to demonstrate that their products are not linked to violations of labour rights, land grabs and violence against those who live with, with and in forests. Where human rights violations or destruction of nature are part of a supply chain, even though a company would have had influence over it, European companies should be able to be held liable for this damage under civil law and pay compensation. Contrary to what is often claimed, companies are therefore not held responsible for transactions over which they have no influence whatsoever. They should only comply with their own due diligence obligations. A law without a liability rule would be little more than a toothless declaration of intent.  These rules should also apply to financial institutions. People need to be reassured that their facilities will not be used to fund environmentally destructive, human rights-violating activities. Globalisation could thus be made fairer and more sustainable thanks to strong European standards. In this way, we make a difference and organise a green deal that not only applies within Europe, but also fulfils our global responsibility. Many companies share the position that responsibly produced goods are not nice—to—have for marketing reasons, but a necessity for the survival of our planet. The legislative framework outlined here would support companies that are already doing their business responsibly. At the same time, fair competition would be created against those who have so far profited at the expense of nature and people.  The European Parliament is therefore in charge this week of putting pressure on the Commission to adopt an ambitious proposal. Ursula von der Leyen said in her candidacy speech that if we support them, she will take legislative proposals from Parliament seriously. Parliament should call on them today to remind them of this promise. And today we should give Mr Sinkevicius an ambitious proposal in the further work, so that we do not have a bitter aftertaste when it comes to enjoying chocolate or coffee, and that we in Europe take a global leadership role against deforestation, for nature conservation and respect for human rights. And that is what we have the opportunity to do today. Please support the proposal.

name: Karin KARLSBRO
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr "The forest whispers of the labors of ancestors. When I walk in the local forests, the traces are everywhere of generations' work for the well-being of future generations." So a friend of mine expressed himself when I asked some acquaintances what the forest means to them. I come from a country that is half forest. Forests are one of our main resources, creating growth and benefits and which generations of forest owners have managed with care and long-term care long-term long-term care long before the word sustainability became an international concept.  The forest is the lungs of the earth, a pantry, an energy resource. The forest is home to invaluable biodiversity and a place of peace of mind. As a carbon sink, forests are absolutely crucial for saving the climate. At the same time, however, an increasingly warmer climate threatens the future of forests. Deforestation is a global problem, a threat to the climate, a threat to the survival of species. But also a threat to long-term economic growth. Illegal logging does not only lead to environmental problems. It also leads to poverty, loss of tax revenue and risk of increased corruption.  Getting more countries to cooperate in sustainable trade in forest products is extremely important, and doing so together with industry and in cooperation with civil society is necessary. The EU framework, FLEGT, which aims at sustainable forestry and combating illegal logging, is part of this. That is why we need to develop and strengthen this cooperation and make it easier for more countries, companies and foresters to conduct and trade forest products in a sustainable way. It benefits us, it benefits us all and it benefits future generations. Strong European cooperation against deforestation and this report is needed and makes a difference.

name: Virginijus Sinkevičius
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by thanking this Parliament for its valuable work and for its continuous support to address what has become one of the main threats to our planet – global deforestation.  Let me congratulate you, Ms Burkhardt, and the entire Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on your important report, which calls for an EU legal framework to halt and reverse EU—driven global deforestation. It is good to see that we agree on the importance of this subject, and that we share a sense of urgency.  Our EU biodiversity strategy for 2030 stresses the importance of increasing the quantity, quality and resilience of our own forests. But while the area covered by forests in Europe increases, forest degradation and international deforestation threaten the well—being of all of us. Deforestation is a major source of greenhouse gas emissions, causing climate change. It is pushing animals and plants to extinction and affecting the rights of indigenous peoples in some parts of the world. In short, it is akin to choking life on Earth.  Deforestation is also a complex problem, and there is no easy solution. No major economy in the world has yet managed to eliminate products linked to deforestation for its supply chains, and yet this is exactly what we have to do and what we plan to do. EU demand and consumption, our way of life, should not trigger deforestation and forest degradation. In fact, this should go for everyone. We have to break the link.  Your report and the legislative initiative resolution which this House will adopt tomorrow is an extremely important contribution in this regard. We particularly appreciate that through this report, the European Parliament has been truly effective in drawing attention to the issue of deforestation. Public awareness and support are crucial if we really want to change things. The report addresses highly relevant issues and contains a number of important messages. It is certainly true that the limited uptake of voluntary schemes failed – failed to deliver on the promise of reducing deforestation – and that mandatory action is needed. Getting the product scope right and ensuring that it is scientifically based and regularly updated will definitely be a key aspect of any future action. It is also true that we should not forget that high carbon stock and biodiversity rich ecosystems, other than forest, marine and coastal ecosystems, wetlands, peatlands or savannas are equally threatened.  Let me be clear, we are determined to act and to use the EU’s economic weight to help protect, restore and sustainably manage the world’s forests. As you probably know, we have already started preparatory work on a new legislative proposal to curtail the placing of products associated with deforestation or forest degradation on the European market. This objective is enshrined in the European Green Deal, the EU biodiversity strategy for 2030 and farm—to—fork strategy. We are currently working on an impact assessment and we have launched a public consultation that will run until 10 December. The adoption of this proposal is currently scheduled for next year, 2021, the second quarter.  In the current impact assessment process and in line with our better regulation principle, we are of course assessing a variety of policy options. These include due diligence and bilateral agreements with third countries, but not only. We are, for example, studying the system put in place by the EU regulation to prevent, deter and eliminate illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, as well as different forms of verification systems, among other options. In parallel, we are also conducting a fitness check of the rules in place to fight illegal logging, namely the EU timber regulation and the FLEGT regulation, to take action into account of our past experience and better understand what has worked and what has failed. We expect to finalise these fitness checks in early 2021, so that their results can duly inform the decision—making process. We have been implementing the due diligence system of the EU timber regulation for more than seven years and have been negotiating and implementing flexible, voluntary partnership agreements for much longer.  Let me be clear, we will certainly not shy away from proposing strong mandatory action to address the problem, but we need to make sure that whatever we propose works, that it has the necessary impact on the ground and that it is compatible with our WTO obligations.  Let me conclude by saying that the report of the European Parliament constitutes an important contribution and goes beyond the legislative work of the Commission, meaning it should also translate in the work of other sectors, including working in partnership with producing countries to reduce pressures on forest and help them implement sustainable forest—based value chains – ones adopted by this House. We will carefully analyse your recommendations and will duly consider these when developing our proposal. Honourable Members, between 1990 and 2020, about 10% of the world’s forest cover was destroyed – an area bigger than India. If deforestation were a nation, it would be the third biggest emitter of greenhouse gases after China and the US. We cannot underestimate this challenge, and we have to act. This is also why our efforts to curtail the risk of deforestation and forest degradation feature prominently in the Commission’s work programme for the next year, which the College adopted only two days ago. It is our responsibility to do our part to change this course and it is in our hands to do it effectively, already in upcoming months. Let us not waste this unique opportunity. Let us do this together.

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture. Mr President, I would like to thank the Mrs Burkhardt, I would like to congratulate you most warmly on this report, which is really a big step forward. I would also like to thank the Commissioner for being able to create measures from this now, because the drama of deforestation has increased so much in recent years that something really needs to be done.  I also believe that Europe has more than 10% of its share of deforestation. If I alone imagine that we have about 10% of our forage area in South America again – that is, soya imports have become the basis for the massive investment in mass animal husbandry, we must realise that we also bear a large part of the responsibility in these countries. We can also produce protein in Europe itself, which is possible, and we must go down these paths.  Palm oil - another big issue. We have decided not to use palm oil any more than renewable energy. That should actually be done sooner. However, it is also quite clear that free trade agreements, Commissioner, such as the Mercosur Agreement , must be dealt with differently from what is now on the table. One final point: we must also protect European forests, and I would remind you that the Carpathians also need massive protection in Europe, and we do not have that at the moment.

name: Caroline ROOSE
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Development - Thank you Mr President. This week, our Parliament is voting on the draft reform of the common agricultural policy, but how can we vote for this insufficient reform, even as the Amazon is plagued by deforestation and the proliferation of forest fires? Let's face it: our model of industrial agriculture heavily dependent on soybean imports is largely responsible. It is responsible for deforestation, the destruction of unique ecosystems and the habitats of many animal species, and land grabbing at the expense of the rights of peasants and indigenous peoples. The problem has been identified for years and yet nothing is being done to solve it. The report we are going to vote calls on the European Union to develop a legal framework to combat deforestation and forest degradation. The report is based in particular on the duty of vigilance and the responsibility of companies. I am rapporteur in the Committee on Development on corporate environmental responsibility. Those that, directly or through subcontractors, contribute to deforestation must be judged. It is important that people in developing countries have effective access to justice. The time for impunity must end. The culprits of ecocide must be tried.

name: Hildegard BENTELE
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the The speed and scale with which we are currently losing forest land around the world is breathtaking and highly dangerous. We in the EU are contributing to this destruction by consuming soya, palm oil and meat. Even if our share is only 10%, it is clear to us that we must act, we must reverse this trend, we must protect forest areas!  With this draft new EU legal framework, which we jointly adopted in the Green Deal resolution, we are taking the right steps. We want the entire supply chain to be traceable for products that are particularly hazardous to forests, especially the place where the product originates. We want to make sure that it does not come from an area for which forest has been cleared. If we could achieve such a set of rules for all companies that want to bring their products to the European market in the future, then we would have made real great progress in terms of our responsibility as Europeans for forest protection worldwide. But, ladies and gentlemen, for this we need companies as partners, because the state cannot monitor every tree and every farmer.  We need tougher measures when the risk is greater. We need actionable measures that can also be implemented for small and medium-sized enterprises. We need an impact assessment in advance, we need legal certainty through clear guidelines. I think we are wise to use existing certification systems, improve and standardise them if necessary, and ideally label the 'EU-certified'. We have made a long-distance impact in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and The European People's Committee on the Environment. It is not only the forest that is to be protected, but also human rights, especially the rights of indigenous peoples. That is right, because we must also face up to this responsibility. However, we should not create facts through the back door and bypass the lead committees in formulating binding due diligence, as this report is intended to do.  Ladies and gentlemen, this new legal framework combines the great hope and expectation that we will significantly reduce deforestation, which is the result of consumption in the EU, and thus have a standard-building effect on the other 90% of consumers worldwide. It is therefore very important that we get the measures right now and that they act quickly.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, there is no doubt that global deforestation is an enormous problem, and we need to take good care of the world’s forests. They are the lungs of this earth. There is an ongoing and very worrisome trend, with the loss of global tree cover and the destruction of forest in many third countries outside of Europe. This has dramatic consequences for our climate and our ecosystems. It also has grave social impacts. Almost one in every four people in the world today depend on forests for their daily livelihood and income. Indigenous people around the world – for example, in the Amazon – are heavily dependent on forests, and deforestation threatens their livelihood. There are also completely flagrant and abhorrent human rights violations due to conflicts linked to the situation. In the Amazon region alone, we have seen how more than 300 people have been killed in resource and land use conflicts in the last decade. This is really awful and can never be accepted. Although this deforestation takes place in other parts of the world, we see here in Europe that we have a responsibility to act. Our own consumption is a big part of the problem; it contributes to at least 10 % of global deforestation. Therefore, we must look at ways to better ensure that we halt global deforestation, including through our own consumption. As a consumer, I want to know that my consumption doesn’t have negative effects on the environment or on people who live in other countries. Commodities used in EU should not lead to deforestation and human rights abuses in the countries where the products have been produced. All of us agree on that, and now it’s time to act.

name: Pascal CANFIN
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I think we all want, when we have a cup of coffee, when your children or mine eat a chicken cutlet, to know whether or not we are contributing to the deforestation of the Amazon. Today, unfortunately, as we do not know, as no European rule prevents products from deforestation in the Amazon or, in Africa, the Congo basin or, in Asia, Indonesia, it is very likely that, without our knowledge, we will contribute to it. And that's where we need to change. We have to change the rule in a fairly simple and ultimately very consensual way. The bill that we are going to vote on today is supported by the extreme left in the EPP, by the right, the centre, the Greens and the left. This means that we can find a compromise when we work intelligently on these subjects, because it is our general interest and it is our common good: both as consumers and also as citizens of the world, our general interest is to protect a common good like the Amazon. I have heard that you will propose, as early as the first quarter of 2021, a bill on this subject: we will support it if it is ambitious and consistent with what we are proposing today and which, once again, is supported by a very large political majority. Things are quite simple, there are now European companies that have led by example, who are able to say 'I have put an end to deforestation on my supply chain'. So just take what they have tested and succeeded, take their best practices and say: 'From now on, if you want to sell chocolate, soybeans, palm oil, rubber, etc., then we must respect these good practices, which are already implemented by our best European companies'. The path is quite simple, namely more transparency. I wanted to say a word about traders. Above all, remember, when you are going to write your text, Commissioner, that traders are an opaque black box that must be opened in order to fight deforestation effectively. We are counting on you, you will be supported by Parliament in this adventure.

name: Teuvo HAKKARAINEN
text: On behalf of the ID Group. – Mr President, deforestation is not so much a European problem. The main cause of deforestria is the recklessness of people. If it can't be contained, the roof will accelerate. Africa is one example of this. Billions of development billions have been thrown in there, and the roof is getting bigger.  It is claimed that the clearing of the field causes most deforestion. That is probably true, but the situation will not improve with de sadning, but we must follow suit. In Finland, the forest area is constantly growing. Finland is an example country for forest management. Take inspiration from that. After logging, we have an obligation to plant new trees immediately, and this model must also be imposed there in developing countries. In addition, the cost of regeneration is very small. Personally, for example, I have personally planted at least 100 000 trees. The biggest of them all is this size. Come and see how to combat deforestation in Finland and how to get more of that forest area.

name: Marie TOUSSAINT
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Good morning, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I call on us to appreciate the importance of the text we are debating today and for which I congratulate its rapporteur Delara Burkhardt. We can defend forests for their beauty, we can defend them for the mysterious bond they forge between us and the origins of the world, we can defend forests because we defend the rights of nature. But let us also be convinced that we must defend forests because by protecting them, it is our very existence that we protect, because forests are the lung of humanity and the planet. Between 1970 and 2012, 58% of vertebrate animals disappeared due to deforestation. So can we imagine preserving biodiversity without preserving the world's forests? The answer is no. Can we hope to meet our climate commitments without preserving the world's forests? Again, the answer is no, because forests cover 31% of the Earth's surface and are, after the oceans, the second largest carbon sink on the planet. To continue to destroy them is to condemn us to lose the battle of the climate.  I would add that deforestation exacerbates the threats to indigenous communities, victims of attacks, sometimes even murders, because they claim to defend their lands and their rights. Deforestation is the other name for the violation of people's rights. Who claims to defend human rights must therefore put an end to it. Let us be clear: our forests continue to be destroyed for the benefit of trade; short-term profits still prevail today. Industrial agriculture alone is responsible for 40% of global deforestation, the European Union 10%. So yes, Europe must lead the way. Yes, we need a duty of vigilance for companies and their financiers. We must recognize the universal right to a healthy environment for all, ensure access to justice, and protect environmentalists. We must also put an end to the ecocide underway in the Amazon, by bringing the recognition of this crime to the international level and finally guaranteeing a legal status for the world's natural commons. So let us be ambitious, let us adopt this text protecting forests: we are talking about our future, we are talking about Europe, we are talking about our responsibility in the face of the destruction of the planet.

name: Mazaly AGUILAR
text: ECR Group. – Mr President, global deforestation is a problem that unies us and yet reports like the one we are discussing separate us. We cannot use the fight against deforestation to attack biotechnology without data or begin the transition to a vegan paradise.  Production such as soybeans, which is critical to feeding our livestock and which comes mainly from the United States of America, a country where there is no deforestation, cannot be stigmatized.  I find it counterproductive to ridicule the sector's efforts through certification or voluntary agreements. Only through realistic objectives and loyal cooperation with the sector will we achieve the objective of reducing deforestation outside the European Union.  I'd like to be very clear. We must ban in the European Union all imports of products from deforested areas, but let us not focus the debate exclusively on Latin America: deforestation is much higher in areas of Asia and Africa, which we are not talking about.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: for the GUE/NGL group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have been working closely on the subject of deforestation for almost five years, also because I was Parliament's first-ever rapporteur on deforestation and palm oil. In that time, unfortunately, I have experienced all sorts of delaying tactics on the part of the Commission and have heard many fairy tales from representatives of third countries on the subject of 'everything is fine and we are doing the best we can'. I'll admit I've had enough. We have been witnessing the total devastation of global forests and forests for some time now. And I'm not going to point the finger at anyone because it's a global problem. However, I consider it essential that the European Union is part of it and therefore the burden of finding a solution rests on it. It is not possible otherwise when we put palm oil in biofuels and European banks finance deforestation in third countries. I would like to thank my fellow rapporteur for her work, and I hope, colleagues, that her report will no longer be changed by those who believe that sticking her head in the sand will solve the problems, or by those who want to blame this whole complex problem on consumers. Ursula von der Leyen touched on the subject of deforestation several times in her State of the Union address, and I believe that the European Parliament should not be afraid of an ambitious approach and should not change the opinion of the Committee on the Environment. And this also applies to you colleagues who elected Ursula von der Leyen to the post, please respect her words and support our text.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, from the beginning of this debate until the last speech, the world will have lost between one thousand and two thousand forest-surface football fields. Global deforestation is estimated to have amounted to 1.3 million square meters from 1990 to 2016, the equivalent of 800 football fields per hour. Satellite data tells us that deforestation is advancing at a much faster rate in the Brazilian Amazon rainforest. We talk about the equivalent of a football field every minute and this trend shows no sign of diminishing. In the first four months of this year, the destruction of the Amazon rainforest increased by 55 % compared with the previous year, but pointing the finger at Bolsonaro's crazy and criminal policies is not enough, the hunt for those responsible for this ecocide must start from home. Indeed, the European Union is responsible for 10 % of global deforestation through its consumption of products such as palm oil, soya, meat, rubber and wood. It is time to put an end to this disaster, but the solution is certainly not to label which products are zero deforestation and which are not, thus leaving the consumer the choice, as some suggested, but to ensure that those products made by deforestation, conversion and degradation of natural ecosystems cannot be sold on the European market.  That is why we need a legal framework based on due diligence that applies to all those operating within the supply chain of deforestation-related goods, including European credit institutions, which in recent years have had no problem financing those who destroy our country's green lung. The citizens of Europe do not want to commit this environmental crime, let us help them.

name: Michal WIEZIK
text: – Mr President, a total of 13 million hectares are deforested globally each year. The main driver of deforestation is the expansion of agricultural land and the production of three commodities: soy, beef and palm oil. The Union has a share in this as it imports up to 10% of the global consumption of products associated with deforestation. We will ask the Commission to come up with a legal framework to prevent this and make supply chains bringing products to our markets sustainable. The global preservation of forests and preventing their degradation are some of the biggest sustainability challenges of our time. Crucial steps are needed to achieve this, but we are opposing and fighting these steps even in this very House. We should stop pretending that there exists a single ultimate solution called sustainable forest management, a remedy for deforestation. We will lose primary forests all around the world in a vain attempt to manage them sustainably. We must protect primary forests from being extracted. However, not only forests are affected by the degradation as a result of economic activities. In Brazil, the Cerrado ecosystem is a biodiversity hotspot, home to 5% of global biodiversity. The conversion and degradation of this ecosystem has been happening at a faster pace than for the Amazon rainforest and it is crystal clear that these ecosystems will be exposed to increased pressure to be turned into agricultural land. The problem is complex.  I will vote in favour of a call for a legal framework that takes account of forest and other valuable ecosystems and therefore recognises forest and ecosystem risk commodities.  To sum up, I congratulate the rapporteur for preparing such a complex and effective file and I am ready and happy to vote in favour of it.

name: César LUENA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, today's debate on this report to combat global deforestation is very important and I would like to congratulate Delara Burkhardt because I think she has done an excellent job. We have adopted a report on the climate emergency in this Parliament, we have also passed the Climate Law to achieve neutrality and I believe that today we take another step to make the most environmentalist institution in the world the European Parliament, a House that is at the forefront in combating the effects of climate change.  Ladies and gentlemen, we are talking about them this afternoon, but what do the forests mean? Forests are unique ecosystems that host 60,000 different tree species, 80% of amphibian species, 75% of bird species, and 68% of mammalian species on Earth. They are natural carbon sinks of invaluable value in basic natural processes such as air and water purification, carbon absorption or temperature regulation. This means forests. How do we protect ourselves? Commissioner, under Article 225 of the Operating Treaty, it is clear that there will be a legislative proposal. I hope you'll introduce her to us soon. Tell the president, Ursula von der Leyen.  We need to protect forest ecosystems, and I don't want us to forget about natural ecosystems, wetlands either. We need to include binding chapters on sustainable development in free trade agreements such as Mercosur, thus complying with the Paris Agreement and the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. Mrs Burkhard, I congratulate you on paragraph 46 of the report.  Anyway, ladies and gentlemen, we're at the sixth mass extinction of species. The Holocene can be ended at any time if we continue like this, so let's build on this momentum, this afternoon's momentum and this report to protect and preserve ecosystems, biodiversity and forests.

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Ladies and gentlemen, we Europeans have been working for many years to reduce our ecological footprint. Of course, it is logical that we should also look at the impact of our imports, especially our contribution to the loss of rainforests. That is why I very much welcome the initiative. However, we must actually do something good with this, rather than just creating a green fig leaf. Central to this is the law in practice, that it is feasible and does not only mean uncalculated risks and high bureaucratic burdens for our companies. Firstly, we will continue to need imports and we will depend on them: many fruits, such as cocoa, coffee, tea and others, are not growing here in Europe. Secondly, the environmental contribution of such a supply chain law will only be positive if we continue to trade with the affected regions and help them to become more sustainable.  We will be insulated by an unworkable law. If exports are indeed shifting towards other countries that have less concern, nothing will be gained for the rainforest, Commissioner. That is why I call for a thorough impact assessment and a workable scope. On the other hand, I am equally strongly opposed to the creation of incalculable legal risks.  Ladies and gentlemen, with this initiative, we want to address in our role the specific situation in third countries where the principles of sustainable forestry are not consistently applied. Forestry in our Member States, on the other hand, is a world leader in sustainable, responsible management of forests. It is clear that different standards need to be applied here. It must therefore also be clear that, with this Supply Supply Supply Act, we must not create additional burdens for our foresters.

name: Aurelia BEIGNEUX
text: Mr President, Europe, as I recall, is the first continent responsible for imported deforestation. Worldwide, 13 million hectares are cleared each year and the vast majority of this deforestation takes place in tropical forests. Once again, the European Union acts as the main link in the chain of deforestation. The majority of these products are related to three commodities: soybeans, beef and palm oil. There is a direct link between deforestation and climate change, as 12% of global greenhouse gas emissions are the result of deforestation. It degrades major endemic ecosystems, especially in tropical areas, which are so important for temperature regulation. I could have voted in favour of this report if it did not contain two major errors. First, once again, we are dealing with a report that will allow NGOs to condemn sovereign states through the famous arbitration tribunals. It is an unspeakable attack on the sovereignty of our nations. Secondly, the European Union is only making itself aware. There is no point in creating products stamped with zero deforestation when the central problem remains free trade agreements. Again, your European vision harms both producers and the environment, so you are fatally a link in the chain of deforestation. Let us get out of the too many free trade treaties that the European Union has ratified, defend another model geared towards localism, stop this excessive liberalisation and return to a truly ethical model.

name: Anna DEPARNAY-GRUNENBERG
text: – Mr President, a surface bigger than Switzerland is lost to deforestation worldwide every year. As Europeans, we are sadly jointly responsible every day for deforestation, for an incredible loss of biodiversity, for speeding up climate change, and for harming the rights of indigenous people – for example, when we simply order a ham sandwich at the station, and so maybe consume meat from animals fed with soy planted on illegally—logged forest soil. No wooden product sold in Europe should come from illicit sources. No product that indirectly results from illegal logging should be imported. We know the mechanism that can help: mandatory due diligence for all enterprises in our common market. People in Europe know that forests are the lungs of our planet. So let’s act now.

name: Sunčana GLAVAK
text: – Dear Chairman, according to Global Forest Watch data every six seconds we lose the rainforest of the surface of one football field or about 7410 m2. Despite the successes in forest conservation, data from the Food and Agriculture Organisation in the State of the World Forests Report this year highlights one fact: the fight to combat forest losses is not yet over.  Deforestation and forest degradation have a negative impact on a number of global European Union objectives in various policy fields, such as the protection of biodiversity, climate change, human rights, peace and security, good governance and the rule of law.  The European Union is the world's most attractive market. It is the right time to incorporate some positive legal regulations and environmental goals in trade relations with the world.  We need to take action to ensure that the well-imported into the European Union are the least a product of deforestation. I therefore welcome this initiative and believe that the European Commission will consider the proposed regulatory measures we could take and thus affect the reduction of deforestation. My speech lasts 90 seconds. During this time, colleagues and colleagues, 15 forests the size of a football field or 148 200 m2 of rainforest were deforested. We can change that with our actions and - let's start that now.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Mr President, the report on deforestation deserves all our support because we are at a tipping point in our history. If, for example, deforestation of the Amazon continues at this rate, by 2030 all the CO2 stored over billions of years will gradually be released back into the atmosphere. This will result in temperatures rising by 2 degrees in Latin America and by half a degree in the rest of the world, only due to deforestation in the Amazon. So we're at a tipping point. We are all victims of a global pandemic today. We also know why: because we as human beings are penetrating ever deeper into nature. The question therefore arises: where will the next pandemic come from? From the forests of Congo, which are getting smaller and smaller because of the mining policy? Or from the primeval forests of Ukraine, where there is a lot of cutting today, for example for our Ikea furniture? It has already been said here, but we cannot stress it enough: 10% of deforestation worldwide is the result of what we eat and consume here. What we are doing here has a huge global effect. So we have to take responsibility! This report is therefore extremely important because it contains a call for legislation that tells companies very clearly what it stands for. Your products are more than welcome here, but they must be produced fairly, with respect for the environment.

name: María Soraya RODRÍGUEZ RAMOS
text: – Mr President, the debate we are having today is indeed essential, because every year we lose a lot of forest mass, the equivalent of Belgium, in an annual loss of primary tropical forests, but which is an irreparable loss because primary forests cannot be replaced by planting more trees: forests are much more than trees. That's why it's absolutely necessary to act fast.  The European Union is more or less responsible for 10% of global deforestation, and we need to address safe and global standards. This is, and it's not legislation against anyone, it's legislation in favor.  It is legislation in favour of European companies that meet environmental and human rights standards and which have to compete in a market with the disadvantage of doing so with companies that do not comply. It is consumer legislation, which has the right to know transparently the supply chain of the final products they consume. It is in favour of consumers also when we ask for clear labelling, to know that what comes to our tables and our homes does not come from deforestation or the exploitation of forests that are very degraded. It is therefore also in favour of those who die every year precisely to defend forests.  And it's also going to help us understand that every time we cut down, that we make a hectare of forest disappear, we're making our lives disappear. We're all victims, but we're all responsible.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: Mr President, I am delighted to be speaking to you from our beautiful city of Strasbourg. At a time when the world's spotlights are being pointed at the Amazon rainforest, another drama is taking place in general indifference: that of deforestation in Africa. The forests of the African continent are disappearing faster than the others. The population explosion is one of the major causes that causes this infernal acceleration. Cutting down trees to expand agricultural areas destroys biodiversity that is essential to the sustainability of crops. The phrase "cutting the branch on which you sit" has never been more true, dramatically true. Added to this are the problems that are encountered everywhere else. Palm oil production, for example, is still in its infancy in Cameroon or the DRC. A disaster announced, when we know that this is where the rainforest of the Congo Basin is located - the second largest forest in the world, tomorrow destroyed? Overcrowding or overexploitation, Africans are at risk of being completely overwhelmed. We don't talk much about it, but it's an essential subject for them and for us.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Mr President, now is indeed the moment for European leadership, in order to make sure that we don’t have deforestation or child labour in our supply chains.  I would like to communicate to you a message that has been sent today by major operators in this field, namely food producers such as Mars and Mondelez, who say that they, as major buyers of cocoa and other agricultural products, with longstanding engagement and continued efforts for sustainable cocoa, defend the report of Ms Burkhardt.  They warn against the amendments that are put there to water down the idea that we need mandatory measures, because that’s what they want. They need mandatory measures because they know that voluntary mechanisms don’t function. They are not able to guarantee supply chains which are free of deforestation and child labour.

name: Nicolás GONZÁLEZ CASARES
text: – Mr President, "[t]he forests and jungles of rugged thicket yesterday, where among the mystery floated the mists and the fountain sprouted, today they are arid hills that boast deformed and black their deep fissures". This was said by Rosalía de Castro, a Galician poet about the destruction of forests. And it's true, every forest tells a story, stories of human protection. Stripping ourselves of the woods, we unprotect ourselves.  This is what this report is about, and that is why I would also like to congratulate Delara Burkhardt. Because this report helps us fight deforestation everywhere on the planet, putting rules of the game to our consumption models.  We need better regulation. We also need to protect primitive forests, the primal forests, the natives. Not just outside the European Union. Here too we are suffering from this deforestation and substitution with other models of agro-industrial production. That's why we have to defend ourselves here, too. And also remember that to cut down a forest, to get rid of it, it promotes climate change and also causes the escape of its inhabitants, not only of those biodiverse but also of humans.  Therefore, demanding regulation that protects forests at all levels will be a good option for the European Union.

name: Nicola PROCACCINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the fact that we are talking about deforestation in this Parliament is already positive in itself. The problem must be tackled, not overlooked, provided that it is done by keeping a distance from the usual environmental extremism, which cares nothing about scientific data.  We know that our planet is getting greener and greener, as the scientific studies of recent years document. This is due to some political choices that have matured far from here, paradoxically also as a result of global warming. After that, we know, on the other hand, that severe tropical deforestation cannot be compensated for by reforestation in other parts of the world. I would therefore like to pay particular attention to the consumption of forests, but only to ensure that European companies do not bear additional geopolitical burdens, because that would not be fair to them, especially at a time like this.

name: Virginijus Sinkevičius
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, deforestation is a threat to the biosphere and the well—being of all citizens on Earth. Today’s debate has shown that we very largely agree on this and share those huge concerns. It is also a complex problem that requires concerted action among different players to be addressed.  Let me reply to some remarks and issues you have raised today. On the need for an impact assessment and the need to have businesses on board, I absolutely agree. I can only confirm once more that we are assessing all possible impacts and that we, of course, have to consider also the costs and administrative burden, especially on SMEs, and that we are carefully looking at the scope as well. All these elements are currently being carefully assessed in the context of the ongoing impact assessment.  On the need to protect forests also within the EU, I can only strongly reassure you that tackling global deforestation does not mean we stop looking at our domestic forests. Quite the contrary. This Commission, and I personally, are truly committed to fighting the worrying phenomenon of illegal logging. We have launched infringement procedures and are determined to find this till the end. Also, forests play a central role in our biodiversity strategy for 2030. They are a key focus of our work and, as you know, with Commissioner Wojciechowski I am preparing a forest strategy which updates the previous one and will take into account the recent resolution adopted by this Parliament.  On social aspects and the impact of deforestation on indigenous peoples, yes, the environmental dimension of global deforestation is closely interconnected with fundamental socio—economic factors – with poverty, corruption, human rights abuses and stability. This is why our initiative is so important, and this is why the fight against deforestation has to be fought together with indigenous people and local communities. They have to be part of the solution.  We are not playing delaying tactics, quite the contrary. The Commission is determined to act. We are putting to use our previous policy experience, we are leading exchanges among stakeholders and we are trying to design smart legislation that can ensure meaningful action on the ground. We need to join forces. I would like to thank you once again for your support and your contributions in today’s debate, but also for the legislative initiative resolution that you will adopt tomorrow. We look forward to taking it into account and to continue our close cooperation with this House over the next crucial months.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: The debate is closed. The vote on the amendments will take place shortly. The final vote will take place on Thursday, 22 October 2020. The sitting is suspended until 18.15 and the announcement of the results of the second voting session. Written declarations (Rule 171)

name: Carmen AVRAM
text: in writing. – This report recalls the essential role of forests for our planet’s ecosystem, biodiversity and future. It is a reminder that biologically diverse forests, being natural carbon sinks, are indispensable in the fight against climate change, in line with the Paris Agreement’s goals to hold the increase in the global average temperature to well below 2°C above pre-industrial levels.  Fighting illegal timber logging is also central. It recalls the due diligence criteria of the EU Timber Regulation. The text repeats its demand that imports of timber and timber products should be more thoroughly checked at the EU’s borders to ensure that imported products do indeed comply with our legislation.  Moreover, I want to stress that trade and investment policy need to be reviewed in order to address the global deforestation challenge in a more effective manner, and by creating globally a level playing field, and take into account the link between trade agreements and global biodiversity as well as forest ecosystems.  Finally I support the calls on the Commission and Member States to develop information and awareness-raising campaigns about the imported timber products and their impact on the world’s forests and biodiversity-rich ecosystems. Our youth and next generation are on our side and we shouldn’t lose them.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. – The importance of protecting European and global forests is beyond dispute. However, this report is not fit for purpose, it crosses the EU legal framework and disproportionately jeopardises the functioning of European SMEs. Without an impact assessment, the proposal would list the products most commonly associated with deforestation and the deterioration of natural ecosystems by green NGOs. Moreover, the left would leave open the possibility of expanding the scope of the regulation. Without a European certification system, the process would become completely opaque and disproportionate. The arbitrary scope of the report is also problematic. The rapporteur would extend the proposal to all economic operators and the entire value chain. This would have unforeseen consequences and an administrative burden for SMEs. Moreover, the document therefore concerns a number of areas of competence of the Member States, which is also unacceptable. The protection of forests should not be promoted by listing and quotas, either at European or global level. We need positive incentives and international cooperation. In doing so, it is also worth taking into account best practices in the Member States. Such a good example Hungary, which undertook to increase the size of its forest area by a third to 27% by 2030.

name: Rovana PLUMB
text: in writing. – Global preservation of forests and preventing their degradation are some of the biggest sustainability challenges of our times, without which the objectives of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, the Paris Agreement and the Green Deal cannot be achieved.  I welcome the creation of a forest observatory to collect data and information on deforestation in Europe as well as globally. We have to call for this observatory to establish a mechanism to protect forest defenders. I fully support the creating of the early-warning alert mechanisms in order to notify public authorities, companies, including third-party schemes, and consumers of commodities originating in areas of eco-system conversion risk concerning loss and deterioration of forest and savannah and areas where human rights have been violated, and to assist in tackling these issues by intensifying dialogue and data sharing with respective third countries.  This mechanism is important to preserve the forestry sector which employs at least 500 000 people directly in the Union, and 13 million people worldwide, especially in rural areas. It encourages the Commission to strengthen the EU Action Plan on FLEGT, with a focus on Voluntary Partnership Agreements, and incorporate it into the new European Forest Strategy to encourage third countries to abandon deforestation policies.

name: Edina TÓTH
text: Writing. – The drivers of deforestation are diverse, complex and linked differently from one geographical area to another. I agree with the reporter that deforestation does indeed have a number of negative environmental, economic and social impacts, in particular climate, biodiversity and poverty. However, we differ in our positions on the issue. I believe that further intensive preparatory work is needed for the global forest protection mechanism to be operational. If we are to actively combat deforestation, the EU must take the initiative in many areas. This includes supporting capacity building in developing countries, strengthening forest governance and correcting shortcomings. I think it is important for the EU to support proven initiatives: for example, the Global Climate Change Alliance provides an appropriate framework for monitoring measures to promote dialogue with developing countries on deforestation and to continue efforts to tackle deforestation. What is certain is that the EU must take the lead in developing a global policy response to deforestation. The Community and the Member States should work together to pool resources and ensure the complementancing nature of actions. The fight against deforestation must be fought on several fronts. One thing is for sure, in this fight, my country, Hungary, will definitely be a partner.
